text: this has a great exploding head and looks great . it has a dirty deep amber-and slightly ruby brown color .  somewhat thin but more close to medium .
source/serving : 650ml bottle dated 2/19/2010 ( 6 months old ) smell : delicate and complex , but not dynamic . very nice overall .  it is slightly watery on the palate .

great nose - big , malty , sweet . smells like barley malt fresh out of the bag . a rather abrasive malt profile - i hate to use that word , but it best describes it for me . nice flavors all the way through , but fails to deliver a big full mouthfeel as promised by the nose and malty attack on the tip . the finish cleans out fairly well .  m - some carbonation , not much to speak of .
it pours clear ruddy amber with a very thick and creamy tan head .  lowish carbonation and a light , smooth mouthfeel .

exquisite critrusy , lemony aroma ; actually smells 'juicy ' . just amazing . flavour consists of traditional hefeweizen attributes with the addition of citrusy , american style hops .  i had this beer at the great waters facility as we stop in often . i try to take notes on the beers i try but sometimes forget . the attack was very smooth and there was a sweet and smooth flavor with faint hops character at the finish . i do n't think i have had any cask beers at great waters that i did n't like .
pours pitch black into a snifter . the visual is as appetizing as it 's ever going to get for a stout .  m : gritty and more astringent than any brown ale i 've ever tasted , very porterish feel .
a gorgeous midnight pitch-black , with luscious creamy , light-tan head , almost a finger thick . impressive sticky lacing .  too much carbonation for this style ( -1.0 ) .

the smell is very strong of hops . very floral and powerful . the taste it really dominated by hops and the bitterness at the end is quite nice .  this beer was purchased at cyclone liquors , in ames , iowa . the beer was very dark in color and tasted very well . i drank the beer warm and i think it was a good beer . i would try this beer again if it was presented to me . it had a very nice sweet taste for a german dunkel , which i am not a huge fan of .

aroma is great . rich dark chocolate . wow , what a disappointment after the aroma . mouthfeel is nice . a shame that a beer that smelled so good did n't live up to it .  m-explosive carbonation . tough to gauge the feel over the bubbles . a bit too carbonated for me .

nola brown ale , draft a big thick rocky head , deep ruby red color when held to the light . a nice looking beer .  light copper color with a large head s. malty with a slight resiny hop smell t. more bitter than sweet but well balanced with roasted malt m. a little to acidic and carbonated for my tastes d. a good lighter amber ale that i can heartily recommend

saranac black lager is a dark and clear tawny brown beer with a thick , lumpy , light beige head that has oily bubbles ; outstanding retention and lacing .  pretty weak mouthfeel , it 's a bit watery . i 'm enjoying the flavour and aroma quite a bit but the mouthfeel is a bit weak . but lacking in mouthfeel .

s - huge pine aroma that is quickly and easily enjoyable . massively beautiful from the get-go , with underlying citrus notes . a perfect , varied aroma that promises wonderful delights within t - slight pine taste , bit of grapefruit , pure hops abound . d - very nice , but perhaps lacking a bit of malt balance making this a bit more difficult to enjoy .  the feel had decent carbonation , if only it had n't been followed by a lingering metallic feel on the tongue .
poured into a tulip . this beer is a beautiful gold . stunning and fragrant .  m. a bit acidic d. overall a nice iipa .
s- totally amazing smell . just like pumkin pie .  m/d - a little sticky but the body is still thin and it feels appropriate for the style .

typical intense heller aroma , roasted pork and tons of smoked ham , sweet maple syrup , campfire , just rich malt altogether and intense smokiness . it somehow reminds vermont maple smoked cheddars which is no little task . taste is actually quite wheaty and fruity ( banana , lemon ) so its actually pretty well made since it was clearly the intention , but i dont really enjoy the atmosphere created from wheaty dusty tartness mixed with the big smokiness .  m & d - the brew is a tiny bit watery , the doughy character is a tiny bit too small , and so the mouthfeel is n't as full as i 'd expect .
the beer pours beautiful . great head and retention .  mouthfeel is a little too carbonated and light but i still enjoyed the beer in-spite of those tow minor complaints .

a : pours a crystal clear amber color with a fluffy white head that sticks around for a long time . without a doubt one of the best looking ipas i 've had in a while .  and this is a surprisingly warming , earthy-tasting beverage for a `` summer ale '' -- i would n't mind opening up one of these in midwinter either , except in that it lacks body . it 's in the mouthfeel that the summeriness stands out .

reviewed 11/16/2008 ( tap @ the stables , st. louis , mo ) : very cool presentation in a kasteel glass with a castle on the stem of the goblet-like glass . pours a very dark blood red body , with a lasting frothy pink head .  medium bodied and a bit sticky in the mouth .

best by date of 5/3/11 a : standard pour yields a billowy 2.5 finger light creamsicle colored head with very good retention . lacing is patchy and spotty with nice cling .  the first time i had this beer , i distinctly remember it being among the worst i had ever had . apparently my ba colleagues disagree , so i 'm giving it another try . there is some faint grassy hops , but this beer is mostly about the malt character . overall , this is way better than i remember . i might have to make this a regular part of my beer fridge ! or perhaps they had n't figured things out when the brewery was just getting started . glad that there 's another quality beer in e-town .
the lacing is astounding . pretty appealing .  more carbonation would go a long way .

this is obviously a schwarzbier or brazilian black beer -- not a euro dark lager . anway : nice black color with thick , foamy tan head , fades slow , very nice sticky lace .  s - some grassy hops paired with caramel malt t - slight hop bitterness resolving into some serious roasty malt , but then it 's all gone fairly quickly with just a hint of woody bitterness m - quite light with just a hint of carbonation on the back of the tongue ; the slight bitterness endures for a whlie d - quick drinkable , though the excessive roasty malt will probably get in the way ; little to no alcohol warmth nice drink ; did n't expect it to be as dark as it is - listed as an american porter , but it 's almost a supercharged brown ale .
hops . a touch of skunk . excellent aroma . t- hops ( pine forward ) .  m : very smooth , but seems pretty thin in terms of the body of the beer .
fairly strong aroma and inviting . t : definitely citrus forward , although the flavors are a bit more muted than the nose lead me to believe .  mouthfeel was average .
head is 2 fingers with very good retention eventually settling to a crown producing excellent lacing s- aroma does n't five much away .  mouthfeel : a bit thin and watery .

pours out somewhere between a hazed and cloudy light apricot body with tons of bubbles feeding a fluffy , rocky , and dimpled head .  i first had this beer a year ago and fell in love . so i was excited to see it appear once again this fall . i find it a very easy beer to drink even for the inexperienced beer drinker . flavorful and rich with malts , a slight hint of hops towards the end . the aroma is sweet but not overpowering , you can definitely smell the sweet malt that went into this brew . i highly recommend this beer . unfortunately its not around year round but it definitely will give you something to look forward to come fall .

pretty good aroma wafting from this especially when warm , distinguishable espresso and coffee grounds with baker 's chocolate , coarse grains and a earthy woody note , not unlike campfire smoke with the addition of some licorice . great aroma and feel , solid overall .  had to give it the maximum points for appearance , because even out of an imported bottle , it looks just right . comes in with an alcohol bite that 's almost like an imperial . pertty nice taste , though , and if you had some , i would n't refuse .

this is a beautiful looking beer . not much lacing or retention , but the color alone gives this one a prefect appearance rating .  this is pretty good , but not up to the level of most other weihenstephaner beers in my book . the aroma is raisiny and alcoholic with grapes , dry grain , hint of bread , honeym , pine , herbs , and hay . the taste is bread , herbs , pine , faint hints of honey , apple and lemon , with a tingly pine-herb flavour and bitterness , along with a faintly rough , thin mineral-water quality . it goes pretty well with food and is fairly easily drinkable , but not great .

pours a beautiful dark brown with a slight ruby hue on the outer edges , nice thick microfoam head that leaves nice lacing .  this is an excellent pilsner . number three on my list , only behind konig and pilsner urquell . just as crisp and refreshing as both of those , but a little lighter in taste and body . very clean , top quality .

the beer smells pretty good , very hoppy like one would expect from this type of beer .  this is a great light summer ale from pike brewing . this could be a great crossover ale for the bmc drinkers . it is very light yellow and clear . head is white light and fluffy , overall a great light easy drinking als . this is a beer that everyone will like .

poured from a 12 oz bottle , 2008 version a : pours a clear mahogany brown , with ruby hues , under a big slightly off white head . excellent retention and lace .  smell : uh oh , something is going wrong ... taste : blecchhh . my stomach is starting to turn . what happened to this beer ? simply put , the taste is sour and offensive . beef notes : horrible . what was the thought process when putting this beer out for sale ?

really nice , dark golden color . really substantial , bone-white head that has little recession .  the mouthfeel was a bit watery which could be due to the fact it is only 4.8 % and thus not alot of malt was apparently used , but i think it held up well over time , although i have not tried this fresh so i can not compare .
the beer pours amazingly dark reddish purple with a creamy purple head of 3 cm foaming up easily .  good carb , but feels a bit thin and watered down in general .
pours copper hue , with a nice , long lasting , white head and lively carbonation .  the carbonation is surprisingly strong for the style .

poured from the growler into a shaker pint glass . a : clear , dark brown color with garnet highlights ; over one finger of light beige foam head . heavy lacing remains on the glass .  m good medium body , with a lot of carbonation , either takes away from this beer .

they have to put some sort of chemical happiness in there to keep everything together ... beamish is almost black , but truly more ruby brown than anything . the head is bleached mocha with a fantastic nitro lace pattern .  i think that the long trip from greece to williamsburg , va did n't treat this beer too kindly . pours and looks like the standard heine-clone . taste was rather flat .
this beer pours a hazy orange color . the head is a mammoth three inches in height , and recedes slowly into a large , rocky cap of foam .  the mouth was a bit oily but not unpleasantly so .

the aroma is very appealing . sweet hoppy fruit notes , strawberry licorice , apricot nectar . very nice .  smooth , nice , a little thin maybe . not a ton of carbonation at the end which leaves it a little watery .

pours a glorious deep , garnet-tinged amber color , with a thick , creamy , sticky , cream-colored head on top .  mouf & gt ; average drinkability & gt ; great ! more beers to add to the breakfast menu at my house .

pour produces an impenetrably obsidian ale with better than an inch of fluffy and dense mocha foam that loiters on top and fades gradually , leaving thick lacing .  good coffee and chocolate and malt ( ate a small piece of oreo birthday cake with this and it was damn near orgasmic ) mouthfeel is surprisingly thin .

aroma : an amazing , complex aroma which far exceeds any other pils aroma i have smelled . lemony , peppery , summery , yeasty and malty all zipping around my nose . taste : does n't live up to the aroma but is n't bad .  smoky , malty and mildy coffee-like . deep black with a thumb thick mocha head . fore is hoppy bitter then roasted barley malt follows . very much in the fullers vein as opposed to the more roasty and coffee/chocolate flavored american porters . very nice brew .

aroma is mostly complex stages of hops , it 's easy to believe there are 10 varieties , there 's the big american c hops character combined with the refined english ones . very relaxing to sniff on and ultra-complex , like a touch of vanilla on fresh citrus ( grapefruit ) . in mouth this dances on the tongue , nice effervescence , creamy , full-bodied , complex malt sweetness and an obvious balancing yeastiness . this is a delicious big generous beer . tasting this with my buddy martint , we came to the conclusion that given the choice to pick only 2 beers from a same brewery to have an infinite supply of , hotd with fred and adam would probably win over quite anyone .  mouthfeel : thin yet flavorful .

smell : damn this smells great . i 'm getting sugar coated rasperries , sweet malts , milk chocolate , and toffee .  a bit watery at the start , but , it gradually gains weight as it rolls to the back of the palate .

tasted june 22nd 2011 ( from notes ) poured into a la chouffe tulip a - a clear blood red , one finger tan head and some lacing s - alcohol , wine barrels , sweet dried fruits , earth , oak , french vanilla and more sweet and alcohol t - alcohol , lots of sugar , sweet malts , tons of sweet dried fruit , black cherries , wine barrels , raisins , charred oak , molasses , carmelised brown sugar and vanilla .  m - kind of watery , but good carbonation .

pours a dark reddish brown with a huge off white head with huge fat lacing .  poured chilled in large ale glass ; bottle courtesy buzzlitebeer a : dark chocolate colored ; good frothy head ; decent carb action s : chicory and ( what ? ) tobacco predominates ; musty coffee t : wow , unusual ; the brown ale is a base for experimentation into coffee and tobacco ; bitter cacao serve this to friends and you 'll definitely have a talking point ; it 's very distinctive

lighter and brighter looking than i expected , nelson poured without any `` redness '' i typically , and erroneously , associate with rye beers . a clear hay golden hue , with a beautiful cream white head ; excellent retention and lacing .  m : a little thin on the body , and surprisingly light and spiky with the carbonation .
s : pinot barrel with some dark fruit riding a wave bringing a boatload of vanilla and whiskey .  mouthfeel seemed a bit to lean to me .
a wonderful sweet , almost fruity smell after opening the bottle .  the body is on the thin side , with below-average carbonation .

golden colored and pours a huge white fluffy head with good retention .  this beer has a flavor i really like m- pretty thin and bubbly , almost reminds me of a bmc feel o- one of my favorite tasting pale ales .
pours an opaque thick looking black , with a fat beige head . very attractive .  the body of the beer is actually approaching medium and the carbonation is not overly fizzy as many macros are .

wonderful aroma . warm and oaky , molasses . almost get a bbq sauce scent , very spicey like a worcester sauce . very interesting tastes in this one , unusual .  the only detraction i can fin is the below average body .

hazy yellow orange body , extremely cloudy , with a strong 2 finger head . lots of lacing and rather good looking by any standards .  taste : sweet malt , raisins , a lot of sweet nutty flavors like pecans , sour/tart dark cherry flavor , ending with a nutty malt characters mouthfeel : really light body , low carbonation , pretty basic .

smell : loads of coriander , yeasty nuttiness and clove phenols , with a heavy dose of of bubblegum , yummy ! mouthfeel : very carbonated and full body notes : excellent . different and similar to the original at the same time .  as readily available as bud , and a whole lot better . a great fall-back session brew , which is good with a meal , or having several at a baseball game .

very heavy hefe pour . thick , deep yellow gold that glubglubs out of the bottle and leaves a giant head .  nice carbonation , but this comes off as a little thin . this should be more drinkable considering its thin body , but as this is a stout , the thin body is a bit of a turn off .

cloudier than the surface of jupiter . a great looking , one finger head , sticks around for quite a while .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin and the carbonation is quite sharp ; a bit fizzier than i 'd like .

stellar appearance with this beer . it pours a really nice orange amber color with fine yeast particles suspended in it like stars . very attractive .  tastes pretty amazing really . watery on the tongue but ends dryish .

when you crack the can open you can hear the tsss of the nitro kick in , then it pours a full pinto of nitro head which slowly ( but faster than on tap ) dissipates into the body . nose is a bit roasty and creamy , nice and smooth .  it was also a little to carbonated for me in the mouth feel category .

aroma held very much of the brandy barrel aging . cherries vanilla , and some very tart notes as well . tart cherries oak and vanilla mix nicely in the flavor good caramel malt sweet backbone . amazingly complex and flavorful . really great beer is grounded due to complete lack of carbonation .  a little lighter and less sweet than many `` real '' belgian beers , and a little thinner in the mouthfeel department .
a beautiful deep amber with ruby and copper hues . frothy white head with superb retention and lacing down the glass .  mouthfeel was a little thin , that 's my only complaint .

pours a deep dark chestnut brown color that is nearly opaque with mahogany edges when held to a light and a two finger frothy , soapy tan head . very good retention , only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glass with chunks , rings and splotches of soapy lacing .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin and harsh from the acidity and carbonation . also finishes quite dry with little to no bitter .

) appearance : very nice appearance ... shiny amber body , very clear , big frothy beige head with great lacing . it 's a nice looking barleywine , thats for sure smell : odd ... metallic , plasticy pungent hops , sharp candied aromas ... unusual and difficult to describe taste : this is just a wierd beer .  an e-mail from the brewery indicated that twins lager is not the same beer as hauenstein , just with a different label . schells tells me that the twins lager uses a different recipe and yeast than the hauenstein , but a side by side comparison leaves me wondering why they would go through the trouble . i have always liked `` cheap '' beers . the beer drinkers of olden days wanted it cold , crisp , and cheap . but for afternoon lazing back and swigging , there is certainly nothing wrong with a cold bottle of twins lager . twins lager might be `` twice as refreshing '' as the label purports , but , boy would it be a treat to drink an original recipe fitgers again !

appearance : darkest , thickest brown head i 've seen , even a notch above rogue 's shakespeare stout . pitch black even when directly on top of a 60w lamp . tall head , intense lacing .  mouthfeel is somewhat disappointing . if we 're talking about banana bread here , then it should be thicker , like bread .

glassware : tall 14.4 oz glass ( i love pouring it to the halfway point , let it sit and agitate it by swirling it aggressively just like scotch whisky ) appearance : amber brown hue on the pour , with a reddish head nose : i loved every moment of this brew , i sat for at least 2 hours sniffing on this puppy ( if only these guys aged their ale in pappy van winkle 's bourbon barrels , i can only dream ) palate : loving the booziness of it , sweet caramel , vanilla oak and maraschino cherries . all in all , a decent coating with a medium to long finish . pairings : a relatively inexpensive bahia blu robusto went very well with this drink , the hearty cedar core blends well with the sweet caramel and vanilla oak .  it is a bit thin , bordering on watery with adequate to slightly low carbonation .

the nose is excellent . chocolate , caramel , dark breads , a little honey and molasses . the nuances from the nose did n't really carry over .  the mouthfeel was thin with a slightly dry aftertaste .
very inviting . malt beginning just sorta slides on by without really putting down stakes .  bittersweet finish . kind of think and syrupy on the palate .

a : thank god with the help of the cellarman and barman it pours a pint of heavenly nectar~~ white , tight frothy head on top of a pale amber hued nectar , very low carbonation just like a cask-conditioned ale should be . the beer head settles to a 1cm thick layer of creamy foam and stays forever ( i mean throughout the drink ) , leaving incredibly tight and creamy lacing ... this is a dream for a cask-conditioned ale , right in front of me , really .  a surprisingly great beer from a brewing giant . it could have been a little less punishing when guzzled , but hey it 's a dark beer and we are not dealing with coors light here . i think the beer is buitiful to look at , and is rather smooth . but the lable and beer fit perfectly ph
a dark body that exhibits a reddish tinge when held up to the light , with thick lacing spiraling down the side .  m - a little water , but it goes down smoothly d - this is a really good beer .
a sexy , blurred mahagony colour with patches of head . would leave small remnants of lacing .  a little too thick on the tongue , but nice .

when i first opened the bottle i could smell the cherrys right away . it was a very sweet smell which suprised me that the beer was not as sweet as the smell . very nice appearance .  m : upper light body with high carbonation .

a - golden brew with extremely intense carbonation large head fueled by the bubbling .  in my opinion , flying dog brewery has created a great seasonal , smooth-tasting beer with very little bite or after taste . i would definitely recommend it to any self-respecting beer drinker who might be having an end-of-summer party this or any october .
a - dark as night with amber hue creeping in with the light . thick head that lasts the entire time drinking it slowly and leaving very nice lacing .  mouthfeel is sticky-sweet and dense .

the spiciness attacks your olefactory senses with a vengence . aroma reminds me of some winter warmers i 've had .  m : mouthfeel is decent , goes down reasonable smooth even with the slight burning sensation .

ale here in western ny so quickly.my second time trying this new black ipa style of beer my first being rogue black brutal wich i had mixed feelings about , this poured a deep dark brown but not black some ruby colored highlights thruought a thick 2 finger head atop that never completely settled just a fantastic creamy mass left with gobs of lace behind in my impy pint glass , just awesome.mix of piney and tropical fruit hops and black malt in the nose mainly i picked up some pineapple and molasses wich was nice and it strayed away from the one dimensional resiny hop profile and caramel malt base.the hops are big but so is the black malt element of this beer sure its big and piney and citrusy but the dark bread and molasses in there is large as well in finely balanced that black malt character really shows itself.the alcohol creeps a bit but this is a very interesting brew it has it all big hops and some malty sweetness , another top notch brew form one of the best .  the mouthfeel is very fizzy due to the ample carbonation .
wow . thick bourbon and aforementioned flavors , mostly caramel . lovely beer , quite exceptional .  4.5 m - lacks body . a bit thin but spritzy carbonation .

pours a three fingered cream head that slowly fades to a thin layer , leaving a good lace .  m : the body is not as thick as i was expecting . it on the thin side as far as stouts go , but drinks very smoothly . i would have liked a thicker body , but that 's just being picky .

appearance- beautiful aroma- smells like raw dark chocolate and smokiness taste- bitter chocolate and smoke overpower at first . one of the less complex stouts i 've had .  smell is of old corn/rice and skunk . pew . taste was horrendous . a skunky malt liquor flavor mixed with sweet rice/corn adjunct . maybe it went bad on it 's journey from the carib-bean ? looks like i should have gone for the sam light that was also in the fridge ...

s : a pretty complex smell , though coffee beans tend to be the dominant auroma . it 's nicely accented by a faint hint of sweet chocolate . t : there 's a real bright fruitiness that i do n't really pick up on in the scent that compliments ( but not well ) the coffee flavor that is n't so much roasted anymore as it is just kind of bitter . both are underwhelming to say the least , but this taste is n't as bad as it is disappointing .  the palate is average .

aroma is funky and enticing ! smells like a farmhouse ale of the jolly pumpkin style . i 'm disappointed ; freetail can do much better .  its perfectly balanced and not overly done . m very medium , which i find most all stone beers to be and i dont really complain about . the carbonation is present and isnt overly aggressive or submissive .

this brew is really gorgeous . nice hint of red , obviously , but the cloudiness swirls around and give the beer a nice look . head is off-white and puffy ; almost too big even with a careful pour .  m : starts off creamy , but i 'm pretty quickly struck by how watery this is . the carbonation is decent , but i find this surprisingly thin .

smells like delicious ginger snaps , cinnamon and some clove . delicious . it has a medium body with a good amount of carbonation . definitely a sipper , but a very good sipper .  m : a little bit thinner than expected , medium-light bodied with low carbonation , lightly creamy .
ever so slightly hazy orange color , with rocky head that lasts well and leaves good lacing .  like cheap malt liquor infused with citrus and nail polish remover .

a : poured with a large , white fluffy head that was very long lasting ... never got below 1-2 fingers size . body is a beautiful , dark orange color , with excellent clarity .  very well carbonated , but not alot of head . i am thinking its a unique hop that i have not experienced alot of . thoughts - this beer is one of my favs from shiner .

good size 2+ finger white foamy head that looked more soapy as it receded . excellent lacing , dissipated to a thin head that lasted till the end .  ) my only qualm was the the body seemed a little thin .

pours a deep copper color with a big creamy tan head that lasts forever and leaves a great looking lace all the way down the sides of the glass .  this beer poured a dirty blonde color , with a haziness that made me suspect that i would n't enjoy this beer too much . aroma was malty , and flavor was a sweet maltiness with only a hint of hops . this was n't what i was expecting from an american pale ale , and i really did n't enjoy it . i may have gotten an old beer , but there is no date code on this beer , so i have no way of knowing its age and it gets what it gets ... most of this one is going down the drain .

this beer pours a gorgeous clear deep orange amber color with a 3 finger ( on an easy pour ) of offwhite/tannish thick sudsy head . the head retention on this was ridiculous !  quenching , medium-light body , citrus-earthy character .

d - the aroma is very nice , but the flavor just does n't live up to it ( an unfortunate trend i have noticed with dieu du ciel ) .  mouthfeel is probably the most disappointing aspect of this otherwise excellent beer ; the carbonation promised by the head largely disappeared , leaving a slick , full bodied beer with very light carbonation . a nice , sharp bite of carbonation would have been welcome in this case , drying out the finish nicely , but that does n't happen here .

the color of this beer i find just amazing . it 's so dark as it sits in a guinness glass , with it 's beautiful smooth head . are there bubbles finer than these ? in contrast to how heavy it looks , it 's goes down incredibly smooth and fast .  the overall feel is dry , like it should be , but unfortunately , it 's also a touch chaulky , which is pretty unfortunate .

very still with incredible lacing s - dry roasted malts , sugar and bread , a touch of spice t - earthy roasted malts , dry corn , very malty with a mild hop finish m - nitro tap gives a creamy smoothness that makes it super sessionable o - really great !  my only complaint with this beer is that it is a little thin .

pours a honey colored amber color with a three finger tight bubbled head with lots of wispy lace from start to finish .  i 'd love to try this on cask , if only to taste it more directly without all the carbonation dancing across my tongue .

the first impression i got when i took a long deep breathe in the the glass was sweet malt and chocolate , oh my god , chocolate ! it seems as though i was sniffing a fresh glass of dark chocolate milk . it just smells creamy and smooth . the taste was roasted malt and grains combined with the chocolate .  while the carbonation is nice , the overall feel is a bit thin .

pours out a very clear deep reddish bordering on copper/ bronze with a big light tan colored head , great retention and nice lace .  good carbonation and medium bodied . flavor is spicy , yeasty , hints of sweetness that gets buried by the yeast . lingering yeasty aftertaste .

coffee dominates the nose and overpowers the other smells that are underneath . nevertheless , the smell is very enticing .  m - a little thinner than i thought and more carbonated than i would expect .

the color was hazy lemon yellow with two fingers of rocky , yellow-tinted head . the cap retained itself beautifully and the lacing was in solid bands .  body is ok , nothing special but not bad . very boozy finish .
huge four finger mocha head . really not all that impressive .  m- somewhat thin , actually . smooth , clean , but a little more watery than i expected .

flavour is bit more restrained , still very nice with all the traditional hefe characteristics , wheaty and yeasty with cloves but also some caramel and brown bread . aftertaste is , like with most wheat beers , very moderate but nice . can you expect a hefeweizen to be much better than this ?  m : relatively light though not particularly carbonated .

slow pour with not alot of head . incredible color . just beautiful dark ruby . the sun shined through it and it almost looks like a red wine .  the mouthfeel was a bit unimpressive too light in my opinion .

this beer pours a beautiful cherry color with a nice one finger cherry red head .  reminded me a bit of bmc with a bit of syrup added for sweetness . the taste is more of the same with a quick malty dryness at the end that seems to say , `` ha ! had you fooled..you thought there was about to be something pleasant here , did n't you ? in fact , this may get sacrificed to the kitchen sink . as i always say , in total fairness to the brewer and his ( or her ) intentions , this may have its fans , but it most assuredly is *not* for me ...

pours out to a clear copper color , forming a modest whipped yellow head with excellent retention and solid sheets of lacing . this is how i like my pale ales to look . beautiful !  the mouthfeel is light bodied with a high level of biting carbonation ( the carbonation is the only part of this beer that i 'm not too fond of ) . quite dry due to the high level of carbonation .

s -- the deepest , richest coffee smell i 've gotten from any beer . lots of other coffee stouts have this `` stong '' of a smell , but none that i can remember have such a deep roasty smell , its hard to describe since i am not a coffee drinker .  a new contender for the worst beer i 've ever tasted . it tasted like a carbonated v8 with sweeteners added .
pours a two finger white head that fades slowly , leaving a good lace . nice crystal clear amber color .  m : medium to full body but needs more carbonation .

really nice aroma . smells of pecans , buttery crust , vanilla and dark fruit .  the mouth feel was hindered a bit , as the bottle had n't been sitting in my refrigerator long enough , the ale could have been a little more carbonated .

brown/red/amber , on the clear side , nice head that lasts . maybe give it a touch more opacity . edit : if they just called it a winter warmer and dropped barleywine from the name , why , it would probably just be average and not bad .  does smell a little like `` beer , '' as my wife would say . so sweet on the tongue . slight raspberry tartness but it is like drinking raspberry sorbet after it melts . it is still trying to recover from the sweetness . a good once in a while beer . sorbet beer , i tell ya .

tasted nov. 21rst 2011 ( from notes ) tulip a - very nice translucent blood red , 1/4 finger off white fizzy head and minimum lacing s - peat , smoke , nuts , alcohol , slight wine , lots of yeast and oak t - so much peat , wow ! sap , wood , lemon , citrus , alcohol , sauvignon blanc , more peat , some nice hops and the peat kind of peats ( haha ) out all the other flavors m - medium body , medium acidity , low complexity , not balanced and very long finish d - while at first few sips the peat is overwhelming and almost nasty , after a bit the peat is more in the background of a smokey , citrus , alcoholic ale .  mouthfeel is effervescent , lighter bodied ( almost thin ) , medium carbonation and slightly dry .

lightly spicy with some typical weizen-like notes of clove and yeast . this is quite a fruity smelling brew with alcohol esters being fairly pronounced . for a beer that smells quite deep and intense with character , the flavor falls a bit short and is not nearly as complex . as the brew warms up , some chocolate grain notes become evident .  it is a little bit sweet on the tongue . i could stand it to be a little bit more dry .

pours a dark brown/black color with some dark ruby hues when held up to the light , excellent amount of head that fades at a good rate to leave some lacing .  mouthfeel : surprisingly thin body , full carbonation , fairly thick coat after the swallow .

pours a murky , dark dark brown colour , only a sliver of colour really visible . head is stunning : beige , dense , small bubbles that wobbles on top but retains , with a beautiful , vibrant cascade when poured . lace is clingy and thick , like coffee foam . that 's a stunning beer .  it was barely palatable : very little carbonation - full of sour , gone-bad notes .

appearance : pours a slightly hazy ruby-brown with an inch of foamy off-white head on top . head is slow to settle leaving behind a nice lace along the glass . aroma : bottle depicts oranges , though the aroma is more a tart cherry with some hints of sweetness .  i got this beer in the beers of the world gift box for christmas . immediate taste is a lil sharp and bready with a hint of citrus in the smell . it was not an out of this world experience , but it is a very light and enjoyable beer for everyday or get togethers .

aroma starts off with some vanilla and slight chocolate , but really comes to live as the brew warms . banana 's , plums , lots of malty goodness . taste is caramel , dried fruit some alcohol as she warms . definately worthy of the hype .  the mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with no carbonation .

clear golden body wit a 3-plus finger foamy , clumpy white head that never really goes anywhere . big old patches of lacing on the glass . if reviews were based on looks alone , this beer would rate very well .  m- low carbonation , medium-body .

the aroma is wonderfully smokey and peaty , with some dark malts in there too . great aroma and interesting flavor .  the mouthfeel i found oddly watery ... but still fairly full bodied at the same time . carbonation was fairly mild - maybe that lended to the `` watery '' sensation .

app- a nice dark brown which looked alot like maple syrup .  i 'm rather late with this review but i had this on tap at nicholson 's downtown and it reminded me of sierra nevada celebration . in fact at the time the original name was celebration ale . i 've since had a few growlers from jungle jim 's and though it 's a quailty brew i 've experienced some diacetyl like off-flavors when served from the growler . still it 's quite enjoyable and recommended . i wish the best to mike and his future brews !
lots of big , flaky , dark specks rolling around in the carbonation ... looks pretty cool .  carbonation a little higher than i expect in the style but still manages to be exceptionally drinkable .

appearance - jet black in color with a very nice one finger light tan head that lingers while drinking . perfect for keeping in the flavor and smell of the beer smell - very light on the malt smell , but somewhat heavy on the bitter hops .  apricots . hops undetectable above the jaw-clenching , eye-squinching , head-shaking sourness . awful . ugh . otherwise , it defintely seems to be beer , ( if in no way resembling any version of a contemporary pa ) , but with a sour and bitter fruitiness that pervades , annoys , and overwhelms . the originally enticing head cashed in early and diminished to virtual non-existence before i gave up trying to like this one ; very little lacing to wash out of the glass . wo n't drink the other two in the sampler , did n't finish this one , and opened a sn celebration ale to get the taste out of my mouth .

it 's almost stout black , with very sparse mahogany highlights . maybe two fingers of foam , the color of light coffee , rise up and then fall right back down . toffee , vanilla and burnt sugar are the primary aromas , with bourbon and oak providing subtle complexities in the background . the body is full and creamy , but the carbonation is a bit too subdued , even for a malt forward style . king henry 's a solid beer , but given how well goose island 's barrel aged beers usually come out , i 'm just a little bit disappointed .  m - comes across a tad light on the carbonation , making it a bit watery for my liking .

i actually smell this beer about 2 feet away when opening . very citrusy and piney , a small amount of orange juice sweetness is present . a very nice extreme beer , i may be afraid to try fresh .  mouthfeel is light and carbonation fades to almost flat .
the head fades very slowly , leaving a massive lacing .  the carbonation is ok ; small fresh bubbles at a decent strength .

pours a deep chestnut brown , with a layer of foamy white goodness on top . laces amazingly . the more beers i try from this brewery the more i realize they sure know how to make a beer look good .  m - body is a little thin , moderate carbonation .
almost black colour , with a very good head .  mouthfeel was ok ; about the same as urquell .

pours a great red color with an off-white head which sticks around for a while and clings to the glass . the taste is somewhere between a dark lager and a stout ... it 's got a good malty taste with a great strong finish .  mouthfeel is soft and a little heavy .
poured a medium copper hue with a huge chunky white head . there was very good retention and sticky lacing .  the mouthfeel was light but a bit chewy .
this one is jet black with an enormous off white / light tan head . this head is quite frothy and laces incredibly .  light to medium in body .

biggish , crusty , light tan head leaves lots of hard , sticky lacing . very pretty .  though this is a red ale of stormy garnet and the menu states it is `` brewed with 20 % honey malts for a touch of sourness '' ( honey = sourness ? it is not merely that this red ale tastes bad ; it is absolutely offensive . of the lowest evolutionary order . the entire beer is corrupted by spoilage and should n't be served publicly .
smell is exactly what you 'd expect , with a strong earthy espressor aroma and some chocolate notes , with a bit of sweet maltiness in there .  m- a bit thin for my taste .

a truly spectacular appereance , deep chestnut with reddish purple highlights . a massive head that left thorough lacing . really attractive . quite pleasing minus the fact that no taste seems to linger .  m : medium mouthfeel with moderate carbonation .

bottle courtesy of bu11zeye : poured a slightly cloudy bright yellow color ale with a super huge foamy pure white head with great retention and great lacing .  mouthfeel : the carbonation is light , as is the body .

aroma : pine and floral hops . big hop profile . overall , a decent brew , but nothing extraordinary .  a - black on the pour with no head whatsoever s - big burnt malt and bittersweet chocolate aroma along with some bourbon , some oak and vanilla in there as well , slight alcohol , as the beer warms up , smells almost like straight bourbon , maybe more like a bourbon and cola t - big bourbon flavor right up front , lots of oak as well , some bittersweet chocolate in the body , finish is more bourbon and oak along with some vanilla , alcohol notes , long finish m - a bit too flat for my taste , full-bodied but totally devoid of any carbonation action in the mouth d - i 'm glad port put this in a 375ml bottle , because this is a sipper , treated this almost like fine bourbon sipping for quite awhile , but i could sip on this all night very interesting beer .

the smell has a great citrus/banana smell to it that captions your nose the second you pour into a glass . very satisfied with the smell . taste - the taste is very good . the smell and taste together make this an exceptional beer to drink .  m - the feel is not terrible .
it pours a dark brown to almos black color with a huge fluffy tan to light brown head .  the carbonation does not give this beer a pleasant mouthfeel that i would like .

pours a clear amber color with a creamy off white tannacios head that leaves great lacing .  cons : the low carbonation level does hurt many factors of the beer , but it is such an exquisitely brewed offering , it 's only a minor issue .

pours black with a dark brown creamy head . very nice beer to look at .  this was my first encounter with pumpkin ale . i must confess that i could not finish the bottle . i had the distinct impression that the beer was trying to taste like something and not quite getting there . fearing the latter , i tossed the bottle after about five sips .

s - bourbon , bourbon , bourbon , buttery toffee , roasted cashews , malted vanilla milkshake , tiny amount of hops , pecan pie , and harsh booze . this is the best smelling barleywine this nose has ever smelled . perfect . t - harsh and boozy , but delicious . caramelized sugar up front with tons of bourbon .  i always look forward like most do the annual stone anniversary brews.poured a rich deep amber with a tight and sticky one finger off white head , big hops in the nose with a mix pine and herbal/leaf , there is a gummy , fruity-like sweet note as well.the mouthfeel is a bit sharp i will say it crashes down the gullett at first , it does begin to smooth out after a few sips but still seems a bit harsh.no holds barred hops hit the palate up front with big pine and big herbalness , a healthy does of sweeter alcohol gives a slight burn along with a bit of dark fruit.very good but seems like it something that should sit for awhile , still another fine one from stone .

the beer pours a delightful orange/amber with a heavy off-white head .  drink this on tap at city beverage in durham . i like the color and mouthfeel , though a bit thin for a heavy beer aroma is slightly sweet and complex spices taste is toasted barley , spices , and slight caramel with little head . drinks easy for a heavy beer
the smell is certainly its best quality .  mouf & gt ; meh . okay . average .

the smell is strong of both a carmel brandy and a little alcohol is evident . the alcohol that was apparent in the scent is not in the mouthfeel , which is very nice .  m : medium body with low carb . dry finish . nothing special here .

bear republic tribute ale is a very clear , very lively , deep crimson brown berr with a huge , lumpy , beige head .  a completely black beer with a thin mocha head . boris is a thick , almost to the point of sludgy beer with a roasted malt taste with a noticeable but background hop presences . the oatmeal comes into play as a slight cookie taste . overall it 's a great beer that worthy of a try .

pours a nice creamy sunshine-yellow-wheat color . head is thick and creamy which is typical of the widget-type cans .  the only thing slightly disappointing about this beer for me was the mouthfeel seemed a bit watery .

the aroma is that of fresh american hops that have been sitting in the aging tank for a while . this beer is dry hopped every day for a month and the aroma tell the story . citrusy aromas that gram the oral senses and tell a story of freshness . it is surprisingly balanced and the hop aroma and flavor is a real treat . score : my personal taste score was a 93 / 100 .  mf : the carbonation is n't quite as spritzy as i would hope to go along with the huge sourness , the body is light d : this is a great lambic .
the appearance is the best attribute of this beer for it is a nice amber-brown and has a steady head that leaves rings of lace .  light , decently carbonated , and quenching for the desert dweller .

poured black with a thick brown head . the retention was great . very creamy and capuccino like looking head .  a-garnet with small ring of foam s-raisin , pancake syrup , faint vinager t-assertive sour front , sour cherry , some malt sweetness , dates m-medium , with average carbonation d-very tasty !

charcoal black with an inch thick teddy bear brown head that quickly sinks to an eighth of an inch . excellent lacing persists for some time thereafter .  flavor is absolutely nothing like an oud bruin .

the smell is the best part of this beer : very hoppy and `` dirty '' . the taste is good , but i feel that it 's a bit weak compared to dogfish head 's 90 minute ipa . overall , a good ipa , but not the best i 've had .  the body is surprisingly light with moderate carbonation , helping to make this very drinkable .

the head is one inch of bright white foam that recedes very slowly into a firm cap of lacing that lasts until the beer is gone , and leaves rings of lacing all down the sides of the glass .  nice dark brown color with fantnaztic lacing ! smells choclotly with coffee . tastes even and thick with cocoa sweet caramel flavors continuing thru . good for its class this porter represents well , its much better than its younger brother . would drink again .

the liquid is dark amber and clear and is topped off by a plentiful marshmallowy tan colored head . the retention and lacing are out of this world . mountains of foam cling to the glass indefinitely .  mouthfeel is a bit thinner than i would have expected .
the smell is wonderful , but what happened in the translation to taste ?  mouthfeel is way more thin than the head and lacing made me think it would be . very quaffable .

smell : this one is all about that distinctive fruity grape note ( thinks welsh 's grape jelly filled grape bubblegum ) in the beginning that then gets washed over by a classic cantillon urine and yeast wave . truly unique and highly enjoyable . taste : same as the nose but more integrated and not as grape dominant as the nose .  mouthfeel : this was my one issue with this beer . it loses carbonation quickly , and with not that much to start with , it is kind of a bummer . a little sticky as well but the taste makes up for a bit of this .

drank on-tap at atwood 's tavern , cambridge , ma served in a stemmed glass gorgeous appearance . thick , lasting rings of lacing coated the glass .  tingly in the nose which is common with sour ales but this is n't sour at all t. sweet with dried fruit , malty m. has a biting quality , a bit to carbonated .

the head is an extremely pale tan and stands at two inches tall . the head is frothy and light .  mouthfeel : a bit thin the only thing i can say i 'm disappointed about here just seems watery i even recall the original munich formula having more body but hey sturdy carbonation excellent o-fest .
a : very nice translucent amber color with a half finger of white head . good head retention .  thin mouthfeel , this is the achilles heel of the beer .

this is apparently a modification of this location 's recent belgian ale , and also has an addition of pineapple . a- red-copper , thick white rocky head lasts very well and leaves some lacing . there is a bit of haze as well .  m : it 's a little thin , but i kind of like it . d : improved because of the thin mouthfeel .
overall , this is a complex smelling beer and wonderfully balanced . t : disappointingly not as good as the smell .  good carbonation , which i appreciate . minimal complexity to this beer .

this is the dead-on look for a pilsner ; pale straw color with steady streams of bubbles heading for the surface . the head is huge and sticky and clings to the side of the glass as if it were a life-or-death matter .  the mouthfeel is quite thin , verging on watery .

pours a slightly hazy amber body with a good inch or so of off-white head that persists and leaves great lacing .  a soft , almost too light mouthfeel and a little weak carbonation , the only appearent downside of this brew in my opinion .

appearance : creamy froth deep dark brown , nearly ebony color smell : deep dark roasted coffee and subtle dark chocolate and some nice cinnamon spice aroma taste : a heavy dose of black coffee , zero alcohol burn , lacked power though , you have to like coffee to liek this beer . mouthfeel : light bodied for a stout drinkability : a solid stout and interesting pumpkin pie aspect  mouthfeel : it 's a bit heavy for the style .

appears a dark brownish black with a rocky 2 finger tan head . leaves some nice , chunky lacing sticking all over my deep tulip glass .  m - medium to light body , low carbonation , smooth mouthfeel going down , perhaps a bit watery .

nose is fantastic ! uniquely fruity , like a cranberry-mango chutney . hops are detectable and make this a complex sniffer , probably the best smelling tripel i have ever laid nostrils upon . fruit levels take on the best from belgium , impressive . very nice brew , might be my favorite that i have had so far from the bruery .  the feel is a little odd . it does n't seem to be too carbonated , but the bubbles sting like sprite against your lips .

a - moderately vigorous pour yields an over the top , dense , styrofoam khaki-colored head . decent sticky legs , too . impressive !  m - extremely light and watery , typical carbonation from a cask .
bottle poured cloudy amber large white head that lasts thru the whole experiance .  mouthfeel : there is a lot of bitterness .

awesome bouquet ; fruitiness and candy malts . even so a pretty good drop .  is this someones idea of a joke ? rotten peaches with a kick of dirty feet is not something i prefer in my beer . sour an nasty , she be . i should have know by the pour , cider apple yellow fizzy white head . cripe , im glad i only got 2 bottles of this overpriced ( $ 2.50 a pop ) sour peach soda geez , only 4.5 % . i would have kicked myself in the sack for buying this , but im no longer that agile .

very nice nose . nice raisin notes . otherwise very clean .  malts help to round it out a little , but that bitterness hangs around for quite a bit m : medium body with typical sa carbonation , slightly oily d/o : well , apparently zeus is known for that intense piney flavor , so it is highlighted well here .

s - cherries , orange peel , and fresh fruits combine to create an enticing aroma . a definite yeasty quality is also present .  m : sharp carbonation is pretty overpowering , and any refreshing aspects of the smell and taste are lost .
great amber apperance with thick ass head that will not stop clinging to the glass .  mouthfeel is on the light end .

poured a deep dark reddish-brown into my guinness pint glass , and the tan head reached the top . beautiful .  the mouthfeel starts off kind of watery since this seems to be a light to medium bodied brew and leaves a dry , but sticky feel to the lips .

version , and it emitted a loud and powerful `` snap '' when i opened it ; as expected , it erupted into a fabulous , large-bubbled tan head . i was surprised , though , that there was no hint of bananas when i pushed past the head and drank the actual beer . it 's the beer version of a broad-shouldered red zinfandel wine , or one of those filling-rattling cabernet sauvignons .  a little thin .

canned on 10/26/2011 a : pours a deep , clear ruby color with a finger of thick light tan colored head .  i always drink my high life out of cans ! it looks like beer , smells like beer , and tastes like beer ... to keep it simple . this is my go-to macro , and will always be as long as miller keeps it the same ! prost !

the aromas amazing . its like smelling a glass full of fresh fruit . theres a little belgian malt in the aroma as well , but the fruity character of the beer is the most amazing quality of the beer . the yeast flavor is intense , and a little distracting , though .  mf- raw resinous and sticky , becoming oily , medium carbonation , slightly astringent , dry and grainy in the finish d- well rounded ipa , but not the best around .

s awesome whiff of freshly brewed coffee and oats . bits of chocolate are also pleasing on the nose , as this is very simple but rather enjoyable . burnt roasts add to this smooth and creamy mixture of scents .  m : medium body but the finish is not as crisp nor as clean as it could be .

this beer was poured a very dark rich chocolate brown with a thin tan head . with this beer being pushed nitrogen , it had a ton of lacing and the head lasted the entire beer .  m- average medium bodied beer o- great take on a saison style beer .
lacing is phenomenal , it sticks around the whole time , leaving great looking webbing on the glass .  the flavor is a bit harsh and a bit watery , but not too much .

smell is amazing ! nice and sweet and very hoppy . very appealing and aromatic . a very good blonde .  mouthfeel & drinkability : lighter bodied and less bitter than most other ipas , which makes for quite easy drinking .

the body is a nice burnt gold color and is slightly hazy , but the carbonation is clearly visible . its topped off with a nice thick white head , and is very bubbly and frothy but doesnt last long : there is some mild lacing too .  m - a little harsh , not as smooth as other ipas .

it poured black as a tuxedo in a dark closet . it came topped with a dense , dark-brown head that had a lot of staying power .  poured from bottle to tulip glass a : brilliantly clear pale yellow color with huge 3+ finger head that fades very slowly n : nose of a light belgian type wit with some light malts , touch of spices , toasted quality , touch of yeast t : starts with more malts and toasted quality , pretty light otherwise , a touch of light fruits and banana , slight earthy marzen quality , no spices m : very light and somewhat watery f : finishes dry and very crisp with a fading earthy marzen taste , would make a good session beer final thoughts : its a very light tasting oktoberfest/marzen .
pours with a fluffy , light tan head that sticks over a deep , hazy , amber brown body . great lace .  mouthfeel is a bit thin , but thats a minor complaint .

color was a dark brown with amber highlights .  the rye is evident , as is a tangy almost sour note along with the bread . a little over-carbonated ... i found it slightly distracting and that it may have affected my enjoyment of the beer 's complexity . light-bodied and very refreshing . while i have little to no experience with beers of this style , i enjoyed this one and i believe that its a great refresher during the summer months .

this beer pours a clear orange with a white , foamy head and smells hoppy and briney with hints of concord grape . personally , i find this beer to be too hoppy ... it would have been very nice without that second , stronger wave of hops .  mouthfeel is poor due to the overdone carbonation .

beautiful box package , dated 2004 , opens to reveal a classy looking bottle , numbered 85352 . this pours into a tukip a dark amber/light brown , with a thin head .  medium bodied with carbonation that was a little too high and too coarse for my liking , but it did n't turn me off completely . my only issue was the carbonation .

poured into a duvel tulip , between the brilliant dark amber body and the tight , creamy head it fills the glass . simply beautiful - my wife heard me say something to that effect , took a look and said `` wow ! that 's pretty !  m - surprisingly , its a bit thin and lacks carbonation .
it is as black as pitch . a nice , pillowy thick 2 finger head formed and stayed for the whole beer .  medium bodied fairly low carbonation .
this beer looks really , really nice .  light bodied for what i was expecting , but then it does n't claim to be a porter or stout .

pours into my new belgium globe with very dark brown body that looks almost black in the glass . thick creamy tan head tops the beer and looks stable enough to stick around for the duration .  mouthfeel : a little watery , but not terrible .

pours a slightly hazy , deep copper with a 3-finger thick , frothy light yellow head . lots of lacing .  m : lighter than it should be and very creamy and smooth , decent carbonation . f : long creamy chocolate vanilla smoothness .
this beer is so dark that it makes the glass appear as if it 's jet black . it 's beautiful . no head , no carbonation , just black .  heavy hops , but not totally unbalanced . very quenching .

smell - pumpkin , nutmeg , cinnamon , malts , brown sugar , spices . smells like liquid pumpkin pie . rather smooth and easy drinking .  my first tripel style beer , i spit it on my counter . the flavors of fruit combined with a bitter aftertaste left one bottle down the drain , and three still sitting in their case . anyone near me is welcome to the other three . while i am confident in the quality of this product , this style is definitely not for me .
beer is a slightly hazed mid-orange . very generous , sudsy white head is slow to go and leaves thick lacing .  the body is medium with decent carbonation .
extremely full smell , very good . t : sweet dark fruits up front then a booze laced chocolate and toffee .  spritely carbonated and fairly aqueous . very good but i would like a little more body .

seeing the mixed reviews of this beer , i was almost hesitent to buyit , but alas i did.poured into a tulip glass a clear bronze with a fluffy one finger white head that never really fades completely.hmm the hop aromas are a bit different , there is a resinous quality , but like a few others have stated there is a `` meaty '' quality to it wich is odd , also i pick up some leather wich i normally wouldnt find in a dipa.wow the flavors are very odd , the summit hop gives off an odd flavor , its got ta green leafiness to it and a weird kind of fruitiness as well , its a bit prickly and not fun to drink really.hmm this is different in a not so good kinda way .  actually thought it might be bad but when i drank it there was plenty of carbonation . smell : a toasted malty smell with an almost cardboard smell . taste : very strong toasted smell but more of a bitterness then a sweetness . note : no date on the bottle but wondering if this beer had gone bad . will try another attempt at it but not really looking forward to it .

delightful aroma but blindfolded you would never identify this as a strong dark . regardless , very nice . salvation rr reasserts itself in the taste .  mouthfeel : light/ medium body with excessive carbonation that somewhat hinders the flavor .

pours jet black with 3 fingers of brownish , mocha head that just screams ice cream float . tons of sticky lacing & very good head retention s : roasty malt , rich , dark & fruitty with woody hops , & booze once warm t : roasty malt , dark choclate , herbal hops along with molasses , leafy & minty hops up front .  the body is thin and slightly anemic . a little more carbonation and body would carry this really unique beer into the stratosphere .

appearance : pale caramel color with an amber tint . smaller off-white head never fully dissipates and leaves behind thick foamy lace as you drink it .  mouth- thin ? it 's a little thin , it lacks depth , and too much raisin for my taste .
perfect lacing . very good retention .  very low carbonation , strong , hoppy with lingering after taste , a very typical english bitter but not my cup of tea .

brown 33cl bottle with an artsy looking label . pours a peach orange-honey -very murky with a big 1inch + cap and holds very well down to 1 finger after a few minutes . very fluffy and fresh-looking lace which leaves thick puffs on glass . the head holds so well it is similar to egg-whites with very soft peaks .  lightly bodied , perhaps overly so , with a passably dextrinous mouthfeel .

poured into a fluted tulip glass , lots of sticky foam on the glowing orange body .  the mouthfeel is the only thing i think could be improved here and it very well may just be that i am having it from a growler .
first off , this is easily the coolest looking beer can ever . awesome retention and lacing .  the palate is somewhat thin for the style but it 's still smooth .

golden yellow with a full white head that melts to a quarter inch covering of sticky lacing .  mouthfeel was not particularly big , enough that you knew you were drinking something real but not a facefull .

pours out a thickly hazed golden-orange . gigantic , solid off-white head . consistancy and appearance of cotton candy . great looking , but lacking elsewhere .  the mouthfeel was about what i expected going in , but i thought it might a little over-carbonated . the aggressiveness of the carbonation was a little distracting .

an ending swirl murks up the brew nicely . massive thick and rich eggshell ice-cream topping floating on top .  it was bland and the stout portion was overpowering . yet , for reason 's i do n't understand , the people i know from philadelphia all seem to love this beer .

appearance : pours the color of a tripel ; that burnt golden orange appearance . head is gigantic and rocky which dissipates slowly into a thick rocky soapy lacing that clings to the glass tenaciously and refuses to let go . it even have yeast in the bottle which i found out on the last pour of my bomber . so really proper looking for an imperial ipa and the color of a tripel . i 'm giving this a 5 ! its a beautiful beer smell : this a very hoppy beer .  m : thin , but with a bit of sparkle .

s ) pumpkin pie ... this really has it covered . this is spiced , but not over the top , which made me very happy . a very nice balance of pumpkin and beer . this is quite smooth . nice finish and aftertaste . o ) i have n't really had many pumpkin beers , but i 've heard good things about this one , so i finally gave it a shot . i 'm really glad i did .  body is fairly thin , but that is expected for the modest abv .

pours to a brilliantly clear pale golden , forming a tall soapy `` pure as the blown snow '' white , with excellent retention and lacing . great looking brew .  wow this has to be one of the worst ideas in beer history . trying to cross a pale ale with a belgian and what you got is something that is a distant cousin to both . instead of leveraging the style 's strengths this beer doubles down on their worst attributes . a very hoppy tatse that fights like a strong ale . not a fun beer and a true shame that it might discredit weyerbacher 's other great beers .

pretty clear with a slight haze from the chill copper colored brew . very sizeable and fluffy cream colored head sticks all over .  flavour is better than expected- a little woody and slightly spicy , with a thick strong maltiness . i 'd like the hearty body on this one , were it not for the turbocharged carbonation .
smell- by far the sweetest smelling beer i 've ever had .  feel is thin bodied overall , but well bodied for the style .

appearance - as billed , this pours totally black and opaque . a big dark mocha cloud on top resembles the thick top of a chocolate cappuccino or something . thick , creamy , lucious .  taste is weak but odd at the same time with a mild rice-sweetness . this is the kind of beer you can share with your friends because most do n't appreciate the imports anyway . i drank plenty of this is my younger days ... when you look up headache in the dictionary it reads `` drink 12 budweisers and take a nap .

devastatingly attractive . dried herb in color . brilliant nose . obviously aged and incredibly smooth on the palate but the cellaring destroyed the hop presense .  the mouthfeel is light carbonation , somewhat on the watery side , but very drinkable .

the head of foam was nothing short of exceptional . it had a 1 1/2 inch creamy head of tan colored foam that looked good enough to eat .  i have had ipas that went down a bit smoother but this one is n't bad it still goes down good but with just a little more carbonation and bite .

appearance = ridiculous amount of head - like 5 to 6 inches of thick milky white froth and foam . looks pretty darn good ; i just need this one to settle .  the mouthfeel however is slightly taut . body is clear red copper with sustained carbonation .

a : a medium amber color with a very robust creamy white head . it has a very creamy and milky head . lacing is incredible . s : it smells of citrus ( orange or grapefruit ) with floral notes .  as with several anchor offerings , i feel the carbonation is a bit overdone , but is n't powerful enough to be overly distracting .
bottle courtesy of plucier : poured extremely cloudy whitish/yellow color ale with a nice small pure white foamy head with good retention .  very carbonated feel on the tongue .

glass : chimay goblet temp : cellared @ approx 45 degrees bottling date : 04-23-08 pours an exceptional clear golden amber color . minimal head that retains a light lacing all the way down .  m - a little thin for my liking . the body is quite thin , almost watery .

big ripe banana aroma that is quite pleasing . malts can be noted as well .  the feel is the only drawback here . it was rather light in body , and thin feeling . carbonation was adequate , but it just lacked that `` near medium '' that i would expect from a dipa .

a deep mahogany appearance with thick lacing on the sides gave this a beautiful appearance . i emailed the location and i guess what makes it unique is its cross between a red ale and a stout .  ) i would like a little more bready/chewiness as the mouthful feels a tad more thin than what i 'd prefer for this style .

s : the smell is quite amazing and complex in my opinion . there are some light hops initially noticed . overall , it is very pleasant . t : after the very satisfying smell , the taste was sort of a let down .  the mouthfeel , i was not so impressed with .

pours a very appealing ruby red with a tan-ish 2 inch head that leaves some of the best lacing i 've ever seen .  mouthfeel if very alive and crisp at first sip . maybe a bit overpowering on the carbonation .
12oz bottle into a tulip glass - from the latest release a : pitch black pour with 2 fingers of fairly dark brown head . beautiful beer .  m : average , nothing of note .
s - good smell , lots going on .  the largest macro beer in the country is very disappointing . the feel of this beer is somewhat thin but i liked the bock feel that it had .

i love the look of this in the glass , nice pale yellow color , frothy white head . it looks like it was dry hopped to me .  the beer feels light but not watery . there is a little prickle on the tongue at the swallow .
in the original struise glass it looks really great .  somewhat smooth feel , moderate-medium body for amber , but still feels a little thin .

very complex . thin to medium body with tastes of malted cereal , light residual sugar followed by roasted and hoppy bitterness . i am still amazed by the complexity of smells in this brew .  m : crisp feel at first , mellows gradually before eventually becoming a little sticky/gummy . light-medium body .

p : crystal clear yellow-orange pour with an intense white foam that came almost over the top of the sam adams glass . foam slowly lowered with huge globs of lacing and a very thick cover .  mouthfeel is a little lacking ; like i said , this bottle had very little to no carbonation , so i might need to try again . overall , though , a very tasty sweet high abv winter seasonal that i wo n't mind drinking again to `` research the carbonation .
a absolutely beautiful looking beer .  the mouthfeel was lowly carbonated .

a - tons of carbonation streams up from the nucleation point to a puffy off-white head of almost three-fingers . good retention and clumpy lace above a totally clear golden yellow beer .  mouthfeel : medium body and a finish that is a bit dry . this beer almost flat .

this notes of grapefruit and pineapple . just thick hop notes here so ripe and fresh it was like heaven just smelling this . smooth and mellow delivery of the flavor , though not as strong as the aroma would have led me to believe . light alcohol notes as well and a really good medium feel to it . something i would love to try again as the aroma itself was worth the price . this was damn nice  m - the reason i dinged it on mouthfeel is because it actually left some of that nasty coffee-mouth feeling in my gullet .

this beer looks so beautiful on nitro with a creamy long lasting head and glass coating appeal .  lighter body than i thought it would be with with very low carbonation..the weakest point of the brew . easy drinker for the abv and ignoring the mouth feel , a nice brew .
head is big , tall , pillowy , and tanned oak in colour . decent retention . nice , delicate , thin strings of lacing .  the mouthfeel is light with a decent amount of carbonation .

color is a lovely deep honey-brown with a nice thick fine-bubbled head .  brownish gold beer straight out of a 40 ounce bottle . sugary sweet flavors of corn and grain . it 's not something i 'll buy very often . milwaukee 's best 40s are cheaper and taste better , even if they do n't have that signature bottle shape .
this beer is absolutely stunning , sharp ruby red . it 's a really great looking winter brew .  it is astringent and medicicnal .

the initial pour formed a small head of small dark brown bubbles . as the head died , it left a clinging vine lacing stubbornly letting go of the side of the glass .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied to me . could be a little thicker on the tongue .
a : there is not too much better than a nitro'ed beer to look at . thick , rich creamy white head with tons of lacing .  m - a little on the thin side .
overall pretty good .  nice floral hops and malt starchiness in the finish . it 's a drinkable beer . heavy in the stomach .

( s ) - a very fruity aroma with fresh orange peel and lemon . a very vibrant fruit driven profile with hints of a hay/wheat dryness .  the only complaint i have is that the texture left much to be offered . overall i great beer .

a - dark honey color but very clear .  the taste was very light and highly carbonated . overall i 'm really surprised at all the negative reviews of this beer . maybe it 's just the fact i had it on tap , or that it was fresh .

had this at a recent ba gathering at milly 's , and brought a growler home . this is a beautiful beer : as black as can be , with a thick coffee-colored head .  mouthfeel is decent , this beer seems to foam up in your mouth .

s blackberries . light , hammy smoke . the fruit character is subtle and dry . gentle coffee note .  the beer seems to thin a bit in the mouthfeel . very clean beer for a triple , slightly thin in the mouthfeel , but that helps give this beer a nice clean dry finish .

pours a very nice chestnut brown with a quite good head that sticks around as a cap throughout . very good lacing as well .  the middle is kind of hoppy , but somewhat thin . the finish is dry and quite hoppy . a decent light beer .

12oz brown bottle . frothy and creamy off white 1 '' head that holds for a while , eventually leading to some nice layers of lacing . very deep mahogany color with a shade of brown .  t - again , bicuit and nut . nice and malty , virtually no hop bite , but tasty none the less . d - i have had this a ton in the past , but i only just got around to getting another one for the purposes of reviewing .

a little unusual too . overall , a unique and very enjoyable iipa .  a- blackness with a espresso colored head s- coffee beans ground soaked in licorice coffee and dark chocolate really bold t- straight up coffee and espresso with bitter chocolate and a slight tang finish m- medium carbonation and a bit watery for the style d- i drink 3 cup of coffee a day who am i to judge ?

s : very complex and aromatic , dark fruits , like figs and raisins , some dark sugar is there as well , with a bit of port wine and grapes . t : taste is of a medicinal , dark fruity brew . very complex , though the flavour did n't really come through until the beer was at about 60 degrees , so serve this one a little warmer than usual .  body is perhaps the one less thanexcellent area , as its a little too light and i would have preferred something heavier and slicker ( more like the maui offering ) .

s : a typical fff piney , citrus hop parade hits you strong up front , with delicious burnt cocoa , cinnamon , and brown sugar following . an epic nose that promises much . t : unfortunately , the nose can not keep it 's promise . there is still some malt left underneath , but it is just not coming through like it does in the nose . as a huge fan of toasty porters and stouts , it ; 's kind of a let down for me .  it may not be for everyone but i think this is a beautiful product . flavor is far less sweet than the smell and look might hint , in fact this is gobs of sour black cherry . it 's an instant classic and one of only a handful of lambics i 've liked so far .

enjoyed from snifters and beer a gift from the brewer himself ... ap : deep dark body , roasted brown head , awesome retention .  the mouth is a tiny bit like flat soda which was the only off-putting part of this beer .
a very good looking porter .  mouthfeel : the body is oddly thin , and crisp .

this beer looks great in my mug with a great black body and a thick coffe colored head .  mouth feel was pretty average , smooth , not very complex so i expected a little more from it in that department .
nice hop aroma right off the bat . very piney and resiney .  m : the thinnest , lightest imperial i can remember , but the intensity doesnt have to be overpowering .
absolutely fantastic aroma . t & m : sweet chocolate , citrus hops , and toasted black malt all make their appearance .  more watery flavored than i expected from this ... very light mouthfeel .

a - pours very dark red , foams high but dissipates quickly . has a very nice cream/coke fizz coloured head and a great ruby red hue in light . very attractive beer .  this is very malty at the opening with a twinge of caramel . upon downing it , the taste resembles a very dark beer . very malty with heavy caramel presence that makes it a bit sweet . it also gives a bitter character that mellows into a sweetened deal . i 'll have to try it from the mug in the near future . it may turn out differently due to more carbonization released , making it less bitter , dare i venture to say . but , straight from the bottle , it is easier to imbibe if you 're used to dark , bitter ales .

pours a brilliant colour , reddish , orange , very clear , just amazing , thick white head , lots of lace , great retention , head never leaves , i have to give this a 5 for appearance , simply one of the best looking beers i 've ever seen .  taste was pretty balanced with a bit of malt sweetness . overall i liked this one . this is the first beer i have tried from boulder . based on this one , i 'll have to try some of the others that we can get in ct . the website says that a secret spice is added , but i can not really taste any spice . maybe i 'll figure it out by the time i finish the six . good brew .
beautiful fucking color .  m : slick mouthfeel with a medium amount of carbonation that can be prickly at times . body is medium and has a bit of resiny stickiness to it .
very nice . i was frightened from all the soy sauce talk , but the aroma really sucked me in and eased my fear .  it feels very thin in the mouth , close to water .

a giant , rocky , off-white head explodes out of the bottle , leaving strata-like rings on the glass as it settles , which is a good amount of time .  it has little to no head on it with a soft pour . this beer has a good balance of spices that is not overpowering . the aftertaste is mellow . this is one of the darker ales that i have drank but all in all i would give it another try . especially on a snowy winter day .

appearance : cloudy golden yellow with an amazing , big , billowy head that last all the way through the beer , incredible lacing too which sticks all over the glass . the best looking tripel i 've ever seen .  like chocolate carbonated corn syrup . body is light and watery ... good carbonation level helps it feel thicker than it is and hints at being creamy .
an alcoholic praline . profound amber hues and sticky fingers of lace .  the body was only medium , this was not unexpected as it is an ipa style , but i though it could have done with a bit extra .
overall , not as good as smell . alcohol well hidden .  the mouthfeel is medium , slightly watery .

hazy golden orange and white fluffy head with great retention and nice lacing .  incredibly light with cereal grains , very grainy taste , hops are nowhere in site . there are way better summer beers out there .
'' pours almost black with a generous amber head and fruity , hop-spicy nose .  m : a touch thin .
pours dark mahogany with a thick tan head .  md-light body and sharp moderate carbonation . foamed pretty good going down the drain .

pours a thick black color with a medium beige head .  ) it has very low carbonation witch makes the mouthfell very average with about that of a tap bud lite , only a little tingle from the carbonation .
pours an absolute , dense black with a healthy sized brown head .  the mouthfeel is just a touch too syrupy , though it does n't detract much at all from the enjoyment of the beer .
