smell : complex nose boasts belgian yeast with a sweet apricot note and some underlying white pepper spice . complexities abound . taste : a well balanced tripel with a nice peppery spice and undistinguishable fruit presence . overall : solid , solid tripel . very fine beer .  smell was sweet , with a citrus hint and strong english ale smell . initial taste was interesting , and i was n't sure about whether i would like it . by the end of the bottle , it had become one of the best beers i 've tasted . i would n't recommend it for any parties , but in small groups of like minded people i would say good call . very drinkable beer . looking forward to trying more from the brewery ( if i can find it )

this is a fairly average offering in liquor stores round the calgary area , but it is one i can never pass up : this is a very flavourful beer by any means , though it is the most mass-produced of the scotch ales . i love the hue of amber/red glow to this beer . the colour itself is almost appetising . the aroma is my favourite part of the beer . sweet candy , or blueberry gum , rich sweet malt that evokes red licorice , candy cane , sweet bread , sourdough , and other sweet confectionaries . the taste is not as full as the aroma . this is a sweet offering from the time it hits your tongue to the time it leaves your breath : up front there are cherries and irish-red tastes . the hops are there , adding a touch of balance and grass to the finish . the mouthfeel is well carbonated , full , and heavy .  taste is dominating by anis with some candi sugar . body was above average and alcohol was well hidden .

pours from the bottle to a reddish orange with medium off-white head that lingers , and excellent lacing .  the beer is somewhat oxidized , but still highly drinkable very light bodied bitter , true to the the style . this is a prime candidate for a session beer . at 3.8 % abv , it 's alcohol content makes this a clear choice for something that could literally be consumed all day long , starting with your pancakes !

the head is fluffy , off-white , and responsible , in part , for the best characteristic of this brew : the nose . the nose is a wonderful mix of allspice , nutmeg , and a bit of cinnamon , laid over a warm , inviting sweetness . it 's like sniffing a particularly delicious cookie . this brew goes down quite smoothly , and does not seem as high in alcohol as i thought it would .  nothing special here .

this beer pours a slightly cloudy golden orange color , with a thick , fluffy light yellow head . the head fades very slowly , leaving a thick cutrain of lace .  medium-bodied , maybe just a little bit thin .
honestly , a fantastic looking beer .  mouthful : somewhat over-carbonated but generally decent mouthfeel .

i also love the brownish patina imparted to the deep red colour as it sits in a chalice .  drinks a little heavy because of all the sediment but feels watery and thin on the palate . adequate carbonation but not incredible lively .
the appearance was a perfect deep color with a incredible head .  boosting the carbonation would help .
smell was strong with bananas , sweet , bready malts . an interesting beer , and one that 's good as a crossover beer .  very light bodied , but carbonation seems too low to me .
once cracked it pours a deep , impenetrable black with a thick , high , pillowy light tan head that leaves intricate webs of lacing .  m - a little thin , sickly-sweet finish .
smells really good .  mouthfeel : pretty heavy for a porter but very drinkable even in the heat .
smell : sweetened chocolate , floral notes .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin , spicy , moderately dry , and has a distinct saison flavor in the aftertaste .
a nice two fingered head forms quickly and had great retention .  smooth and to the point , bit of a sweet aftertaste in the sweet sticky beer way .
s : there are very strong aromas of coffee beans and roasted malts in the nose .  mouthfeel - a little gritty , though a light body to it .

appearance very cool bottle art . beer is a deep rich mahogany brown .  mouthfeel : a little slick , thinner on the palate than i expected drinkability : a fine porter , would definitely drink again .

a . great appearance . 3+ fingers of super dense head . excellent retention . great appearance , lackluster smell , very interesting taste , good mouthfeel , drinkability good and overall uniqueness good .  m : medium to light bodied . feels a touch watery .

s- super hoppy and sweet with a mixture of predominant pine flavor and underlying grapefruit notes ... absolutely exquisite . t- taste is very reminiscent of pliny the elder but possibly better balanced .  mouthfeel : medium body , a bit chalky , tingly carbonation and a dry finish .

smell is downright incredible , with lots of oily hops , citrus , and a complexity i ca n't describe .  m - medium body , with moderate to high carbonation . a bit too carbonated for my liking . slightly thin , would like a bigger body from a stout . the mouthfeel is lacking , and sweet flavors of vanilla and chocolate make it too much like a dessert beer , one is all you need .

) extremely unique . outstanding ! t - sweet sugary honey and vanilla flavors up front , followed by strong herbal flavors , mint , anise , and a bit of tangy hop . m - medium bodied and slick , with a course , gritty , dry finish .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and resinous , this is really the only fault i can find .
copper color with two fingers of creamy offwhite head that really stands up . leaves nice lacing .  for the mouthfeel , i found this stout almost watery in consistency .

just unbelievable . on the palate the beer is very good , but does n't blow my socks off . very nice beer from stone brewing .  m : full bodied and creamy , the slightest touch of carbonation and a smooth , somewhat watery finish .

smell - i thought the nose on this beer was the best part . malt with grassiness . fresh smelling , almost floral . taste - wow ! that 's one bold and bitter finish !  do not know if this was an aberation , but this caused a lower score in mouthfeel .

appearance- pours a slightly hazy pale gold into my glass , a rough pour results in four full fingers of well constructed bubbles . after about 8 minutes , the head settles leaving behind webs of sticky lacing and a creamy , whipped topping . it 's messy and uneven , and leaves a burning bitterness that even i find unpleasurable .  i 've always liked this beer , and if they beefed up the abv and gave it a little more body , it would be the perfect porter . why grant 's beers share these characteristics i do n't know , but if they ever did beef 'em up a little , they could truly be a contender .

a : looking very decent and nice -- light amber hue , with a tight , foamy white beer head with extremely good retention and looking very fizzy ... s : light floral hop aroma arrives upfront , plus a flow of semi-sweet grainy flavour at the back -- the aroma reminds me of some belgian amber ale ?  mouthfeel is rather thin and average .

appearance : slightly hazy , ruby-amber pour with a voluminous ( and tenacious ) , light-tan whipped-cream head . recedes to floating dollops ... lace everywhere !  seems a bit thin , with very soft carbonation .

s : bold and healthy hop aroma . perfect ipa smell . t : dry and hoppy .  m : thinner than i expected , pretty fair amount of carbonation , once again a little more reminiscent of a porter than a stout .
the beer pours out a very dark brown that is almost opaque expect for the edges .  body is a little thin .

reviewed 1/12/2010 ( bottle ) : pours a dark reddish brown color body , big fluffy head , off-white , lasting .  it was pretty smooth for stout and for for the alcohol content . i tried it with a few other beers .

a - beautiful hazy orange , loads of carbonation , four fingers of fluffy head with good retention . very little lacing .  trying to think of a sweet red wine , not one i can place , but its defintely tannic , bitter and sweet ... the taste is super interesting , not say its good , but interesting . chocolate wine comes to mine , light feel though . what i do know is that 8 months is too long as it totally changes the beer into something new losing almost all stout character .

very little head to speak of , thin collar of dense white bubbles s : deep notes of dark chocolate , carob , molasses , and a hint of coffee . the flavors are very mellow but well integrated . t : the taste does n't translate into being as good as the smell suggested , the smooth chocolate is there , but turns into a slightly sharp flavor by mid palate and has a slightly metallic finish .  its a bit thicker on the palate than american crap beer , but it 's your basic `` serve cold , swill it down , catch a buzz '' beer for the masses .

the head is a huge and fluffy 3 fingers high cloud puff with great retention and excellent lace .  again , dried dark fruit seems to be the dominating taste , and as it warms , a sweet cherry-like flavor comes in m : at first i found this beer a bit too prickly and highly carbonated for my liking ; i purposely agitated the beer by swirling and enjoyed it a bit more when carbonation was less severe great beer that i would drink anytime i needed a belgian fix .

even with a careful poor i ended up with a huge , tan rocky head . this beer looks a whole lot better than it tastes with a bit cloudy , dark ruddy brown color , and that big aforementioned head .  m - a little thin-bodied and watery and a little low on the carbonation .

this thing pours up a crystal clear copper with big rocky white head that leaves behind some of the prettiest lace i have seen in a while . great head retention and beautiful rising bubbles in this incredibly clear beer just make this look positively stunning .  m - the hops lingered a bit too long and had a metallic feel at times .
s-this beer has a nice sweet flower aroma with hints of roses and apricots .  mouthfeel is a little too tingly for me with the carbonation .

the beer pours a dark amber with an impressive frothy head . the retention is excellent and lacing is glass coating .  it was an average imperial stout with a thin mouthfeel made exciting with some fruit .
the smell dances on the nose , full of floral and hops .  a bit thin , but a very good stout flavor develops in the mouth . i 'd have preferred a bit fuller body .

pours with a short , brown head with melted caramel edges . really nice lacing .  m - fairly zesty and zingy carbonation that left me feeling a touch bloated after a third of a glass . medium-light body that also has a bit of grain character .
pours a beautiful color , have to admit . deep gold/cherry in color -- like a cognac .  the mouthfeel is a little lacking in carbonation too .

seems very complex , i love it . t : disappointed from the smell .  like drinking sour grass , probably the best way to put it m - low carbonation , slightly astringent d - not very drinakble , i had to leave a third of it

nice downward bubbles on pour ... dark brown to black with a slight ruby edge , a tan creamy nitro head , and lace like wallpaper .  mouthfeel is not too bad , sharpness coming more from the carbonation than hops .

this smells amazing . like perfumed hop elephants . but damn ... this smells amazing . i could inhale this all day . which sounds odd .  out of all of the blueberry beers i have had i would have to say this is probably my favorite . very fruity with a somewhat dry finish to it . the blueberries are definitely the star of the show . overall this is a very drinkable beer and makes a great summer brew .
very impressive lager appearance .  mouthfeel was medium with a bite in front and back and made the roof of my mouth tickle ( odd ) .

excellent . t- sharp hop bitterness with a floral blanket overall . slightly sticky d- smooth , smells great and tasts great .  i can feel it in my cheeks . it does n't have any off aromas specifically , but it definitely has the acidity for it . undrinkable , i 'm pouring it out .

the aroma is just amazing . it is easily the best smelling ipa i 've had in my young beer tasting career .  m : carbonation is a little weak ( especially since i poured moderately , and received an aggressive head ) leaving a mouthfeel thatis not strong enough for me to consider it cask-like . a little watery ... d : all things considered , i really enjoyed this beer .
appearance is beatiful dark dark black with a fluffy , pale yellow head that laces nicely .  the mouthfeel is larger light with a very , very slight fizz .

this pours out the same deep orange color as the last one with the same solid fluffy head , lacing , etc . as appearance goes , there is nothing left to improve upon .  the mouthfeel was medium bodied with adequate carbonation .
huge , foamy beige head that leaves several lace rings smeared down the glass . kinda like the glass is wearing a striped shirt .  it goes down smooth .

poured into a standard snifter at about 55 degrees f , 1-inch head , light lacing , deep beautiful cloudy magenta .  best as it warmed , when the malt flavors of chocolale and toffee become a bit more complex and the mouthfeel seems fuller .
one beautiful looking barleywine here . it almost glows a nice dark amber color .  the only fault is that its a little thin bodied but that 's what makes this brew dangerous .

the smell is amazing . it gets me first on the sides of my tongue .  this beer poured nicely with a creamy white head , giving off nice citrus aromas . the flavor was shocking , however , reminding me of kool-aid orange flavor , and with almost as much sweetness . i could n't distinguish any hop bitterness , though it could have used some to balance out the excessive sweetness . this beer tastes as though all the yeast were filtered out , and then orange kool-aid added post-fermentation
amazingly slow head cascade action . clear from yeast or other floaties .  m - moderate carbonation , medium bodied .
a decent amount of brown head . the pour looks excellent .  the mouthfeel was medium with a syrupy sweetness on the palate .

bottle : poured an orangey color ale with a huge off-white head with perfect retention .  medium bodied , it seems a little flat at the beginning , but there 's sharp carbonation at the finish , which is a little watery and silty .
the smell of it was great . the taste was not as impressive , but i did enjoy the chewyness .  mouthfeel is pretty typical , and if anything is a little undercarbonated or slick .

looks beautiful in the glass , with rich crystalline red color and a nice head .  the expected lactose or creaminess is absent in the flavor as well as the mouth feel given that this is a milk stout . the carbonation , again , is more soda-like in the mouth instead of frothy or creamy . the drinkability and mouthfeel improved with time as the intensely carbonated head withered away .
pours an almost transparent golden/light copper with an amazingly fluffy 3 finger head from an extremely gentle pour .  the mouthfeel is a bit too light for my liking .
could n't get too aggressive with the pour b/c it has some major head on it . nice gold , perfect clarity , big puffy white head .  pretty average mouthfeel overall .

bear republic big bear black stout is an impenetrably black ale with a huge , chunky , foamy , light-chestnut colored head that coats the glass .  the body was light and there was not enough carbonation .

i love nitrous beers - they have this amazing waterfall effect as the head settles . the beer 's head was a nice creamy tan color and featured some light coffee/mocha scents . appearance - 5.0/5.0 - love the waterfall effect of the nitrous , tan creamy head - very full taste - 4.5/5.0 - silky smooth - coffee and light chocolate taste feel - 4.0/5.0 - no aftertaste , extremely smooth in mouth smell - 4.0/5.0 - very light with coffee/mocha accents drinkability - 4.5/5.0 - way better than a guiness - very tasty , smooth - i will be repeating this beer .  long , super bitter piney bitterness , aftertaste almost of pine-sol but i love the hop attack . problem is that it 's too sweet and slightly syrupy , especially evident in the middle . a little harsh and unbalanced overall , big beer and it shows .

s - very nice . sweet . i like it a lot . very different than most beers of this style .  in the glass , the elderberry dominates . the taste just off , sour in a nasty way , more like rotten fruit than any sort of pleasant tartness which might be expected from the berries . we gave this a decent try to see if it would get better , but in the end just could n't drink it .
11.2 oz , 2007 bottle a : deep brown , not quite black under a nice sized tan head . excellent lace and retention .  mouthfeel - a bit too carbonated which overrides the wonderful taste at first .

the beer poured beautifully into the glass : a bronze-brownish coloured pint with a thick off white head . the main thing i noticed throughout the duration of the pint was the excellent retention and lacing that the head left .  4.5/5 m : crisp , medium body .

this poured out wonderfully with a growing tall head of very tight frothyness of light tannish color sitting atop a glowing deep mahagony , rubyish copper highlighted gem of a bottom .  picked up a few of these `` oil cans '' at a local liquor mart . this is the only place i 've seen them . i like the regular fosters occasionally , and have fond memories of it from various parties and times in life . after looking at the color , noticed that the can said `` caramel coloring added , '' so nothing real to go by there . i liked this , i guess , but the drinkablility was hampered by a fakey sort of bitterness that did n't hold a candle to the fuller 's and young 's of the world . kind of caught in my throat . i pick up the regular if it 's on special , but for a real bitter , this ai n't it .

a - it 's impossible to score higher , beautiful beer ... thick fluffy white head that resembles the frothed milk of a latte , dark gold to light copper , carbonation rains towards the head ... such a beautiful looking beer .  m - lots of carbonation maybe bordering on too much .

served at a few degrees below fridge tempeature in a tulip glass . the color is a gleaming orange , and the lacing is setting up with unbelievable sticky cling . superb ! smell- a bold metallic smell booms out from the glass , incredibly phenolic and overpowering the malts and hops .  mouthfeel : medium and semi-smooth . bottom line : this is one of the most bland beers i 've ever had .

a - black as thick midnight hanging over a field , with subtle touches of chocoalte milk . lacing levels out nicely in turn . from now on , i 'll head straight to those black 6 packs with their odd violet label anytime i feel like a remarkably solid showing , probably .  the palate is thinner than expected but not bad .

a-black , a lot of tan head s-dark roasted malts and a lot of sweet creamy chocolate , there 's hint of caramel as well t-hits with a very light hint of roasted malts and chocolate but they come in quite strong within the after-taste .  s- smoky wood and scotch , one of the more interesting noses on this beer t- malts , with some nice roasted flavors that come through and then a hit of alcohol m- lighter bodied than expected d- a very interesting and drinkable beer , but one i need to be in the mood for

i 've always put off reviewing this thinking perhaps i 'm not getting it at it 's freshest , but it is perpetually average so here we go ... start with the positive.. good looking beer .  an amazing brew . medium strength carbonation with a wonderful complex flavor of hops barley and corn . somewhat similar to pbr , but upper canada has an after taste that pbt ca n't compare with . usually i do n't care for beers to have much of an after taste , but with this brew it 's all good . i would recommend this beer to anyone who can get their hand on it .

v.07 very nice look - medium head that quickly finds resolve . light perpetual carbonation , with a beautiful deep bloody amber resin-esque look , much like a barleywine/olde ale .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation and is a bit watery .
absolutley perfect looking beer .  it was creamy with an average carbonation level and also average alcoholic strength ( 6.0 % abv ) . overall : awful .

s - lively lemon oil aroma , very fresh and unique . lots of spicy wheat and slightly fruity yeast . the aroma is spectacular , it smells like oil squeezed out of a fresh lemon peel , though the flavor is not quite as good .  mouthfeel is a bit too thin , especially in view of the heavenly head and ample lacing .
smell - pretty nice smelling . lots of blueberries as well as some malt .  mouthfeel is a bit thin for my liking .
wonderful looking ale .  sweet caramel and an herbal bitterness m- clean , but a bit watery with mediocre carbonation d- i do like to drink this beer every now and then .

very nice aroma . hmm , not sure about the taste .  m - not as thick as i 'd like it to taste considering how rich the smell is . d - very drinkable , with the lighter mouthfeel it 's easier to forget how much you 've had .

hazy light golden with a nice , moussy white head ; excellent head retention , and great lacing . perfect looks . no contest here .  the only downside of this beer was the mouthfeel , which was fairly flat and watery , probably due in part to the low % abv .
exceptional head and lace . big , rough , chunky , substantial lace . impressive to look at and earns full points on that count .  m : light to medium bodied and highly carbonated .
pours a beautiful golden color with thick , frothy guinness-like white head .  m. a little too sticky , it feels syrupy , but without a sweeter taste it fells a little off .

pours a clear copper color with a fresh citrus aroma , it seems a little like this beer wanted nothing more than to get that grapefruit hop aroma , it smells great , but the flavor is pretty bland , too simple i think .  very basic but very good m= average carbonation and average weight .
pours really black with a big , pillowy dark brown head .  m : finish stays around for quite a while , almost too long , really coats the mouth .
very light copper color mixed with soft tarnushed brass . good bubbling , great head and foam retention for all 16 ozs .  m : mouthfeel is a bit thin , considering how robust the initial flavor is .

the smell is really quite wonderful ; nearly perfect . the roast and sweetness are the perfect marriage of complimentary elements .  if you closed your eyes and smelled this you would think your smelling a good octoberfest beer due to the scent of carmalized malt and faint hops . has a carmel toasted nut flavor on the tounge and finished dry . i like the fact that this irish red is a little more bitter than most red ales but still not overpowering . tongiht i will be reviewing 4 of hook and ladder beers as i bought a gift pack that came with 3 bottles of 4 different beers . the beers i got were backdraft brown golden ale pipe and drum irish red ember amber ( a type of black and tan made with their backdraft brown ale and golden ale ) . try these beers if u can find them they are good
lots of aromas , raisins , plums , maple sugar candy .  definitely a little too carbonated for my taste - the mouthfeel was a little too creamy , masking the flavor .

s - strong tropical fruit aroma with hints of mango , lemon , and other citrus fruits . a slightly sweet smell from the malt is a welcome addition to the strong hop presence . d - the nose was much better than the taste .  smell is cocoa , touch of coffee , licorice , slight vanilla , a whiff of smoke . taste is thick creamy , dark and bakers chocolate , touch of espresso , end is dry and slightly bitter , a woody aftertaste .

the pour was very good and this is easily one of the best looking beers i have ever seen with its excelent head , color and champagne like bubbles .  m- the weakness of the beer - moderately light body feels a little weak to me . light carbonation does n't add much .

appearance : very dark brown with a thick , creamy , light tan head with excellent retention and fabulous rings of lacing . the cascade is a thing of beauty !  body was medium with med/high carbonation and a dry finish .
for me , this was one of the most appealing scents i 'd smelled in a long time .  mouthfeel : i 'm a bit disappointed by the mouthfeel .
pours a very nice amber , just the slightest bit of haze . nice thick , dense , head . excellent lacings .  mouthfeel , i would like it have been a bit more carbonated , but it did fine .

a nice dark red/amber color with about 1.5 finger head of off-white creamy head . the head stuck around for about 3/4 of the brew and left some nice lace .  magic hat usually disappoints me , not that their brews are n't good , it 's that some of them just are n't tasty- till now . magic hats roxy rolles is right up there with ithaca 's cascazilla and troegs hopback amber . a definite seasonal must have for me . great ! ! !

a- pours a good looking deep brown with a little light let in around the edges . a big 1.5 fingered mocha colored head leaves some good lacing on the side of the glass all the way down .  under carbonated .

the clarity on this beer is quite amazing has some very see through character to it . head falls slowly and head bubbles all seem to be a nice pin head size .  this one is a bit light and watery but does have a decent taste .
a beautiful looking beer that has a very appetizing aroma , but its flavor does n't meet expectations .  the mouthfeel is a bit overcarbonated for the stle but not bad .

appearance- deep brown-caramel colored pour . leaves wonderful lace streaks and patches . almost the entire glass was caked with lace after i was finished .  this is the least impressive quad from the trappist breweries ... do n't get me wrong , it has a similar taste profile , although not that perfect as a westy 12 or a rochefort 10 , dark fruit , plums , candy sugar , but i did n't like the mouthfeel on this one . too much sparkling going on ... pretty funny thing is i just absolutely endlessly adore the la trappe quadrupel oak aged batch 1 version ... so so so much better then the regular one , especially when the oak aged version , bottled this summer , is coming around fantastic ! i like their dubbel more too .

fantastic smell of sweet banana and a slight tart cloves .  it smells of rotten banana peels , rotten apples , and molding compost . the flavors are very sweet and kind of medicinal . it leaves a clove laiden aftertaste behind , making you think you just had an artificial banana milkshake . i just do n't understand what two brothers was going for on this one .
s - excellent . yellow grapefruit , with lots of citrus , and a malt backing . great appearance and smell , no taste .  m - somewhat lacking in mouthfeel .

bottle ( 2011 ) port bottle shop carlsbad , ca dark black with no clarity throughout . thick and persistent light brown head and plenty of spiderweb lacing down the glass .  nothing to write home about when it comes to mouthfeel . kind of a club-soda feel to the beer , tingly . though there seems to be a strange `` romanian roulette '' effect where every sixth beer is kinda soapy .

appearance : large , crackling layer of fizz off pour , which descends to a firm , tan crown . deep brown body shines crimson in light and shows excellent clarity . nice head retention and lace .  i can see why the word peat was used before in a review the mouthfeel was medium to light i will agree it needs some more body to it this is a good brew and with a little tweaking it could become world class .

a -- pour a cloudy pale gold color with two fingers of head that recedes fairly quickly but leaves some lacing on the glass s -- smell is spices , banana/clove , light wheat malts .  shockingly light carbonation feel . i think the mouthfeel is off from what it should be .

t - not as complex as i had hoped for , but still good . starts off with bourbon vanilla flavors with some caramel malt sweetness mid palate , then big oak flavors with a bit of spice through the long finish .  i feel that it felt a little light on the tongue after it went down .
very big head on this one . very big and fluffy ... looks like powdery hills of golden snow .  the mouthfeel is a little on the thin and watery side though .

smell- the jasmine is def . present in the nose of this one , along with fruity , citrus , hop notes . taste/mouthfeel- starts out with a nice hop presence but then fades quickly drinkability- very easy drinking beer , having it with some food helps the overall taste of the beer too .  come and drink this corn syrup !

clear dark ruby appearance . creamy , somewhat bubbly , beige head sits on top .  cake/nutty malt up front with a huge , thick spiced tea hop flavor headbutt with the swallow . not just season 's best , but saranac 's best . i usually find them to be just an average brewery but this stuff is nice .

smell- lots of dark fruits off the starting line . the dark fruit aroma is huge . followed by a hint of banana esters . very inviting , but also oddly fearsome . taste- not nearly as complex as aroma let on . as it warms , it gets better , but not that extremely rich , complex blend of tastes that a lot of belgian holiday beers have . drinkability- good , but not great .  m - decent body with a bit more carbonation than i 'd like from this style .

crazy amount of hops , smells awesome . t - tastes of citrus hops , pine , grapefruit , smooth fruity malts . d - this is definitely a very good black ipa .  mouthfeel : hoppy and rough , but a bit fuzzy .

aroma packs an immediate bourbon punch and is balanced by rich vanilla and milk chocolate . molasses , raisins , brown sugar and caramel with very little roast , burnt or hop aromas . non-existent alcohol and the sweetness is very pleasant and smooth . flavor is similarly smooth and balanced with surprisingly more of a milk chocolate , vanilla and molasses presence than in the nose . bourbon is still present , particularly in the finish , but never harsh . warming throughout , yet the balance between the barrel and base beer is remarkable . mouthfeel is slightly thinner than hoped for , medium thick with light carbonation ; slightly milky in character . i do n't feel like this detracts from my enjoyment of the beer , but for the style would have expected something a little more robust .  malty and corny .

amazing retention and lacing .  m -- slightly too watery , does n't really coat the mouth like i would hope but it washes down clean with no bad lingering tastes d -- this is it here , i think this is the beer i would use to introduce someone new to ipa 's .

a : black , opaque , with dense creamy tan head s : mild to medium nose , more spritzy carbonation than anything , slight roasted malt evident t : decent black saison , definite bubblegum and yeast taste , not as clean as i 'd like , somewhat metallic-sharp taste in body , almost reminds me of an average tasting extract homebrew m : medium bodied , good roasted malt but sharp , metallic bitter finish that makes it slightly unbalanced in taste o : not what i 'd expect from goose island for balance and representation of the style  this is a very good pumpkin beer . picked a 6 pack up at the local market , came home on a chilly night here in rural mi , and my girlfriend and i finished the whole six pack . lots of pumpkin taste , beautiful color , and an overall great seasonal choice . i would n't drink it in warm weather , but on this cool fall night , it hit the spot . i could see picking this up in the future to bring to a bon fire , or to enjoy while i hand out candy on halloween . cheers !
a - a lovely copper with startling clarity , it truly poured beautifully .  mouthfeel : tingly and not quite substantial enough . seems to be the only point where this beer loses some ground .
s - nutty , chocolaty , malty aroma .  the taste is also fresh but a with bit of watery mouthfeel .

my first impression was that it was surprisingly bitter for a beer that advertises `` creamy and smooth '' . the colour is auburn ( tetley 's tea , anyone ? ) , with a creamy head .  m-its a little undercarbonated but the balance of the sweetness with the malt and subtle hops make for a relitivly complex october beer . d-easy to drink and very nice to have this time of year , easy to session .

nose : an absolutely great floral hop aroma consumes the nose . very nice ! it has a fantastic aroma , a great hop bite but a low ibu and low abv . one word : impressive .  mouthfeel was my only complaint .
pours a beautiful burnt sunset orange with crystal clarity , finger of foamy head has good retention .  perhaps a little watery , fuzzy . quite drinkable but somewhat sweet .

pours garnet with 4 fingers of off white/sand colored head . insane lacing & healthy head retention s : sour , vinergary notes up front that dissipates to not much of anything & then comes back t : sweetness & sourness do battle up front , along with serious dryness .  its sucks to know that in a different format this could be so much more . body and carb is okay , but by this point i 'm already at the meh stage .

a : pours a hazy dark copper/amber with orange hues . beautiful off-white head that clings moderately to the glass .  flavor is very light malt with a slightly sour pucker at the end . finishes clean with minimal bitterness . overall , this is a very good summer beer . it 's light , refreshing and mild , so it 's a good intro beer for those that are n't into intense beers . however , it has enough of a belgian twist to keep more advanced beer drinkers interested . versatile enough to enjoy one with a meal or multiple at the lake or playing cornhole .

crystal clear ruddy copper hue . frenetic carbonation supports a tall , steadfast , cream white head that yields frothy lace .  light carbonation and light-medium bodied . starts as sour apples becomes more sour like lemon juice , dry finish ; easily the least enjoyed belgian i have had . 750ml bottle - gift from vintage cellars blacksburg , va .

aroma is unusual and very pleasant : something akin to meadowland following a spring shower blended with a peatiness and cooked vine fruits .  i thought the mouthfeel was a touch watery but the whole packaged seem very much an alluring strong-lawnmower , early evening session beer .

pours black with a long lasting brown head that leaves plenty of lacing .  mf : relatively light body with medium to high carbonation . would like a little more body , but the flavor more than makes up for it .

pours a reddish , apple cider , clear brown . nice whitish head which hangs out for a while . really looks the part .  mouthfeel lots of fizzy carbonation , lighter bodied , finishes dry . the high carbonation combined with a thinner than usual mouthfeel really did throw off the beer making the flavors less prominent than i feel they could have been had the aforementioned two things been toned down a bit .

the smell starts off with honey sweetness and pine resin which follows into vanilla aromas from the oak and the citrus aspect of the hops . some alcohol is present but it is n't overbearing . its like smelling a liquified custard of vanilla and orange zest .  an american classic . good fall back beer , or one to enjoy when a less complex brew is desired .
this pours a beautiful black with a one finger tan head with incredible retention and good lace .  mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium to high carbonation .

appearance : a deep carmelly red/brown with a big-ass foamy , frothy , sticky off-white head . a hurricane of fine carbonation is billowing up from the duvel `` d '' .  spicy and yeasty on the finish , this beer is medium-light on the palate with a high level of carbonation , much higher than i care for , really foaming up in my mouth .

crisp . ( t ) - has a rather tart profile with some serious pineapple & grapefruit citrus up front . ( m ) - a tad higher carbonation level than you would expect from the style , but it really is not too bothersome . really crisp because of it though , with really potent citrus .  m : the body is medium and so is the carbonation .
impressive looking beer .  mouthfeel : thin body and medium carbonation overall : a nice geuze , a bit too watery for my liking though .
looks fantastic ! the head leaves plenty of lace after a couple of minutes .  m - exceedingly bitter . needs to be a little creamier for this style d - not a session beer .
dark mahogany color with a 1 finger , light tan head with excellent retention and lacing .  mouth feel is sharp and crisp , with a high carbonation level .

guinness looks wonderful . poured into a glass , it 's pitch black but has dark ruby edges in the right light .  i think i 'm a bit parial to this beer for 2 reasons . it 's not by any means a `` specialty '' beer , it 's your typical lager and since it 's been around since before any of us were born it 's got a nostalgic feel . excellent beer in my books , average for most .

a beautiful beer at the start . a dark brew with a thick , creamy head that last 3/4 down the glass .  t- roasty , sweet malts , coffee and dark chocolate m- starts off nice and creamy and full , then towards the middle loses a bit of it 's body and seems to get watery , only to return with a solid finish .
a- pours a tar-like black with a tan head .  mouthfeel - the one noticeable drawback to this offering is the lack of carbonation . otherwise it felt very good in the mouth .

probably the best aroma of any ale i 've tasted all year . amazing ester profile .  this beer has a lot of flavor for a light . too bad its not a good flavor ! nothing impressive at all here . i 'm not sure what they are putting in this beer but its not worth the 7.99 they are charging for a six pack . i would recommend pabst blue ribbion over this any day !

very nice start of a semi-grainy and fully malted pilsner barley . delicious .  the nose is caramely and very malty . a little too carbinated for a traditional barleywine but lines ones gut like the best of the bunch ! being a sucker for barleywines i have to give this beer high remarks .

poured into pints : appearance : pours a deep rusted brown and is cloudy with an immense 2 1/2 finger , off-white , foamy head that fades and retains at a skim .  it 's a black colored beer with ruby edges . fairly nice nose , with a variety of dark fruits , as well as a bit of chocolate and coffee . really nice nose . flavor is fully packed , loaded with dark fruits ( blackberry , plum , cherry and currant ) , as well as some notes of dark chocolate , coffee and a light hint of alcohol . i like it .

s : mmmmm ! banana , caramel , chocolate , pecan . twinge is a big negative . better as it warms , but not great . looked and smelled great but flavor was not smooth and a little imbalanced .  light bodied though , almost watery . in a way this is an ipa-light - some similar desirable flavors and aromas , but less bitterness , less alcohol , and lighter bodied .

subsequent sips bring forth strong chocolate notes mixed with a nice bitterness.the aroma a each sip is truly fantastic . finished nice and creamy with a strong bitter note present .  this review is from notes in my `` travel journal . '' obviously the beer is now `` retired . there is some berry in the attack . the flavor smoothes out to leave a clean finish . it is a very drinkable beer , but not what i normally seek out .
a - black ad pitch .  the only real flaw for me with this beer is that it 's a bit thin , but that 's a bit nit-picky and did n't detract at all for me from this wonderful beer .

2010 batch @ harvest fest 10/1/11 a : golden body with fluffy white head and a good cling s : smells like it will be very good : lots of sour-adding oak , some noxious funk and tartness . t : definitely a let down .  crisp taste - not heavy as expected ... hints of smokey , woody flavors - has the appeal of a coffee porter ... mouthfeel is average .

a very easy drinking doppelbock , with terrific aromas , and a surprisingly `` light '' flavor and mouthfeel .  mouthfeel can be too fizzy if you do n't make sure to pour high for tall head . when i 'm drinking more than one beer , this is my favorite second or third , as it 's got enough hops to satisfy , is not highly alcoholic , and sells for a real good price where i live .

smells fantastic . spicy , fruity and different . really intriguing . tastes similar to the aroma -- some malty , almost candy-like , sweetness underneath , but with a strong bitterness taking centre stage .  dare i say it seems a bit on the thin side . the meatiness in the flavor is not backed up by the body . not bad , but just a little disappointing ... this is a fine stout .

pours a two finger cream head that fades slowly , leaving a good lace . nice deep amber color .  feels quite creamy at first , almost in a draft-stout kind of way , which struck me as odd . would rather it be crisper and a bit more carbonated , though .
this beer looks very impressive .  carbonation is ample but the body lacks a little texture .

pours a pitch black color with a huge brown head into my glass .  the body is sufficient to carry the 10 percent alcohol which is impressive by itself . some spicy notes and an effervescent type of feel to it .

the beer was poured into a champagne flute . appearance : this may be the singularly best looking beer i have ever seen in a glass . the head was very tall and proud with an off white coloration . the retention was perfect throughout the consumption of the beer . the carbonation was explosive rolling boiling bubbles .  m : light-medium body with an oily mouthfeel , and a dry and resiny fade overall , not a bad beer , though it does stray from traditional belgian dubbels in a few aspects : not as sweet or yeasty as the classic belgian examples , a little hoppy for the style , and its too light .
really cool head color : it is mocha with a red tinge .  m- seems a little thin , but nicely carbonated .
this nose is so unique and amazing . as i take first sip i wasnt ready for the electric sour rush that attacks the tongue .  medium-high carbonation .

pours almost a coffee brown with a hint of amber red in the bottom of the glass . nice 2 fingers of off white bubbles tops the glass .  mouthfeel : i 've always thought this was a little off ... not quite enough spine to offset the sweetness .

the nose is heavy on the rye malt- showing a more pure breadiness with fruity tones of buttery apples , white raisin , faint cinnamon , light brown sugar , plum . the parallels to rye whiskey are awesome in this . the medium bodied palate is caramelly sweet up front with a mild bitterness that ushers in the rye maltiness- drying and spicy with lots of fruity tones .  this has the syrupy goodness of the 90-minute , but with an added syrupiness ... robust and smooth , like a desert sauce , you could pour this over a bowl of vanilla ice cream instead of a caramel sauce , with its own french vanilla creaminess ... the only thing that detracts here is an odd light metallic twinge at the finish that didnt seem to fit . otherwise , this is a beaut of a big beer with a light profile .
this beer poured a black body with a thick dark tan/black head . a beautiful sight to see .  surprisingly light mouthfeel makes it a fairly easy drinker for a 9 % er

appearance , was this beers strong suit , poured a nice amber , with a frothy meringue-like head , that left broken puffs all the way down the glass , smell was rather vague , sweet malty aroma , dried fruit perhaps , taste waspleasant , rather weak , unsweetened tea-like taste , very light , and slight hop dryness , but a nice beer on a warm day , as it is here right now , mouthfeel , is light bubbly , smooth .  the mouthfeel was the only thing that detracted from the beer in my opinion , as i found it to be a little to watery for my personal preference .

the bashah has a body that is as black as midnight - very striking and its only with light held up behind the glass that you can catch a glimpse of deep ochre hue . produces a thick deep tan 2-3 fingers of head that contrasts beautifully against the dark body .  i 'm not getting much in the way of bitterness anywhere here , which combines with a medium thin body to provide very little in the way of a finish .

great looking porter . you would get lost at sea looking through this , perfectly black .  quite watery for the big flavor this one tastes and smells different from the main stream craft ipas , which is a pretty new category i 'll give it that .

the aromas were of blood oranges , honey and moist , fleshy herbs ( ie . basil , bluegrass , cress , sorrel , epazote , etc . ) on the palate these images were joined by flavors of toasted , dry biscuits . it was vermouth-like in its exotic spicing and dreary , liqueurish texture ( blame the poor handling ! ) yet its bracing , raw , and complex extraction of herb overcame even this `` flaw '' . can a great ipa arise by accident ?  if you aerate the beer in your mouth , it really releases the co2 . it would do well as a beer to server with medium to strong cheese .

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter - best before oct. 19th 2007 appearance : harsh pouring reveals a generous 2 '' head that lasts quite a long time . the head is tan with tiny bubbles that leaves a bit of lace behind .  very nice m : medium bodied-a bit thicker than i expect from an ipa or a dipa , but it works well with the oaky sweetness of this beer .

growler the bruery placentia , ca a clear light golden with a big and thick foaming white head . the head sticks around for quite a while and eventually leaves thick and sticky lacing all down the glass .  little fruityness . light to medium body , oily , light carbonation . could be a little more carbonated .

two fingers of thick , creamy baige head with great retention and tons of lacing .  this is a man 's beer . none of this flowery wine swilling critique lingo . light color , smell and mouth feel , who really cares . outstanding dry & hoppy flavor without sweetness . when bought in the 30 pack , cost is about 50 cents each . the best macro being produced !
pours a truly awesome blood orange reddish tan color with a tan head .  too carbonated , the mouthful of liquid seems to almost crumble right away .

500 ml bottle poured into a stella challis a - creamy , foamy 2-finger head . cloudy , dark-apricot orange . rings of foam stay on the glass as the glass is drunk .  m : still a bit watered down , but again , it 's better .

big whiffs of tangerines , honeydew melons , bubble gum , concentrated pineapple juice , honeyed graham crackers , and lesser notions of iron-rich blood , spicy tomato juice , and grapes- via a lightly woody and vaguely oxided sense of madeira . for as varied and intriguing as the nose is , the taste is fairly straitforward and unnuanced .  m : a lighter body with good carbonation which yields a sensation akin to chewing on a cloud .

ah the smell of the hop flowers , dominates this magnificent nose that is also sweetly malt , fresh and clean , the quintessential dry hopped aromas all present , sweet malt start , the top moderate in feel . finish is delicately acidic , boom , the hops slap your palate and cling till the very dry and lovely finish , just plain yummy !  this was followed up by a sweet , orangish tang on the tongue , followed by a sweet finish , especially in comparison to the berliner wiesse , which i tried earlier . the introduction of the lemon slice to the beer increases the dryness , especially at the finish . a good , summery beer with a name that invokes `` the simpsons . ''

there 's even some odd sediment that almost looks like it belongs in hot & sour soup . the aroma is welcoming though - deep , filling , and robust with mocha goodness . the combination of malted barley and coffee hide the barely noticeable smell of alcohol . the taste is also very robust - nearly syrupy without carbonation , but still good .  mouthfeel too prickly and astringent but medium body is appropriate for style .

it has fantastic light floral hop aromas . the alcohol content is n't particularly high and their are some superior apas around .  a good beer . comes in a .33ml brown bottle , part of a 6 pack sampler from brouwerij van steenberge . a sweet and dark beer , where hops has taken a back seat to the malt profile . not light , but not heavy either . give it a try .

smell : lovely aroma of apples , pears , and light citrus - notably grapefruit . slightly sour smell comes in at the end . a very sour character shows up that is a bit cloying , then the beer finishes strong and unpleasantly bitter .  t : wood chips , obviously , tastes like a sauna smells , charcoal , molasses , savory like breakfast sausage , soy sauce , real sharp sweetness that 's broken down by hops lurking in the background and that 's absent at the finish m : medium body , very low carbonation , i 'm surprised this was n't the cask ( it was n't but they did have it ) , dry bitter charcoal finish . the mouthfeel was a big drawback for me , it was very flat , considering this was the draft veraion .

bomber appearance - well , hello tall , dark and handsome . what a beautiful pour - thick , mahagony brown with a cocoa head that seems to sort of fade into the beer ( no clear division at first ) .  the carbonation is interesting , but a little too fizzy for me , i feel like this beer has a watery quality to it which i do n't particularly like in a porter . it starts out watery , then the carbonation kicks in .

this one is dark apricot , almost orange , in color and quite hazy .  drank in a chalice from a bottle in brussels at delirium cafe.. this is very good lambic . it smells great very sweet with cherries . the beer has a beautiful red/brown color with a white head , not a lot lacing . it tastes sweet with cherries dominating but has a nice sour kick too .
a- pours a hazed apricot color with an amazing soft bright white head that initially contains a lot of carbonation you can hear . soft , tight thin cap remains .  m : smooth on the palate .
the appearance was impressive , very black with a nice brown head .  mouthfeel is the only real negative to this one , medium bodied and a bit thinner than i 'd like .

the smell was very promising with wonderful aromas of sweet , bready malt with banana , clove , and a banana bread finish .  the colour is a light straw , probably the weakest colour i have seen in a pale lager , the head is very pleasent and has some serious glass cling ... the aroma is very skunky when first opened but quickly disappears and the taste is highly sweet malts on a thin body , very nice for dining , not a stadium brew ... i first reviewed this brew in march of 03 , approx 10 monthes ago .
appearance - cloudy dark red , 2 fingers of creamy head with good retention and lacing .  mouthfeel is bubbly crisp and slightly creamy , but overall rather watery .

let 's start with first impressions : this big beer makes a big impression on appearance . dark and sinister looking , the rough-textured mocha-colored head sits atop the black body like a russian fur cap . lacing is full and sticky .  carbonation is a little light though .

i believe that the triple rock has discovered the perfect color for this sort of beer . it is both red rock and red brick fitting both of its names to a t. head is thin and white with good retention . zero carbonation .  easy drinking but it has a different mouthfeel , it almost leaves a film in my mouth .

a : orange copper color , almost no head s : floral hops , not much else but thats ok with me . i love the way this beer smells ! t : tastes like it smells .  mouthfeel : a bit thin in body but makes up with an even overall texture not much carbonation very wine like with each sip .
a : a clear light copper bear with a nice foamy creamy white head . the nitrogen really adds to the appearance .  mouthfeel is a bit thin and watery .
s : great smell , fruity although i can not place exactly what fruit .  parching on the tongue . almost no flavor : slight sweetness up front , trace of bitterness on finish . really .

aroma is of fresh peaches , and is absolutely marvelous ; the best part of this beer . however , also plain and unexciting . good for what it is , but not anything that really excites me .  on tap this poured as a golden straw colored ale , clear and bright with less than an inch of head . there is an apparent hoppy aroma that followed with a similarly dominant slight-hoppy taste followed by the expected bitters - very tasty . i stopped with one . not to discount its drink-ability , there are just several others i wish to try .

750 ml bottle poured into a tulip glass . pours a cloudy corn silk hue with a pillowy cloudy white two finger head . super sticky on the sides with a head that sticks around forever .  lively carbonation is a bit excessive , but the body is quite smooth .
poured in my struise glass the beer looks very nice , dark with a creamy head . it 's a pity that the head disappears after a while .  the body was a bit too thin for my tastes in this style .

pours out a very nice copper color with great retention and some of the best lacing i ever saw on a beer mug . very impressive . also has nice carbonation .  m- medium body that was slightly under-carbonated . with more carbonation , all the flavors would bite that much more .

i absolutely love the smell on this beer , but i also love peaty islay scotches . the smell reminds me of a campfire on a beach , with the peaty campfire smoke , wet wood , and leather aromas . the complex aromas are a little subdued on the palate . tons of different flavors in this beer , but none really stand out in front .  m : the feel is creamy and medium bodied . rather light for a ris and that really detracts from the beer in my opinion . the mouthfeel is lighter than what i come to think of when i thik of a ris .

s : kiwi fruit and pink watermelon with a hint of yeast , very pleasant . t : nice floral component , early on flowery with and hint of dandelion greens and grass .  the nose of the beer is strong and gives off a nice floral hop aroma . the flavor is sweet and semi-tart with fruity tastes . behind the sweet fruit , there is a slight but smooth alcohol presence . the earthy hop bitterness comes in at the end and fades away with the semi-dry finish .

tons of banana in both the aroma and the taste . this is a very fruity beer , and i think the sweetness would not be as pleasant over a whole pint . a very decent brew though .  taste/mouthfeel : this beer is slightly oily , with a very limited carbonation .
pours a pitch black color with a tan colored head that fades slowly , leaving a thin layer of foam and some heavy lacing .  m : a light-medium feel to it and kind of syrupy .

looks great . large , stark white head with plenty of lacing . it looked great in the glass but fell apart upon tasting .  mouthfeel is ok. fairly light body , more than i 'd think it should be at this abv .

pours a deep brown with ruby highlights into a tulip . creamy off-white/light khaki head leaves excellent lacing and retention .  i sent it back thinking it had gone bad , but the bartender tried it and assured me it was ok. m - average for a macro lager .
pours near black with tan head .  mouthfeel- medium body with very little carbonation .

when you first pour it , it wafts clean fruity and spicy saison notes . put your nose to the glass and everything intensifies going from mouthwatering to mindnumbing .  m : medium bodied with not much creaminess or silkiness to talk about .

if this beer is to live up to its awesome appearance ( and awesome name ) , it needs to be much more robust in all departments , especially mouthfeel .  body is medium , mouthfeel is oily/creamy , carbonation is low but adequate .
the pour results in a fluffy off-white head ; the ale is a nice golden hue . patchy head retention and good lacing on the glass .  color and mouthfeel are average for the style and fine .

laced well . smelled freaking fantastic . toasty , dark fruits .  but it has quite a few pros : this beer is intended to be consumed with food . if you want to have chinese food with a light drink then this one is just what you are looking for ! it 's a typical lager : crystal-clear blonde , discreet taste and weak aroma . i usually do n't drink lager beers but this one i can have by the barrels while there 's food on the table . this beer is what you want to drink when you do n't want to drink !

bottle acquired through recent secret santa swap w/ alohac pours absolutely beautiful brown tinged amber . fluffy , long lived , tan head with loads of lacing throughout .  this is an enjoyable , smooth but tasty strong polish lager . the aroma is fresh , toasty sweet bread , hint of lemon , pine , and rather nice . it has a bit of a czech lager taste to it and the alcohol is essentially unnoticeable . the taste is clearly alcholic , but very smoothly so , with nothing rough opr unpleasant . it has a light caramel quality , bread , and nice , warm spiciness , it 's a bit rasiniy , sweet and spicy with a light bitterness coming to the fore in the finish . it does not taste quite as strong as it is .

absolutely pitch black from the middle of the fluted part down , with a gorgeous caramel brown cascading head up to the rim . excellent head retention and nice lacing . held directly in front of a bright bulb , no light passed through the pour .  medium-full bodied mouthfeel with below average carbonation , the latter being ( beside the appearance ) one of my few criticisms .

pours a clear golden color with a thick , fluffy , off-white head .  this is n't the fault of the brewer so maby it had great head . the main problem with this beer was infection . i 'm sure it was an infection because when i sniffed it i thought for a second maybe i was at the movies about to dig into a 12 dollar medium popcorn . past the buttery flavor i could taste blueberry almost which i 'm sure was n't intended either . it 'd be interesting to taste one from a different batch .

incredible looking esb . pours with the cascading effect and settles to a bright amber color .  medium bodied with medium carbonation . i only wish this average mouthfeel was supporting an average taste .

s- strong cherry and rasberry charachter . a pretty strong tartness is every step of the way as well t- very strong tart charachter , not as sour as i was thinking , nicely fruity at the start but it stays too sweet at the finish which is a little off-putting , however some of my friends realy liked it .  m : surprisingly thin , slightly sticky body with low carbonation . a little weak .

nose is amazing ! huge assertive orange spice . the single most assertive bold orange spice nose i may ever have smelled . beautiful . mouthfeel is rich and lightly creamy with nice carbonation and a nice texture and feel . flavors are just plain weird . there is an herb quality and character to this beer , initially stange and offensive that become very appealing . i suspect that one will love or hate this one ; and , it deserves a taste ; it 's unique .  mouthfeel is a bit of a problem for me . the carbonation level is also a factor , making it hard to enjoy in gulps .
ever so slightly hazed with micro sediment . retention is great , and the head lasts for the duration of the glass , leaving concentric rings of lacing .  feel is kinda harsh .
pours a deep , clear yellow gold with a little amber . massive 5+ fingers of thick and foamy head that just lasts forever . ca n't say enough about how great this looks .  carbonation seems spot on .
pours a deep black with a tan head .  mouthfeel is a bit light , to me , for the style , though it seems appropriate for the flavors that this beer brings to the palate .

mistakenly reviewed as `` jenlain original french ale ( jenlain ambree ) '' on july 12 , 2008 & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; & gt ; 750ml bottle with batch number of l717807.22 poured into tulip nearly clear , golden honey color . decent head fades to wisps and ring . pretty nice lacing .  mouthfeel is a little bit thin .

beautiful color , deep dark amber with beautiful smelling hops and some nice plumy undertones .  m : okay , mostly wet and satisfyingly quaffable , but with a noticeable alcohol presence in the finish .

either way this brew has a wonderful red color and that 's the only thing i really liked about this beer .  not sure if our north american brethren appreciate this but this is , as far as i can tell the first fairly widely available american style ipa brewed in the uk . the american craft brewing industry which has been accused of being derivative is really starting to influence europe which is great . i am all for my uk brewing industry but i do get a little board of the vast variety of often samey real ale bitters populating manypubs . we definitely have a shortage of hopheads brewing in the uk ! and before anyone shoots me down , greene king ipa is not an ipa ! ! !

very dark , nearly black , dark ruby edges , huge three finger head that falls slowly , becomes rocky , excellent lacing , and a cap that sticks around throughout .  a bit on the light side of medium in body , with a dryish spicy finish . aftertaste seems watery .
bottled april 22 , 2009 poured into a pint glass amber with a very thick white head . very good retention and lacing .  m - felt a bit thin to me .

pours hazy gold with a massive , fluffy white head . very promising appearance , but way overcarbonated if you 're shooting for anything lambic-esque .  mouthfeel is a little thin and aftertaste is a little too much ... like the brew has gone stale , although i know it has n't .

pitch black opaque pour with mahogany glints and a nuclear glow of a khaki cap .  a very special thanks to zeke at the speakeasy for sharing a bottle of this 1995 treat . it still had carbonation in it which was crazy . the beer was very dry at this point . the spiciness of this beer has been cut down from the aging .

this one gushed out an extremely creamy , frothy off-white head with a suprisingly long and stable retention . the bottom was also very appealing , golden orange-yellow hue that was opaque and reflective .  feel is smooth and well-carbonated though a bit on the thin and watery side . medium-full body , not too heavy . leaves a nice sticky coating around the mouth . a bit thicker and less bitter and it 'd be great .
the hop aroma was very good , while the malts were only so-so .  the mouth feel is heavy with a decent amount of carbonation .

wow ... the nose on this is excellent ! tons of roasted malts , coffee beans and dark chocolate . very nice ... the taste is n't quite as profound as the nose , but it holds up well . i am really glad i had the chance to try it ... after all , it has been on my wants list for some time .  had this during o'briens wet hop festival . pours clear orange with a white ring of bubbles . lots of caramel with some tropical hops in the nose . kind of like a fruitcake . earthy , yet citrusy in the taste . bit sweeter than your normal ipa . grapefruit and blood orange . good stuff .
a : nothing to complain about here - dark black , with a mocha colored head that hung around for a while .  m : over carbonated - fizzy .

it is overpoweringly fruity and has an amazing aroma . it pours a cloudy light rose pink with a huge head.you are overwhelmed by the raspberry nose .  mouthfeel- light-moderate mouthfeel . carbonation is moderate-high .
very heady pour . nice lacing .  creamy , light toffee . very mild bitterness . mild carbonation and foamation , could be a little more vigorous .

oh , man ... the aroma on this is , perhaps as the name implies , heavenly . almost a perfect balance in the nose -- fruity , pine needles , grapefruit . and this one goes through three `` hoppings , '' kettle , hop back , and dry hopping ... awesome . the flavor is just about perfect . a fine balance of hop flavors , including a nice grapefruit bitterness and a light bready undertone . but , as a whole , this is a very drinkable beer ... and quite delicious .  i purchased this beer in a mix and match pack at the recommendation of the guy working at the liquor store = error . the look of the beer was clear and it drank smooth , but it was accompanied by the 'sour beer face . ' the taste was a combination of failure and shame ( with a hint of fruit ) all leading to the grand finale of a quick pour into the drain .

brown to copper towards the edges with a huge off white head that falls slow and never completely goes away while clinging to the glass . as the edges fall away , thick ringed sheets of foam . this is one damn good lookin ' beer .  m - this one finished a little dry , too much so for my liking , but the carbonation was nicely balanced , making it very smooth .
appearance- beer pours a clear golden with a substantial two and a half finger head of eggshell foam over the top and lacing clinging to the sides of the glass .  mouf & gt ; easy , average .

a one finger , mocha colored head has supreme retention and some amazing lacing to go along with it . very nice looking .  rich , almost like chicken soup broth , and very low carbonation . in the world of bocks , this could be a new favorite of mine .

terrific lacing up the glass !  my first taste of it was great , however it lacks in the balance of the malts , and has sort of a over roasted taste . altogether though , this beer in my opinion is the best of the coors brand and i would recommend for something new . not a everyday beer though .

a- pours a brownish color with red hues noted against a white background . the clear nature of the beer allows me to see the carbonation , which is modest looking at best . the head is plentiful and puffy looking , retaining well and leaving behind a thick film of dense foam on the glass .  this one was surprisingly thin in body .
poured with a nice , white , foamy , frothy head and lotsa lace . color is a very clear medium-to-dark amber .  even with the earthy malt flavor , the overall feel stays on the thin side .

the smell is very rich in aromas . i detect very strong honey notes , like wild honeysuckle . the taste is actually not as exciting as the smell , but still delivers a great complexity .  mouthfeel works just fine , but is a little watery . highly drinkable .

smell is very sugary with a fruit and spice scent of apple butter . apple , cinnamon , clove , raisin , grape , figs , black pepper and sweet prunes are all in here . taste is drier than expected sweet but not very . good spice flavor that builds as you sip . the flavor just is n't anywhere as complex as the smell . mouthfeel is good nice drinkable belgian here that is worth a try , only problem is that there are lots better around .  m/d - mouthfeel is nothing special , the steely hop bite takes a bit away .
appearance- pours a super light straw yellow with a soft bright white head .  mouthfeel is lightly carbonated , a little thick ( like a dark lager ... blech ) , and generally mediocre .

this brew pours out a deep , hazy red amber color crested with a massive head that retains very well and leaves huge , sticky lacing .  m- thin to medium in body . highly attenuated with a soft carbonation .
s : strong hop smell with hints of citrus , apricots , and sweetness . d : an interesting ipa with the addition of the apricots .  a bit more body would 've made this an excellent brew .
smell was out of this world . very fresh hop smell , got me all excited about the fist sip , but ... taste was very underwhelming .  medium bodied , highly carbonated .

incredible retention , eventually falling to a quarter-inch layer of froth . impressive start .  unfortunately , it is basically flat , with a heavy mouthfeel . overall , this beer would be unbelievable with good carbonation .
very nice . taste & mouthfeel : drier than the aroma suggests .  m : very very mild carbonation .

glorious aroma of silky dark chocolate and dark-roast coffee beans . very pleasant . the dry , slightly acidic roasty finish leads well into another sip .  the mouthfeel is a little off , too light and thin .

when you smell it you immediately feel the cocoa and then som pleasant toffee and grass . the taste is also dominated by cocoa without becoming either too bitter or too sweet , perfect balance . however , it lacks in mouthfeel , it doesnt quite feel as heavy as the taste suggest .  heavy mouthfeel .

the aroma is full of dark fruit , raisins and plum with hints of caramel and notes of chocolate . subtle vanilla notes with a smoke tinge . whiffs of spiced rum .  mouthfeel is slightly thin for the style or maybe just thin for how much is going on there ... .like you are expecting more of a stout mouthfeel .

huge , mocha head forms and stays around for a long time , leaving copious amounts of lace down the side of the glass .  if i had to log a complaint , it would be that this stout is too thin and less of a cream offering . however , it is full of flavor and easy to drink despite being 6.5 % abv .

beautiful red orange color . a tan head sits on top for a while . a very pretty beer . we tried it with some honey ham and then some apple pie and it was terrific with both .  this is about my only complaint of this beer-too much carbonation ! carbonation gives a foamy/frothy mouthfeel .

a -- this one pours with as much head as you want , and probably more . i must have had a little too much force behind mine because there was a fluffy white head up 3/4 of the glass . golden yellow with carbonation bubbles racing quickly to the top . tons of lacing .  very good light lager . hints of barley and hops , with a smooth slightly dry aftertaste . this brew had a short lived white foamy head and lower than normal carbonation . i would highly recommend this to any light beer drinker .

poured into my duvel tulip a - pours a dark reddish-brown color with a huge pillowy tan head . this is absolutely beautiful , and took a good 3 minutes to recede enough for me to drink it !  carbonation is n't bad , with fairly good activity after each drink . mouth-feel is a bit dry .

the reserve special black bier was a beautiful sight resting in a dark horse souvenir pint glass . it was black as night with a dark tan head indicating the level of roast of the malts used .  m-a bit watery for my tastes but the taste makes you forget about it being slightly thin .

pours a hazy amber colour with one of the most impressive head i have ever seen . a frothy rocky mountain large off white head .  it has constantly proved itself to be my favorite local utah brew ( this use to be called the 2002 unofficial ale ) . if the pour makes your mouth literally water , you know it 's good . damn good beer ,

citrus hops dominates the smell . citrus and pine are the taste that stick out . a good beer but there are so many better ipa 's out there .  rated as a stout the mouthfeel is a bit thin , the carbonation is a bit high , and the finish is a bit less than one would expect .
what a gorgeous beer ! incredibly dark brown head , near pitch black color , and smells just right .  the mouthfeel has a strange little zing that seems inappropriate for the style .
pours a beautiful , clear , garnet brown body , with a two finger , tan head that is tightly knit and lasting . massive patch and sheet lacing down the glass .  mouthfeel is a bit light .
smell : this beer has an exceptional aroma of toffee leather tobacco cocoa , burnt caramel and coffee .  mouthfeel is fairly carbonated , a bit sour , finishing dry and crisp .

its smell is sweet and pleasant , and reminded me of peaches . i dare say red stripe is the best smelling lager i have ever come across , although i admit my range of experience is not the widest on beer advocate .  m : meh . disappointingly flat . i 'd like more carbonation .

i 've never actually smelt a flanders with actual fruit in the nose but this is really amazing and adds a whole new experience to this brew . simply fantastic and i 'm grateful to have had a chance to try it !  taste : a bit thin for a porter , almost to the point of being slightly watery .

dark brown head over a black body . there were tons of good stouts opened at the tasting , but this rose to the top of the heap . lovely stuff  medium to thick body , light almost too light level of carbonation with a sweet almost sticky mouthfeel .

one of my all-time favorites ... have n't had this in a couple years now ... midnight black with a small tan lace ... great nose ... sweet milk chocolate ... some java tones ... some roasted malts ... a little thin in the mouth ... not as a rich as i remember ... nice burnt malt taste ... not as much of a creamy texture as i remembered ... .not as good as i remembered but still solid ... .a pretty dry finish ... .i 'm a bit disappointed as i came into this review expected to put this in the high 4 's , but it is not that good ... still it is worth trying if you see it .  ginger is one of my favorite flavors . this beer has a wonderful ginger taste , which is exactly what i would expect from a beer with this name . further , there is a decent bitterness & a slight sweetness as well . i 'm not a huge fan of spiced beers normally , but this one is really nice . recommended .

pours a murky dark honey orange color with a very puffy 2 inch bone colored head that fades to a small cap . big globs of foam and rings around the glass on the drink down .  a really really long aftertaste in the nose .

this may be the best smelling pilsener i 've ever experienced . lovely complex , floral hop aroma . pleasant light grained malt in the background . overall , a superior beer .  lowish carbonation and a slightly thin mouthfeel .

app : deep amber clear . very thick fluffy white head w/lace .  the mouthfeel of the beer was , like most porter and ale styles , very average . however , the mouthfeel did not detract from the overall feel of the beer .

750ml corked bottle poured into a tulip glass . ( a ) - pours a hazy golden yellow color that produced a huge 2+finger fluffy white head with fantastic retention . it is sticking to the glass in webs as it dissipated .  the mouthfeel was medium/light bodied with a fine , prickly carbonation .

score : 89 appearance : pours a dark red-brown color with plenty of opaque-ish ruby highlights with three fingers of cream-colored head . excellent lacing , and the head really stick around -- if not apparent by the photo ( proprietary ) .  s : candied pineapple , yeast , and hops well balanced t : a typical ipa taste with accents of pineapple ; yeasts and hops , well balanced m/d a bit thin , carbonation too small and too much , abv on the high side and quite noticeable good beer
smells nicely of bourbon , really great smell overall when you put your nose in it .  i wish the carbonation was a little more noticeable in the mouth .

a : pours a bright light amber with a large dense head that reduced into a delightfully thick dense foam dollop that floated on top of the beer . very active carbonation and fantastic lacing . head stayed forever with very impressive retention .  could use both more body and carbonation .

poured to the expected golden orange with thick off-white head that stuck around for the whole glass , and left excellent lacing .  thin body ample carbonation overall : this is slightly better than bud light but still not really worth drinking

boozy for sure . notes : the nose is pretty friggin ' great . the palate feels thin for the style and the flavors that it 's supporting .  taste is more of the same ... some wild floral flavors , hints of citrus ... seems like the dominant flavors have switched from the citrus to the floral characteristics . i like it , for sure , but could use some balance . i 'm not a big fan of the bitter taste left in the mouth ... but it 's still plenty drinkable . a definitely above-average ale , but not the best .
poured with a beautiful , thick , creamy huge , fluffy , tan head with brown highlights .  m - thought it was a little flat , but not bad .

appearance- pours a off-white , two-finger head that recedes to a well retained thick foam . the color is a medium brown with well defined garnet highlights .  the beer poured hard but the carbonation ended up being low and the mouthfeel medium .
really delicious . 5 t : malty chocolate with some tangy fruit character from the blueberry .  the body is rather thin though .

a : poured into a tulip , leaves 3mm head throughout the session , light brown or burnt meringue in color . simple , but effective lacing .  palate : medium body , thinner than expected actually , but goes down smooth .

deep ruby color with a cream-colored creamy head that leaves a nice curtain of lacing . pretty beer , especially with a little light behind it .  pours a three finger light tan head that fades quickly to a ring leaving a little lace . dark cloudy amber color . light carbonation and light bodied . caramel nose . starts balanced but then a caramel flavor that stays to a clean finish . a tasty wheat . $ 2.49 for a 500ml bottle from john 's grocery iowa city , ia .
a- very clear copper with lots of carbonation bubbles and a decent sized white head with good lacing .  mouthfeel was avg ; like a nice dark beer .

the `` flaws '' in the smell work better in the taste , at least . it 's a good flavor , but it feels to me like the flavors need to stand out more . this beer smells awesome , but taste-wise it falls a bit short .  the mouth is a little lighter than years past .

pours a very dark and opaque brown , almost black , very thick brown head forms , settles to a big thick ring around the glass , lots of sticky lacing , about as perfect as a stout can look .  mouthfeel is fine - it 's a very light lager .

this beer is excellent , from the moment you open it till the las drop i have tried this beer on tap as well and it is good , the 22 ounce bottle for some reason does not taste the same in my opinion as its 12 ounce brother .  m : um . it was carbonated and did n't leave any odd off flavours on the palate .

bomber into a shaker glass , the boont esb is hazy burnt orange with a tall , rocky light khaki head , that took a while to subside to a thick skim leaving decent lace . very nice !  m- light in body and light to medium in carbonation .

s : the smell is very balanced and i am loving it . mild fruity esters mix with sweet bourbon , vanilla , and coconut to form what is probably the best smelling beer ( non-ipa ) i 've had before . d : fantastic barrel aged barleywine . great job mayflower .  sprecher brewing company is one of milwaukee 's first micro 's and in fact its the one that really got me into quality beer tasting and home brewing . this is one of my favorite octoberfest beers as far as drink-ability as many octo 's are a bit overly heavy for me . this one really leaves your palate refreshed and ready for more . i lived in germany for two years and never found a beer at a octoberfest there that was like american octoberfest style of brews but thats why i like them they are unique even if maybe they are n't trying to be .
s : some malty caramel and butter . tons of ripe fruit . t : malty and buttery again with some honey .  3.0 m : medium body . smooth , but not creamy .
pours a promising nearly opaque with a brown creamy head .  mouthfeel is a little thin , though .

a : attractive drink on the pour , looks like a lighter , creamier guinness pint from a good tap . huge head and flowing bubbles .  my only gripe with this beer was the mouthfeel . it was rather thin and watery with a mild yet large bubbled effervescence .
