towards the end of the night it settles down to a thin concentric ring but a nice swirl brings you back to viewing what i consider one of the most beautiful looking barleywines i 've ever seen .  m : somewhat thin body , slightly watery ; could do with more carbonation also .

from a brown 12 oz.bottle , cute dog , no date . poured a cloudy golden orange with a thick , dense , white head that almost topped the bottle before i began to pour , and left nice lacing .  m- low carbonation and very low mouthfeel .

vanilla , oak , maple leaf , faint rum aroma , and most of all ooey gooey caramel - sort of like a caramello bar . t : bittersweet chocolate layered with oaky and vanilla flavors , a caramel filling , and a coffee finish . i would even go as far to say this was luxurious or elegant .  a delightful golden color graced by a pale yellow head . i did n't get much lacing , but i believe that was due to a freshly-washed glass ( served at a bar ) . nice hops come through in this one . it is a little bitter and spicy , but also has some good vanilla and tones of malt . not the most fantastic example of its style , but tasty and very drinkable .

s- smells like autumn . upfront you get a nice whiff of pumpkin and spices . the rum creates a perfect blend here . adds a great alcoholic sweetness to the aroma . t- after the aroma , i ca n't help think that this was a let down . the blandness actually intensified as the beer warmed .  mouf & gt ; nice , nothing special drinkability & gt ; sure thing

poured a hazy golden yellow with a three finger white head that remained throughout the glass and even continued to grow if left to sit for long . insane ! maintained phenomenal lacing throughout the glass . first off , the appearance on this one was ridiculous for the style .  there is a very little carbonation factor in this beer .

pours a cloudy dark reddish color with bright fluffy white head , great thick malty aroma . has a nice malt beginning to the flavor but is very thin after that .  perhaps a bit thin for the style , which i suppose makes it a good pale ale for summertime quaffing .

a : a much darker brown than most brown ales . poured a thick creamy espresso colored head with good carbonation showing .  slight hint of the hop flower but the malt dominates , sweet , crisp , fresh and pleasing to the senses with the start lightly sweet , satisfactory malt presence , and top light to middling in feel . this is a style where i like the lighter body , as it lets the flavoring hops shine through , quite quaffable , a damn fine session beer me thinks , and i thank royalt for this bottle .
pours a very clear budweiser gold , with a fluffy white head . in a big glass mug it actually looks refreshing . the can looks pretty cool .  m - at times , a bit of a metallic feel to the beer .

beautiful ruby red color .  no sediment at all when bought fresh . this really brought out flavors you could not taste beforehand . a wedge of orange or lemon is a nice touch also . best served a little warmer than most beers . goes really well with food . a beer you could drink all night especially during a good bar-b-que .

i had this beer tried next to or , poured from a bottle into a pint glass ... a : a pitch black color , very tiny white thin ring of a head , pretty poor looking ... s : smell is awesome . tons of hoppy citric and grapefruit notes , with some sweet honey and vanilla ... t : wow . a bit of a letdown very little hop bitterness and a strong cloyingly sweet flavor with little complexity ... m : smooth , could use more carb ... d : a decent enough beer , but its the worst between either and or !  mouthfeel is carbonated , but creamy and smooth . lacks the dry bite that i look for in a dipa .

s : big coffee and big chocolate with hints of ripe fruit , plums and molassas , very inviting . t/mf : sort of disapointed with this one , maybe it was because i picked it up at world market and who knows how long that thing had been sitting around getting light struck ( even though i picked it out from the back of the display , but who knows what goes on there ) .  feels thin .

for me , the appearance of a well poured guinness is stellar . the deep rich near-black mahogany tint of it , while the flow of bubbles seems to defy physics is near magical . always great poured over a bent spoon atop bass pale ale or harp lager as well !  much like the ingredient list on the back , there are scent of malted barley , malted wheat , hops , and yeast which gives it an almost caramel scent . starts out making you think this will be a heavy tasting beer with its malted ingredients like a stout but instead it finishes rather light . drinks rather smooth as the malted ingredients really hit the taste buds . finishes rather clean smooth . a decent beer with a rather interesting drinking experience .

poured with some mild carbonation that settled into a thick yellowish head . absolute best porter i have ever seen .  had some fruity and clove flavors but was covered up due way too many hops for the style - not to mention that it was bitter . i barely finished it . other reviewers liked this beer and seemed to have a much different experience than i did which leaves me to believe that they have consistency problems or maybe they use different formulas for each location ? btw this one was sampled at the brewpub near the fleet center .

an aggressive pour into a duvel chalice builds a 1 '' tall , khaki-brown head . retention is good and leaves an inital ring of lacing around the glass .  mouthfeel is a little thin , but not offensively so .

looks like a pretty standard witbier to me . nice and cloudy , has that ideal golden color .  just the right amount of hops . even though you can taste the fruits and spice , you can also taste the high alc % . drinkability : very drinkable , but if you more than one in a session , watch out : ) overall : a better than average tripel .

pours a three finger cream head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving a good lace .  leaves you breathless -- groping for words to describe what is one of the worst beers i 've ever tasted . i have had enough bacterial beers to recognize the usual flavors .

a- pours a splendid black color with a thin milky looking head that lasts the entirety of the beer and copious rings of lacing .  m- a bit over carbonated for me , but other than the crisp nature of most kiwi beers , nice malty and dry .

this beer was so pretty that i had to stop and take a picture . a beautiful translucent golden color with a billowing white head .  m - moderate carbonation-almost too much , dry finish , medium bodied due to the carbonation .

a-pours black , no light penetration , with a creamy , tight knight , one inch beige head that has good retention and leaves spotty lace as i drink . nice looking beer .  m : surprisingly on the more carbonated side with a slight fizzy mouthfeel .

smell is heavy with german hops as soon as the cork was popped . earthy and medicinal notes and just flat out green grass .  a light- to moderate mouthfeel , hints of sour flavor linger at the back of the tongue after the swallow . i do n't pick up much of a hint of carbonation in the mouthfeel .

much better than guinness off the nitro-keg , but not as good as a regular quality stout . very imposing solid black brew with a giant head .  mouthfeel medium body for the style with sharp carbonation .
pours a very dark brown with a nice frothy one finger of off white head that sticks around a while .  the mouthfeel is thiner but still good .

this beer pours a golden color , with a thick and fluffy white head . the head fades slowly , leaving a nice lacing .  there is little ( hardly any ) carbonation here , and the mouthfeel really does n't pack a punch at all .
very inviting , to say the least .  m : light bodied and well carbonated .

a : pours deep brown , nearly opaque . good head with a bit of retention and good lacing .  mouth feel : a bit thin on the palet , or maybe the aroma and taste make you expect more in the way of mouth feel .
the beer poured into the glass crystal clear medium maber with an off-white frothy head which lasted to lace the glass .  m : very carbonated .

very nice presentation . aroma is forresty ( real word ? ) with grassy , herbal , piney , sprucy hop notes along with citrus notes of grapefruit and lemon rind .  mouthfeel suffers a little bit as i feel a higher abv would 've left this coating the tongue a little better . it seemed a little too thin to match its flavor profile .

how many citrus fruits are there ? this one has aromas of all of them -- i 'm picking up kumquat , grapefruit , lime and tangerine ( piney rind ) at the very least . all those citrusy hops i smelled are seriously restrained in the taste . from classic to extreme , from belgian to beefy american , from populist to just plain weird , dogfish head 's got it all . i 'd be their bitch in a heartbeat .  a little less carbonation and this probably enters `` special '' territory .

looks absolutely fantastic , deep impenetrable black body with coffee coloured head , aromas full of coffee and chocolate and heavy dark roast malts with some fruity notes and a little hop .  the carbonation is heavy and it adds harshness to the palate . medium-full body .

looks perfect . mounds of off white maybe pretty much light tan head , and has a clear dark copper colored body .  take this beer for what it is ... a nice `` treat . '' it 's not something you will want to drink all night long . but for a nightcap , or change of pace this beer fits the bill . the vanilla taste is not overpowering , it 's there , but not so bold and overpowering that it seems fake .
gorgeous , classy looking beer .  thin to medium bodied with moderate carbonation .

i know this is a beer and should smell like one but this smells really good to me , reminds me of candy apples when i was a tyke .  mouthfeel was a bit heavy and undercarbonated , but that may have been more of the fault of the bar i was at , and not the beer its self .
pours a deep dark brown with three fingers of khaki head .  the mouth fell was a little thin for stout .

pours a nice bright yellow orange with a massive , almost overflowing white head . head sticks around indefinitely as bubbles continually rise in an energetic fashion .  m/t : light to medium body , watery and a good amount of carbonation . however with the light body , low bitterness and virtually zero aftertaste , i could session this beer .
pours a huge near glass full of pillowy head .  the body was medium to medium light .
smells very delightful , just like fresh lemonade .  mouthfeel : slighty watery good .
very enticing . taste has quite a bit of belgian yeast and spice .  mouthfeel : typical red stickyness drinkability : i love this beer .

sticky , webbed lacing s - booze ! bourbon , vanilla , malt hiding under there somewhere . t - booze ! d - booze ! this one is just a little too 1 dimensional for me .  mouthfeel is high carbonated foamy and slightly mouthcoating .

smell & gt ; sweet and resiny . a perfect balance of the two scents without much alcohol heat .  tart and dry feel , but not overly so . lower carbonation detracts a little , really the only flaw in my mind .
it has a very sweet aroma to it and that makes it all the more appealing . smell is more prevalent the more it warms up .  mouthfeel is light , and carbonation is set at medium .

the nose piques my interest in this brew as the aroma is highly reminiscent of a belgian triple with strong esters of alcohol , yeast , and caramelized sugar . entry is muted until the midtaste takes over by blanketing the tongue with a thick coating of honey . my numbers reflect my overall impression of this brew ... nice appearance , great nose , overpowering honey midtaste & finish .  thin bodied , and just sufficient carbonation , but i suspect the growler is at fault much more than the beer .
it smells awesome and makes my mouth water just anticipating the first taste !  m - crisp and bitey , high carbonation - the bottle overflowed when i opened it .

22 oz bottle poured into imperial pint glass a - pours a near black opaqueness with a large 2 inch tan colored head . a good looking beer .  the motuhfeel is moderately carbonated and slightly watery .
huge ass head , white fluffy cloud pillowtops chillin . a light golden color with a crazy amount of lacing .  mouthfeel is on the thin side for a stout .

a- light copper body with a creamy white head that laces and stays to the last drop . d- highly drinkable .  nice aroma of hops but i would hope for a bit more being a hops lover . the celebration ale , from the same company , seems to hit the spot more than this beer but still worthy of a place in the fridge and still better than many micro beer ipa ii . sierra nevada seems to me to be the only mass beer company that brews excellent beer for `` mass beer '' prices .
this really is a beautiful beer with it 's deep amber hues and dense mousey head that clings to the side of the glass .  mouthfeel was ok , not too thin , right amount of carbonation .

burnt amber with a fluffy , light tan head of good size and staying power . lots of foamy lace left in the tulip as the head never really dies but eventually falls to a cm or so in height . there 's still some retention before the glass is finished . very nice .  the carbonation is around medium . there is a watery texture to the beer which is not pleasant .

) aug. 15 2008 @ hop cat ba / brewery grand opening event , served in tulip glass . opaque black , creamy tan head , beautiful bubble suspension after pour , wow ! looks thick smells of roasty heavy malts , dark fruit , smooth and creamy , mmm taste is of thick heavy bitter chocolate , hot alcohol , rich and smooth , compared to keg this is way mellowed , not as harsh and easier to drink , amazing ! , raisins , chocolate , slight coffee , earthy peat , mm mouthfeel is oily slick , smooth , creamy , viscous , a sipper for sure - delicious !  guest two usually drinks michalob ultra , coors light , or busch light . since this is my girlfriends dad he knows about my passion for quality beer so i 'll often encourage him to sample what i am drinking . he rarely enjoys any of them and most of the time makes a look of disgust after the first sip . he drank two bitburgers in about a half hour without one little peep about the taste . i noticed these reactions before i had the opportunity to sample this beer myself . later in the evening , after the music was turned down and the midnight snacks were partaken of , i tried one . they were right , this beer sucks over a year later i have grown to like this beer alot .

a- the pour yields an opaque black body with a small khaki colored head composed of tightly knit bubbles . the head is long lasting and leaves complete rings on the sides of my glass .  m : very carbonated - almost too much .

a : standard pour yields a .25 dark mocha head with great retention . beer is a dark , opaque , motor oil black . lacing is spotty and stringy with decent cling and thick , oily legs . a masterpiece considering how heavy it looks .  m - fairly thin body and medium carbonation . nothing special on the mouthfeel .

it almost overflowed out of the glass but soon settled into a craggy , dense mountain of a cap . massive cordillera of lace are plastered to the glass .  the taste is sweet and smooth , with a hint of hops but the most prevalent taste is of lemon . finishes with a very refreshing aftertaste . i would defiantly suggest this beer to even non craft beer drinkers .

it smelled much like a chocolate stout should .  the flavor too is ever so slight wine barrel aging with a weird and awkward type sour . it 's really off putting . this barrel aging was awful . this beer is weak and severely overrated . it was awful both times .

aroma is really nice for a bourbon-barrel stout ... vanilla , sweetish milk chocolate , with an underlying fruitiness from the barrel . very tasty stuff ...  m : not too bad , there was a little bit of body .

a big frothy white head that sticks around forever , and then leaves some pretty sticky lace on the glass . a very pretty beer , love head .  this feels thin for some reason . carbonation is good and proper .

brilliantly clear , tawny copper hue . pitted , steadfast ivory white head . persistent , massed lace trails .  mouthful mouthful is okay . has decent carbonation , but i 've had better as far as carbonation goes .

the nose begins to drift toward me as i pour ... a nice roasted barley , chocolate and espresso with a hint of cinnamon . this smells more like a stout . the nose is deceiving .  despite the nearly opaque black color , the flavor of this one is surprisingly light . there are sweet malt notes , a delicious fruitiness and some fairly rich yeasty , estery notes . i keep over-looking this brewery , but every time i try one of their beers im usually pretty impressed . this particular beer is tasty , refined and very drinkable . recommended .

ahh , the smell makes up for the poor visual aspect ... it is phenomenal ! nonetheless , this is an outstanding nose . barrel aging is very evident upon tasting , as is the alcohol . to me , it almost seems like a tripel and a half , as it needs a bit more body-adding malts and the alcohol is a bit rough ... but that is being a bit picky , i am very glad i brought this out for my 500th .  mouthfeel is ok. a litte too dry for my liking though .

the first thing you notice on this beer is the gorgeous pour .  very ashy , very charred , and it really lacks some body and sweetness to back up the astringency . feel is very light , a shame , because a thick , chewy , silky body is a necessity in the style .

the aromas are divine : brandied , sour apples , an array of raw and roasted nuts , oranges , vanilla and pepper . on the palate it was metallic and struggled to deliver the promise of the nose . still , bright , sweet green strawberry and caramel curled in and out of the perfectly flat liquid . apparently this beer was not out of date , as there have been many other reviews this year for examples this old . a shame .  it was my first fruity beer . it kinda tasted like an apricot . i was expecting most of a fruit taste like wine , but no . and i liked the picture on the bottle . and since it came ithaca i just had to try it . over all the beer was worth it . it 's good . : )

nose : much brighter than the 2007 with lots of zippy hops . caramel malt and new leather dominate the aromas . fresh figs , dried dates and autumn leaves round things out . a little more simple , but much more inviting than 07 . the nose is phenomenal , but the palate does not deliver .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and syrupy with a bit of sharp carbonation .
i was first impressed with the color - almost black ! big , creamy , frothy head .  mouthfeel - very enjoyable borderline complex character .

brilliant cloudy , fuzzy , bubbly orange appearance with a perfect 1/4 inch puffy head and a pleasant hoppy aroma .  taste : mirrors the smell , but the flavors are weaker than their aroma counterparts because of a thin mouthfeel .
it has the perfect color for a lager , dark but not to dark .  mouthfeel is fullbodied , and slightly cloying .
the nose had a definite saaz quality to it .  the only thing i felt was it could use a little more carbonation to balance the tart flavor and make it more perky .

o : for a beer that shares the great smells i associate with world-class english barleywines and doppelbocks , chimay grandrserve certainly disappoints me in other categories .  body is on the thin side of medium and the finish is both mildly astringent and slightly bitter .

poured with a huge frothy head . brilliant white in color , the head lingered and then left some amazing lacing . looks great .  mouthfeel : bubbly and light body . the mouthfeel is a little peculiar and affects my experience .

first of all this is an amazing looking beer . a nice pale orange , hazy , with a huge rocky white head . great retention and that belgian lace that i love .  the mouthfeel is decent , but could be a bit more robust to support the flavors .

aromas are super fruity and super hoppy ranging from grapefruit and other citrusy fruits , to a little oily piney aroma that just makes it known that there are some hops in this beer . the finish on this beer is nice a bitter , but still very citrusy with a slight sweet tone that still stays even with all the bitterness .  muted roastiness and chocolate malt notes . deep black body with a decently firm and lasting thumb thick head . roasted coffee beans int he fore followed by toasted and burnt bread and some mild chocolate notes int he finish . finish is dry and coffee tinged great classic porter .
pours a copper color with some haze . it has the consistency of whipped cream and has some of the best retention ive ever seen .  m - a little strong on the carbonation for my taste .
this amber ale pours with a clear amber body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing left on the glass .  mouthfeel - rather bubbly , fairly thin .

appearance- one of the best looking belgian pale 's i have seen . a large 2 inch big bubbled head which 1/4 inch remains until the last drop is consumed . excellent lacing stuck to the entire rounded wall of my glass .  decent palate , a little thin like the others in the series , but fairly smooth .
a : great tawny head , near opaque in color s : somewhat light , a bit of caramel malt , slightly sweet t : yuck !  it has a pretty high carbonation .
perfect looking .  im augustus gloop : ) m - carb a little low , a little on the sweet side .

this is a lovely slow-sipping beer .  not too many micro 's that come out with a light ale . hats off to them for bringing this to market to allow folks who are used to drinking american mass producted swill to move into a easy drinking michigan micro brew . lighter than sam adams but more flavor then the bud and miller 's of the world .

looks like a ton of carbonation . golden , cloudy . great looking beer and i 'm excited to taste my first jolly pumpkin .  nice flavors , with a nice two-row malty sweetness and a huge piney and slight citrusy hop flavor that is very much in front ; good overall , but very unbalanced , even considering the style . goes down fine , but there is quite a bit of hop scratchiness .

poured into a tumbler it produces a 2 inch head that persists and clings to the glass in great clumps . the appearance is perfect pale and slightly cloudy .  m : a bit overcarbonated , dry , thin , light-medium bodied .

pours a brilliant copper ; a vigorous pour produces only a one-inch head but a nice , tight , foamy one .  it 's sort of smokey but in an artificial way . rubber and alcohol . the rubber turned into a slightly smokey malt flavor but still lingered in there . alcohol dominated any sort of flavors coming through . i just did n't enjoy this beer at all . if i ever cross paths again with this beer i 'll re-review it .

the aroma features the citrusy amarillo hops they note on the bottle along with tons of wheat .  the mouthfeel is light , but hey , its a light beer ! for drinkability , again , one of the beers that could probably never offend me .

750 ml bottle cage & cork & gt ; chimay gob deep , dark amber color , red hues with a blissful carbonation with a two-finger deep head at first , solid white , thick and dense and lots of life , the retention is as good , if not better than any i 've seen . amazing look .  the palate is bland , sweet , and clean . the strongest aspect of this beer is its mouthfeel , it is medium , sturdy carbonation , very basic but appropriate .
a pretty good looking beer .  mouthfeel is a bit fizzy , and another beer where bottle-conditioning would have a positive impact .
pours deep brown with a nice creamy head of foam .  i like a little heavier of a mouthfeel than this offers , but the lighter feel is not surprising considering the crystal appearance .

poured into my duvel tulip glass , poured a rich thick borwn that cant be seen through , a rich creamy five finger head rises to the top and stays awhile , the smell is rich grain and alchoal with a sweet fig overtone , the flavor is figs , hazelnuts , molasses , honney , sweet malt , a hint of folaral hops then malt for days .  carbonation is fizzy on the tongue where it should be soft and creamy .

got this beer from a wisconson native , she figured i 'd like this beer ... makes a deecetn two finger thick bright white head , and has a semi hazy white gold colored body .  slightly under carbonated for my taste but not really a flaw .

wonderful aroma . perfect to style taste : bland .  but there are hints of dark fruits that seem to disintegrate on your tongue , slight astringent alcohol tate/smelll this is defiantly a very drinkable brew .

the aromas promise a dandy ; juicy dark fruit ester , roasted coffee , pineapple , chocolate powder and molasses , and hints of bubble gum . a silky mouthfeel , slightly oily , and a sharp carbonation that does n't bite too hard is quite enjoyable . dark fruits , plum , sweet tobacco notes and some coffee and cocoa but not like the nose indicated .  feel seems to be about medium in body , but slightly watery , with a lingering semi-bitter dark unsweetened chocolate/coffee bean aftertaste .

after pouring most of the 16oz can into my new duvel tulip , thanks again brian , i am left with an immaculate 3 beige head that lingers for what seems like forever , and it leaves thick clumps of lacing and leaves behind a nice pillow of foam . the medium brown hue with a red tint is darker than most but still pretty with good clarity .  mouthfeel was ok .
almost black ( ruby red highlights ) with a nice brown head that leaves sheets of lace .  feel is a bit coarse , but just a bit .

not faux-bacos as many low-end rauschbiers often are ... but honest to god bacon . once you get through the scent , there is a wonderfully salty and sweet beer underneath , that makes you want to keep drinking .  perhaps another way to explain the feeling would be a textured shandy . noting the high praise this saison received , i have trouble fathoming such a bad experience .

true amber in color with perfect clarity .  very pleasant indeed . great hop character . this is a fairly balanced ipa . hard to say , it might just be because this particular bottle is more on the room temp side , but i would like more effervescence . a good beer all in all . i will be sure to drink it again , only a little colder and faster . more drinking , less typing ... .

pours out an opaque black with shimmering brown at the edge of the glass . thick , creamy , off-white head and thick lacing as well .  smell is a cross between musty and estery at first , then just corn . tastes like corn , but considerably worse than a typical macro . it has some off flavors , that i ca n't really identify . bad .
poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glas 2 inch off white head on top of a deep coppery garnet , modestly carbonated .  on the thin side , and i dont get much carbonation .

s - if you like coffee , this is actually really nice . great roasted coffee and espresso aromas , along with a little unsweetened cocoa and vanilla .  wonderful flavor , with deep malt tones , a great smokiness , hints of peat , and a touch of caramel . goes down quite smoothly , but it does have an odd , almost generic , flavor on the tongue at the very end .

smell is super fruity sweetness , excellent complexities including wood , vanilla and a bit of alcohol . taste is an explosion of goodness . i love that barleywines come in 12oz bottles** , as that 's the size that i 'd prefer to have this style of beer in .  s : slightly citrus , faint banana t : citrus & yeast & candy sugar m : bit thin , but not uncommon for a triple o : i am sure age did this one well reading the prior reviews ... think i paid $ 3.50 for it , well worth the price and a good brown bagger at a tasting .

aromas are deliciously grapes , plums , candied sugars , and lots of fresh mild fruits .  it is medium-bodied with soft carbonation and seems perhaps more watery than i 'd expect . it leaves the mouth feeling a bit astringent .
very inviting . smells very welcoming , but lacking in other areas .  mouthfeel is somewhere between ultra clean and a little soapy - if that makes sense .

pours out a bright orange amber and sits a beatiful deep orange-brown in the glass with a small off-white head , fading to a frothy skim on the surface . it looks quite promising at first and has the nose to it , but the flavor is n't quite there .  mouthfeel is a little light for a beer this big , but that would likely improve with age . carbonation is a tad too prickly for my personal tastes .

appearance this one is light yellow in color with some noticeable carbonation and a big , beautiful , head even though i had it in a taster . the head left some foamy pits and lacing all over the glass .  being from the adirondacks i quickly likened this to adirondack brewery 's bear naked ale , yet a lager version , and a bit more wheat-filled . the mouth-feel is nice , but nothing special ( not flat , not too bubbly ) . in short , its a dandy brew- we all enjoyed it and thought it was pretty cool to have something that is only currently available in growlers from the brewery ( spring seasonal ) , drink up !

appearance : butte creek 's ipa sits in the glass a beautiful , brilliantly clear pale amber . butte creek has mastered the art of making a nice looking beer .  it seems to light and over carbonated for a stout .

very good smell . taste- there is a good amount of alcohol and hop bitterness on the palate for this one .  my only complaint is that i wish the mouthfeel was thicker . it was smooth , but a bit watery to me .

aroma is wonderful ... lots of raspberries , but not overdone like , say lindemanns , and not fake syrup like norwester . mouthfeel is flittering with a light body and very snappy finish . malts are gamey and `` corny '' .  the carbonation is mild ; there are almost no bubbles at all .

aroma is a study in subtleties . a little bit of roasted aroma , a touch of sweetness . each individual component is rather faint , but together they are very pleasing and inviting .  yack ! i 've had this lots over the years , but this time it got a major problem with butterscotch . aroma smacks me down wth that butterscotch - ugh . but , somewhere in there is some malt and a little chocolate , good malt . flavor is butterscotch - blaaahh . ca n't finish it . draft lines are clean here too . no more , pleeeeze
pretty good lacing , and , overall , a stellar appearance . however , appearance is n't everything .  carbonation is a bit low for the style .

i can taste all the spices and pumpkin , but for whatever reason the taste does n't live up to what this brew smells like . it 's a lot weaker tasting than i thought it would be , at least compared to the aroma anyway .  m - it drys out in the mouth a little too quickly for me .
nitro-can encouraged frothy tan head , superb retention , some lace , almost opaque hue .  mouthfeel medium full for the style with carbonation that is a bit too strong for my taste .

a : significant cream-colored head . the cascading waterfall effect is very cool .  too cloudy and not nearly enough hop profile . at first i wondered if the waitress had given me the wrong beer . i would have characterized it as a weak summer wheat beer had they not told me it was a plisner . there was nothing objectionable about the beer itself . i drank it all . it just was n't what a pilsner should be .

smell is of bourbon barrels , alcohol and some deep plum and cherry/chocolate on the nose . taste follows with notes of the barrel and a very lingering close ... nice.. good feel and the drinkability is extravagant given the potency , as the alcohol is present on the nose but not on the tongue .  medium carbonation .

looks really nice s : light fruity smells , with a caramel malt , slight peppery notes from from the hops , maybe a slight metallic note .  m- the mouth feel is a bit overly carbonated , yet not thin .
very aromatic . t - chewy malts with the same fruity ester present in the nose .  mouthfeel is medium with more carbonation that i expected due to no head showing up .

pours a opaque black no light showing thru this bad boy with a thinner mocha colored head , wow the aromas damn where to begin heavy on the dark roast coffee , bitter chocolate a hint of almond extract as well just awesome.flavors are heavy in the coffee department for some it maybe to much dark roast coffee and chocolate malt flavors with a malted milk type flavor , nice creamy , silky mouthfeel glides down pretty easily.if you like strong coffee and bitter chocolate you 'll love this beer .  m : thin , do n't take that the wrong way though but easy drinking .

smell is amazing ! you can pick out both beers , which is the goal of black and tans . prism hits the nail on the head , because in the beer , you can pick out the lemony hops of the pale ale and it goes very well with the licorice aroma of the porter . carbonation is right on , not too much , and at a very natural level . it brings something else to the table , and yet it works for the style .  light to medium bodied , carbonation seems to be at the right level .

see-thru burnt orange body with a huge frothy head . excellent retention and plentiful lacing .  m : the mouthfeel was a bit thin compared with other sours , although this did not detract from the overall enjoyment of the beer .

the beer pours beautifully with a nice deep dark brown color that passes no light through it , has a nice brown foamy two finger head with great lacing on the glass .  the last 2/3 of my beer was a bit thin , but this was quite refresing and very easy to drink .

probably the biggest dissapointment i 've had in a beer . after the terrific smell , the taste leaves much to be desired . the fruits are still there , but they taste spoiled .  m- actually the mouthfeel is n't that bad but it was really hard to focus on that while i was drinking joan rivers perfume .
aroma is a deep roasted scent that makes me think of chocolate cake baking . color is solid black with good carbonation and a thick tight head .  mouthfeel is too thin for my liking .

this settles very slowly to a thin , nearly complete cap and leaving behind amazing lacing . the beer itself is black as night . a small amount of sediment remains in the bottle and the last portion of the pour seemed a little cloudy .  mouthfeel : both the carbonation and body are on the higher end of the light range .
pours pale gold with a massive crown of stiff white foam .  mouthfeel is okay , no carbonation to speak of .

delicious smelling ! t- tart , slightly sweet with more ale grains in the taste . decent , but i was expecting more fruits in my mouth .  mouthfeel - foam is scarce and small bubbles and light caramel that fades quickly . slightly thin .

s : the aroma is forceful - sweet butter nougat , hazelnut and almond liquor , amaretto , fig , sweet nuts , dark cherry , vanilla ... almost an amaretto stench . t : tangy up front , highly carbonic , muted sweetness much as in the nose , delicate but rich nuts , light molasses , vanilla , all warm soft and lightly sweet , nuanced , dynamic , but flavor light . a delicious dubbel , but with such rich aromatics , the flavor in the mouth leaves more to be desired .  slightly sour , a bit thin , highly carbonated . quite drinkable .
brilliantly clear with a nice 1 '' head - amber/copper in color . looks great .  mouthfeel is medium-light , and carbonation is medium-light .

appearance opaque brown/black with faint crimson edges when held up to the light . a small creamy tan head tops the beer for most of my drinking , slowly sinking to a hazy covering . lacing is a solid coating around most of the glass , impressive . i can not really taste the oysters or notice any effect they have on the beer .  average feel for the genre i 'd say . it 's pleasant in sips and gulps and a few of em would be just as enjoyable as one .
one of the best smelling beers i have tried .  mouthfeel the beer is slick on the tongue with strong carbonation . the body is a little lacking , medium-light .

s - smells strongly of pumpkin spice , and a little hoppy .  bought this over a month to two months a go and decided to give it a go . it is an ipa so it does have a nice bright orange to copper color . the taste and the smell are sweet and fruity , the only bad thing i have to to say about it , is the taste of tea is very lacking . i cant pick it up but , other than that i wish that stone , ishii and baird made this more as a yearly offering , cause its really good

served in the `` new '' sam adams lager pint glass , the beer pours dark , dark brown ( might as well be black ) with an inch frothy brown head . head retention and lacing are both pretty good .  average body and carbonation .

honestly one of the most impressive looking ipa 's i 've encountered .  it 's got a little bit of a piney finish that 's quite refreshing . maybe closer to watery , but not bad . d- very drinkable esb .

boddingtons shows up a light amber , pale gold in color , with a beautiful inch of thick cream , the bubbles being almost indiscernible . the cascading action that takes place as the beer settles and the head rises is fascinating to watch . some of this head stays with the beer , and a thin layer of lace coats the glass all the way down .  had this today on tap @ hibernia in boston . diacetyl ? in an ipa ? and what 's with the low hop profile and mega-sweetness of this beer ? my pint was quite cloudy too . beer drinkers of the world ... this is not an ipa , and it 's a pretty crappy beer to boot .
s- hops are floral , citrus , and a sweetness in the background that 's a sweeter peach and apricot .  m - it 's a bit thin for the style .

appearance : a hard pour gave me about three fingers of sturdy looking off-white foam . good lacing and head retention .  this beer is not awful but it is not good either . if use to be better , i think , back in the days before aluminum cans and pull up tabs . beer is fizzy and gives a good head and that is about the only good quality it has .
the nose on this thing is awesome . complex sweet fruits , sultanas and figs , some ginger , brown sugar , earth and alcohol .  maybe a touch too much carbonation .
the nose has a nice strong hoppy and fruity-peachlike aroma .  mouthfeel is pretty thin and wine like tbh the beer has more wine qualities than beer , carbonation is also a bit high .

pours a dark brown with a large tan head that had very good retention . it certainly looks good .  mouthfeel was medium with a mild lager sweetness accompanied by loads of off flavors , including apples and grapes .
poured into a tall hobgoblin tumbler , there is a huge billowing light tan head . very impressive presentation .  mouthfeel : medium bodied .

i had it at the bruery out of a bottle , poured into their tulip glass . the head held strong , and had an attractive texture , the color , an attractive bright beer-colored beer .  some hop aroma and flavour , a little to light in the body for my liking .

pours up a beautiful grapefruit color with a very thin white head .  ran into the maui brewing company while killing time until our dinner reservations were ready . there was a very slight bitterness in the aftertaste but was well hidden in the passion fruit sweetness . found the beer to start like any average golden ale but the aftertaste was what i really liked about it sorta like an ice tea aftertaste .

it is also carbonated like a fresca soda , which seemed a bit odd , but it also helped to create a great aroma . i could really smell the cascades in this one when i poured it , but as the carbonation dies the hop aroma turned to a sweet malt nose .  i did notice after a while that it has been pulled from tap that it acquires a lack of a better word , a buttery taste that really dos n't go good with anything . i do like this beer and i 'm not bashing it . the buttery taste in my opinion did not take effect until thirty or so minutes after pour . i do keep some in my fridge . i have shiner before to make burgers with , which turned out great . good beer for beer lovers .

nose is great on this - grassy hops , estery yeast and sugary , bready rye . very nice , everything comes together extremely well . yeast seems more tripel than saison , but compared to the smell the yeast is quite tame unfortunately .  mouthfeel was a bit thin , but the taste was clean and minty on the tongue .

taste is very boring after the wonderful aroma . this almost has no taste whatsoever .  i could drink this one all night long . just the right amount of sweetness with a little more than expected carbonation . pale yellow in color , lemony aroma.very clean with little aftertaste . easy to drink and very enjoyable . will definately drink again .

deep golden to light amber colored with a big head that settles into a nice thin layer of foam with moderate lacing as you get through the pint .  m - very carbonated , to the point that it almost stings on the way down .

s- great pumpkin smell up front with a nutmeg spice on the back end . smells like a fresh baked pumpkin pie at thanksgiving .  a : solid black , modest lacing even at the beginning , but once the beer was gone so was the lacing s : malty , chicory , lingers nicely t : dominated by coffee ; bitter stout ; the oak comes through nicely ; not very complex m : casked , so it does n't really buzz in the mouth overall , a really good beer , but not as complex as i was hoping ; still , very worthwhile

a : light brown tea-like color with a large three finger off-white head and good retention and globs of foam grabbing the sides .  it 's almost too sticky and thick to be pleasureable , kind of like a toned-down bourbon county stout . i 'm not a big fan of the finish , which comes off like sweet wort of a stout ( oily and a bit thin ) . m : very thick , with some relief , but then a lingering silkiness .

lots of bubbles along wall of glass . leaves a huge & healthy white cap with bigger lacing along the outside of the body .  initial taste of a sparkling mouthfeel with a puckering sour cherries that coat the mouth incredabily . the palate duration is average . medium body .
a classic looking hefe , a orange/golden color with a billowy , white head .  the mouthfeel goes a bit aloof here and has too much carbonation .

the beer is certainly lighter than i expected with an almost straw color . the nose on this brew is phenomenal ! i 'm immediately transported to magical grapefruit land as the beer screams citrus into my nostrils . there is a piney base note to this smell to that compliments the soaring citrus very well . not on hops of course , as the grapefruity citrus notes yielded to a piney bite on the finish , but rather the malt character . while still a world class ipa , i felt that the backbone of this brew just was n't quite as strong as i would have liked and the huge hop profile was almost overwhelming .  the only knock here is that it was a little thin . m = is it possible to be creamy and watery at the same time ?

a - dark caramel brown in color with some golden hues around the edges of the glass . hue , foamy off-white head with excellent retention .  have you ever canned tomatoes ? if you have , you should be familiar with the smell and flavor tomatoes have when cooked . this beer had an overwhelmingly strong odor and taste of spicy stewed tomatoes . it was too strong to drink . i know this is not normal for this beer from the other reviews of it i have read ( and the style does n't allow for many strong flavors ) , but it was only days past the best by date and had been stored in a refrigerator . there was also some floating particles in the beer which i also assume is not normal , pilsners typically being filtered . i will come back and rerate , but i 've been told by some fellow raters that i should take this beer into account for my rating .
looks really viscous and is extremely dark . excellent cascading head .  m- the mouthfeel is a little lighter than expected , almost watered down .

what a `` mixed bag '' this beer is ! smoooth and lovely , nice head , good lacing , and a wierd smell and taste .  m : lighter body , medium carbonation , somewhat watery thin feel to the body , with a crisp finish .
overall , i really liked the smell of the beer - the flavor , not so much .  well , so ... if it 's a barleywine or imperial or whatever , well ... then it 's probably thin on the mouth , eh ?

beautiful clear deep red-mahogany color with a huge soapy white head . serious staying power and some awesome sheets of lace stick to the glass .  this beer has a fairly heavy body , a bit too much for my tastes .
smell is quite tart smelling , bit of sweetness , can easily make out the raspberry aroma .  mouthfeel was moderate , not super heavy or light .

absolutely gorgeous beer.a ruby-brown color with a very slight head that is quickly gone.very little carbonation.aroma of malt.some fruity , wine like aromas.malt dominates flavor.fairly obvious alchohol.not as sweet as other barleywines.tends to almost be a tad `` harsh '' between the alchohol and hop bitterness.full bodied mouthfeel that obviously speaks for the `` big '' beer that it is.overall a good beer but the harshness detracts slightly.definately a monster in itself.worth a try by all means.i havnt had this in 2 years but remember past samples along the same lines.will be laying a few bottles down this year .  it looks like a pale ale should , there 's some yeast on the bottom of the bottle and the head stays for a bit . i 'd rather have a bit more malt presence , it 's just too hoppy and bitter for me . drinkability , if i had to choose between this and a macro , i 'd take this . edit on 10-3-04 i 've raised my review score , since i 've either started loving the hop , my tastes have changed or the fact that this is one of the few decent beers you can get around here on a night out and i 've become more accoustomed to it .

absolutely amazing grapefruit , lemon , and orange aroma . also has a touch of sweet toffee and vanilla . this was a beautiful hazy golden pour , with typical cask frothy head . very well balanced flavor , then a wonderful dry bitter finish . this is an amazing brew , and the cask only adds to it .  the mouthfeel is slightly buttery but leans more towars a syrup-like feel . carbonation would be greatly appreciated and add a very unique feel for this beer .
nice clear copper color with a decent tan head , nice active carbonation , and nice sheets of lace .  m : fine , nothing special d : probably too sweet for a lot of people , but i 'm a fan .

very addicting aromas . thick chocolatey dark fudge , coffee accents , with heaps of dark fruits thrown in and integrated almost perfectly . sweet malty aromas lay behind the sheen of fruit and lend towards caramel and vanilla . this is a very dry stout that lingers for a long time that i find slightly displeasing . damn good stout worth drinking if for only the smell .  a : dark reddish copper ; flat head ; strong carb ; not much lacing s : strong raspberry aroma , very inviting ; occludes other smells t : expected sweet -- it is n't ; the raspberry dominates , but it 's quite sour , draped over a wheat-beer-like base ; i must confess , this tasted terrible to me ; it tasted like nothing else i 've had , so i do n't think this is something against the genre m : good carbonation redeems the experience a bit overall , a terrible beer , for me .
a - pours a nice amber color . ended up with a generous inch of head that stuck around for a little while . lacing was good .  m - pretty watery and thin .

pour : 750ml bottle to tulip glass . tons of webbing shows how big the head had been , like the water line of a flood . beautiful .  mouthfeel is a bit of a letdown.. crisp but not as crisp as i had hoped . overall drinkability is good , the taste makes up for what it lacks in mouthfeel .
dark brown with good clarity , this beer has a dense , light brown head with excellent retention and lacing .  the beer feels just a bit thin on the tongue .
bottle , a : pours yellow-orange , with a very long-lasting white head , great lacing .  mf : a bit thin , light body , medium to high carbonation d : another winner from sierra nevada .
beautiful dark dark brown to black color with a nice brown head .  mouthfeel is just a tad watery .

) , puckered 10/06 slow pour in a tulip glass poured murky pale orange with a huge rocky fully lasting white head with good lacing .  slightly thin ( but not watery ) on the mouthfeel , which turned me off initially , until i could appreciate all that was going on in this beer .

liquid is a dark amber topped with a thick finger of brown foam and dense and substantial lacing . carbonation is also very prevalent , making this model stand out much more than previous years . visually stunning .  mouthfeel was very thin for the style , but added to the higher level of drinkability .

poured black with a rocky mostly lasting light brown head with excellent lacing .  m- medium body with medium carbonation . a bit to high carbonation for this brew but still has a light creaminess to it . nice blend of flavors just mouthfeel is lacking a bit imo . also the head could of been a lot better especially due to how much carbonation .

nose is floral , with a heavy dose of grapefruit , and a good supply of light , fresh hops . smells delicious . flavor gets a lot more of the floral character , with a mouthful of aromatic and pungent fern , blended with a good dose of hops , and the citrus is barely shining through , mostly overpowered . this is a decent beer , but the smell definitely had me hoping for more .  the mouthfeel was a little on the watery side but i did n't feel like it ruined the experience .
just about perfect for a true winter beer .  m -- light carbonation . good body with a lightly soft mouthfeel .

the smell is great , very fresh , yeasty , sweet and fruity . some dry straw , scattered by the wind , some strawberry , some peaches , some plums . after these heavenly aromas , the taste appeared surprizing and a bit disappointing . almost like an eku maybe ... deeply chocolaty , but with an annoying alcoholic character . after tasting the beer , even the smell gets less interesting .  kind of leaves your mouth feeling very acidic .
s : big chocolate aroma , oak , vanilla and some booze . t : wow !  mouthfeel - medium body with a very active carbonation .

the aroma is amazing . smell it a mile away ; rough citrus , honey , upfront biting bitter that is unrelenting throughout . i really like the aroma .  first sip reveals a much thinner body than i expected and average carbonation .

been looking for this one for awhile ... a- pours a crystal clear shade of orange with a three finger , very puffy offwhite head . well , it looks fantastic to start ... it can only go downhill from here s- smells very citric ... no coffee coming through on the nose .  m : medium body ( maybe a little light for a stout ? moderate carbonation ( more than expected in a stout ? ) . mildly dry in the finish .

into a pint glass , it poured a transparent straw/gold ; heavily carbonated , two fingers of bright white , and great head retention and lacing .  mouthfeel : the carbonation seems oddly low , but the body is medium light which gives the beer a little bit of oomph that it needs .

pours black and thick . substantial tan head that forms of a billion tiny bubbles then morphs into a very slow fading creamy foam .  m - this is where the beer ranks fairly average for me . under carbonated and a little bit flat , would have liked it to be heavier , stickier , and have more of a bite .

epic 's version has a great scent , faint spices , with a slight smokiness . it 's definitely much more bitter , with an almost a lemon pucker factor . the alcohol content also seems to add a bit more 'warmth ' than the dc brau version , which is n't entirely a negative .  a beautiful creamy white head rests on top of a medium body . appearance is a transparent mild orange with a light brown hue . carbonation appears heavy but on first sip is found to be more moderate than apparant . heavy lace is left a head that never seems to go away . aroma is floral , clean , and crisp . flavor is hoppy and slightly bitter . toffee like flavor is prevelant in its aftertaste .
poured a brilliant gold hue with a completely hazed clarity .  it was a little thin .

this beer pours a semi-cloudy pale orange color . the head is an impressive two and a half inches in height , and recedes very slowly into thick , chunky lacing .  m- a little thin , but not too bad . nicely carbonated , with a slight bitter hoppiness at the tail end .

it smells wonderfully of coffee bean and dark chocolate . the taste is just a little bit dry at the finish for me , but very rich and complex roasted flavors going on here .  mouthfeel : it feels like an astringent hop bitterness , but i sure as heck ca n't taste any hops .

smells heavenly - a brilliant blend of maple syrup , caramel , toffee , figs , burnt sugar and bourbon . just a hint of booziness at the end . tastes a lot like it smells - however the bourbon is much more prevalent than the other flavors - you get hints of the caramel , figgy , malty deliciousness present in the nose , but they 're largely overpowered by the bourbon .  m : light body , watery touch , smooth with low carbonated in the mouth .
dark chocolate brown with a nice , thick , creamy , khaki head atop .  the body is light but somewhat creamy .

pours a very dark brown , black in the glass , with a nice tan head that maintains down the glass . excellent rings of lacing .  m- smooth , but a tad thin . carbonation is good , as is the thoroughly smooth finish with a tad of warmth .
not a terribly complex smell , but its really appealing nonetheless .  carbonation was fairly low , with thin to medium body .

per label `` a kicked up version of our popular wee heavier '' , i had the pleasure of trying that brew a few years back while in asheville and i have to say i liked that one better.poured into a 22oz nonic a deep amber/brown with a pillowey 2 finger light beige head atop that settled ever so slowly into a frothy mass leaving broken rings of lace behind , from there down hill.muted aromas slight brown brown sugar and fruit but it doesnt show thru enough , flavors stay with that theme very light with some malt tilted sweetness like brown sugar and raisin but its really light and watery tasting in my mind.hmm kind of a clunker here was expecting much more from a pretty good small brewery in western carolina .  4/5 m : surprisingly thin side of medium , slightly tongue numbing , spritzy .

attractive looking brew here .  taste some roasted chocolate flavors . flavor lingers on the tongue after each sip . not quite what i would consider a savoring beer , but tasty none the less . i could drink this beer around the fire in the winter or after raking leaves in the fall .
smooth melted creamy chocolate with tart raspberry , kissed with dark fruits ; plums , prunes and blackberries .  the mouthfeel is a little thin , very dry , but well carbonated .
it looked very promising , poured thick and black .  m : pretty light-bodied . i was expecting something more viscous .

appearance : beautiful murky caramel color with a hint of dried apricot . smell : amazing sweet english butter toffee with candied strawberries . very very rich and delicious . mouthfull : thick and smooth exceptional beer by another great quebec brewery .  m - medium body , not a lot of carbonation .

the aroma is exceptional as you can smell this ale when you pour it out of the bottle . deep dark fruity ester mingle with a citrussy coriander spiciness make for an excellent aroma , this is the first beer i have tried in which the aroma exceeds the flavor . the rich aroma led me to a letdown as the flavor was much more subdued than i expected . the body of this ale is an immense letdown as a scotch wee heavy imo should have a bit more viscosity and sweetness but this is a rather thin ale in terms of body . the scotch ales always throw me off due to the lack of hops and for some reason i have a hard time enjoying tha malt flavors unless they are balanced by a signifigant amount of hops .  a malty mouthful without much carbonation . resiny flavors fill the mouth but do n't obscure the big malt . this one is quite drinkable with an interesting mix of flavors that rise out of the basic malty sweetness .

pours a golden straw , as clear as an unmuddied lake of deepest summer . dense white foam fills the glass , then gradually settles to a solid rocky head that forms big sticky patches of lace .  the carbonation is moderate high . i think it is a bit high for the style but the carbonation does not take anything away from the beer .

s - smelled like delicious spiced pumpkin pie with clove and spiced apple undertones . this is an excellent beer .  mouthfeel : high carbonation gives the impression of a thinner mouthfeel , and the carbonic acid and alcohol bite knock this one down a little in the mouthfeel rating .

the aroma is like a fresh hop cone very nice . from what you expect with the aroma is a slight let down but that said it is nice . the taste malty to start the taste turns to a earthy hop flavor .  light feel with lots of carbonation .

the color was near black to black with light tan head . the lacing was exceptional , straight rings from the top to the bottem .  the mouthfeel has average carbonation and ismedium bodied yet feels a bit thin at the same time , as it falls off the toungue quite quickly .
the beer arrived at the table black with a tan head .  m : the only thing that let me down was the thin and carbonated mouthfeel .

a : nice dark brown with a somewhat ruby tint when held to the light . leaves a 1.5 finger tan colored head the leaves very nice lacing down the glass .  the body is is a serious letdown , nowhere near rich/full enough and it crosses the line into watery . the carbonation is appropriately subdued , and does n't overtake the lackluster body .

you can smell the fresh raspberry puree aroma from almost 2 feet away ! the first sip hits you with an insane burst , it tastes like you just bit into a big overly ripe juicy berry . i really enjoyed this but personally could not do more than say 2 or so glasses at a sitting , since there is so much flavor , so it would not be a good session beer , but it really is very great tasting !  thanks walter a-a nice rich amber , good head , some lacing that turned into a small bubble ring s-a slight bready smell , some citrus ( makes me think of citra hop ) slight sweetness and then tart t- close to the same as the smell , there is a slight tangyness in the middle of the drink , it 's a good thing m- it 's moderately lively not as much bite and tingle i was expecting , a clean wet finish o/d- overall i really like this , it 's not the craziest ipa but it 's more than just decent , drinkability , i can see myself finishing this growler , this is a tasty beer and one i really like

awesome looking brew . s : wow , what a nose on this beer . sweet smelling with fruity esters along with some spiciness as well .  m : i feel that this could have used a little more body and less carbonation , but overall ... not bad .

hopefully since it appears to be bottle conditioned that the beer is still holding up a - poured into goblet an opaque black color . fluffy inch tall light brown head that disapates into a tinner covering that lasts until the end .  m : earthy with a little grapefruit at the begining and a little pine at the finish . light carbonation .

pours black with a dark hazelnut head with some lacing .  i know some ba 's knock this onw because its not rare or amazing but i love it . if i am in a bar that i do n't think has a lot to choose from sam adams is the first word out of my mouth . its not too expensive and tastes good for what you pay .

smell- mmmmm , nice floral and citrus scents hit you right away . not too harsh , but about what you should expect out of an ipa . very tasty . mouthfeel- nice carbonation level .  the carbonation and the color were good , but this did n't make up for the off taste and smell .
very enjoying ! t - malt is smooth , caramel sweetness is restrained and some dark fruits show up .  body is light and a bit watery , not too syruppy at all .

smells great ! you go the same whitepepper honey spice wheatishness of duvel only with a wonderfully crisp , weedy background . tastes very nearly as good as it smells . big nodes of weeds , pollen , and wild flowers backing up a spicy , crisp , lightly lemony belgian pale .  mouthfeel was week and its not complex at all .

the head very slowly fades to a 1 cm cap atop this impenetrably black brew , leaving beautiful , copious lacing everywhere . perfection in appearance .  it 's light on body , and not especially interesting - but as fruit beers go , this was excellent .

beautiful nitro thick creamy tan head over a black body . has a lovely way of settling to a creamy solid chunk that wo n't spill out of the glass if you tilt it .  ambrosial start , lots of malt , the top skimpy in feel with the finish having a delightful hop spicy bite , the carbonation moderate and the aftertaste droughty and long lasting .

the smell is bright and strong . lots of clover but also a healthy dose of lemon and banana . it is a quintessential hefeweizen smell . the body is a bit weak .  the body is pretty light though and clean .

deep , shiny gold/light copper with good , medium creamy head , that lasts a few minutes , medium white sticky lacing , hugging the glass a good while .  ( m ) - this is where the beer starts to fail in my opinion .

starts off creamy white and then cascades from the bottom of the glass to the top changing to black as it goes . there is a thick off white head that lasts forever and covers the sides of the glass in foam and thick rings that mark each swallow .  mouth : such a light and watery mouthfeel that it becomes distracting pondering the feel when you should be appreciating the tastes . drink : the nearly too-light mouthfeel is redeemed by the drinkability of this brew .

smell : cocoa powder and chocolate . sweet but not cloying so . really digging the aroma . taste : where 's the sweetness ?  light bodied d- in moderation , this beer is perfect for a 2 beer session .
this beer looks like the platonic ideal of beers . light amber/orange color and a fluffy white head that dissipates slowly .  had a typical pilsner mouthfeel .

a complex , sweet smell with notes of chocolate , honey , bananas and a slight spicy note hiding beneath .  feel left me a bit disappointed , however , as it was thin -- too thin for this big of flavor .

on the nose : ( hold on a sec , i got ta blow my nose , goddamn pollen ) sweet pine and hops sandwich , a touch of dry alcohol , almost has that earthy breadiness of belgian trappist offerings , slight prune detected as well , an excellent olefactory exercise on the mouth : tastes flatter than it looks , not to a huge detrement mind you . the 10.5 % is subdued on the take , nice warming in the gullet however , not as interesting as the nose , solid but nothing to go gaga over imo . drinkability : for the style it is standard if not a touch boring overall , a nice beer , one to start people out on the style perhaps , the abv is well hidden here so take some care .  m : medium-full bodied , zero carbonation , silky . d : lacks the warming feeling that is usually related to a winter warmer .

i thought the smell was magnificent ! ! the taste , too , was sweet and fruity , but nearly as sweet as the smell , which is good , seeing that that would probably have been overpowering . i do not really have another barleywine with which to compare this one , but as simply `` a beer '' this is a fantastic brew ...  m : thin to medium viscosity , wet and distractingly acidic at times on the palate , with moderate carbonation .

appearance : thick white foam that looks great in a frosted glass . color is very unique for a pilsner . it 's very pale yellow , almost looks like lemonade .  the body is lighter than i expected , and the taste is a little more burnt than i would 've preferred .

it settles slowly in a dramatically lumpy fashion leaving a tremendous amount of chunky and webby lace .  a medium to full body . possibly a little too thick ( syrupy was mentioned earlier by easyr which sums it up well ) as it took me a while to make headway down the glass ( unusual for me ) .

this is an impressive looking belgian , from a 355 ml bottle it pours a deep hazy apricot colour with a great deal of carbonation action , and a massive creamy head that gets chunky on the pour , rises above the rim of my chalice glass and holds its form . solid lacing down the side of the glass .  hate to say it , but the bottle/case i have is absolutely awful . other than a hint of coriander spice all i got was an overwelming sourness that made this one of the few i had to pour down the drain . they obviously put wayyy too much orange peel in their mix . if you can get past the sourness it is par for a wit bier course . i 'm hoping this was a bad/expired batch because ... .as far as mill street goes imo , stick to the coffee porter ...

quite surprising ... not because it 's a great beer from dogfish head ( that 's certainly not surprising ) , but because i have never actually enjoyed a pumpkin ale . seriously ever . appearance & gt ; what a beauty . colour reads from dark honey to a pumpkin orange glow . extremely lively .  the taste is very good , it could use a bit more body but the flavors are great . tons of chocolate and roastiness dominate the profile but there is also some caramel and hops . the bitterness is at a great level in comparison to the sweetness , especially for the style . the guy below me has it right : not quite edmund fitz or blake butte but this one is one of the supeb examples of the style .
poured an opaque brown , as expected from a stout , with thick , pillowy tan head and excellent lacing .  great big head , perfectly tempting aroma , somewhat thin mouthfeel .
really beautiful beer , pours a hazy golden color with a huge frothy white head that retains impressively and leaves nice lacing .  m - not much fizz , easy drinking if you like it .

opague black extremely heavy coffee colored heading . that leaves excellent lacing and keeps a nice collar all the way down to the last gulp .  the mouthfeel has a little bit more carbonation than i would like a brew of this calibre to have , thus the 3.0 .
aromas are lemon citrus and light spicings of coriander and nutmeg , with a toasty character , also . pineapple and mango aromas release as the beer warms .  a tad thin .

a- this one pours out an opaque black as night colored body with a small coffee colored head on top .  mouthfeel is pretty good , but a little on the watery side for a chocolate/dessert beer . with the abv at 6 % and the body a little thinner than other chocolate stouts , one could have a couple of these in one night .
the foamy white heads even offers a nice lacing as it recedes ever so slowly .  m : a little thin in body d : good .
a - deep orange with a thick off white head that good retention and lacing down the glass .  as for the go-down : thin & lightly carbonated , not aggressive but not annoying either & no aftertaste .

whatever anyone says about guinness , i think that it is an impressive looking beer . it poured with a nice two finger head and the foam never left the top . the color is black and slightly hazy .  i wont go through the details but if you are looking for an ipa do not drink this beer . it may sound novel , but black ipa is a retarded name for this , its not an ipa whatsoever . no hop flavor in the taste , not even close . im pissed i paid 4.30 for this . ridiculous .
pours a rich brown color with a large froth of dense , creamy head . retention is good , but lacing is downright gorgeous .  m - medium/light body with little carbonation good with spicy food .
the aroma is sweet and rich , on the softer side as barleywines go , well balanced between caramel malts and woody hops .  very dry with a bitter finish . a little sticky from all the sweetness .

poured into a chimay goblet.. well , the name does n't lie ... this is a pitch black with a creamy but small head ... laces unbelievably though.. this almost has an ris look to it with its perceived thickness.. this has one of the best aromas i 've ever experienced ... it has all of the aspects of a great stout with an added extra of smokiness that reminds me of a nice thick cut bacon ... it 's just wonderful ... it 's loaded with roasted malts and i might even get a little touch of hops here as well.. just magnificent ... very rich roasted flavors here ... loads of dark roasted malts with that smoke that i was getting in the aromas mix wonderfully with a tinge of hops on the finish ( although not much ) ... there 's a thickness to this that belies the export stout style.. i would guess ris or double stout all the way here ... there 's a meatiness here as well that i would assume comes from the smoke.. it 's a nice brew , i know that.. i 'm really digging it ... i 'm very glad i got to enjoy this brew.. it 's loaded with rich dark flavors and the aromas here are ridiculously delicious.. the whole experience was terrific.. very nice export stout.. very drinkable although at 8.5 , it could hurt you quick ...  maybe a little bit of caramel malts to balance out that chocolate . the body is ok - seems quite normal for what you can buy - but i 'd just like it a bit heavier . ) they could increase the body a little , maybe go heavier on the caramel malts and add a few more bittering hops .

a : pours a slightly hazy , but clean , orange-amber color with a large two-finger , rocky , off-white head that very , very slowly settles so a thick , foamy ring that clings to the glass and leaves considerable lacing behind . really a nice looking ipa .  now i understand the meaning of the word `` swill '' . i have an enormous amount of respect for european beers . avoid . trust me .

head clumping is visible and the head retention is well overall . moderate lacing and pretty clear .  the beer really lacks in body . carbonation is great . overall this was a good beer but the body creates a void .

appearance - very dark red , but clear and looks quite impressive when held up to light . 2 fingers of head with very good retention and lacing .  mouthfeel : medium-bodied with moderate carbonation .
pours a nice dark brown/black with a quarter inch head , typical for founders stuff .  mouthfeel is fairly thin but not unpleasant .

the smell was amazing -- probably the highlight of the beer . it got better as the temp increased . overall , it 's a pretty solid novelty beer .  i found the body to be a bit thin carbonation medium to low .

t : bit of a let dowm after this promising smell . orange , citrus , grains and a little hops .  ( m ) smooth , oily , and flat . it 's a solid beer , or a solid base of a beer that could be improved only with a better mouthfeel .

smells of rich dark roast , light coffee , fruity yeast and light alcohol . when cold , all i could taste were roasted flavors , a sharp carbonation , and a woody , slightly smokey hop flavor , maybe chinook .  the huge head tipped me off and my first taste confirmed that this beer was infected . as a homebrewer , i 'm sure to sample every beer i brew before i give it to a friend . a little qc goes a long way .

a-amber with sediment and good frothy head . the color an intense head gives this one high scores .  m : the feel is slightly creamy but on the lighter side of medium bodied . could be a bit thicker here ... d : if you like coffee beers i could see someone drinking good amount of these .

this poured out a rich golden color with a lovely red-orange glow that danced reflective light off my fingertips . a rush of tiny bubbles formed a thick white head that dissipated at an average pace , leaving foamy crystals that clung to the sides of my tulip glass . superb !  the aroma was quite pleasant ... cirtus and floral hops with a light , bready malt . strong citrus hops up front , but it quickly became bitter , finished bitter and left a strong aftertaste . this is the first beer i 've poured out in a long time .

nose was rich with fudgy chocolate , smoke and charcoal .  i found that the beer smelled and tasted rather skunky , unlike most other beers that i had tasted and was deeply disappointed by it . it felt ok in the mouth and looked very nice in its green bottle but was not worth my time .
this ones a nice deep brown color with a big fluffy tan head and pretty amazing lacing .  m : full bodied but way too over-carbonated .

aroma is overwhelming with citrusy peach essence of hop . so sweet and spicy , very cali . i usually sniff for 15-20 seconds but this beer merits much more nasal enjoyment .  wtf did they do to this beer ? this is the first time i tried it since they put in the new brewhouse and i 'm not impressed . this used to be a wonderfully drinkable beer with orange and subtle spice flavors that made it quite refreshing . now its just overloaded with phenolics and all you can taste and smell is cloves . i ca n't get past the phenolic flavors enough to even finish a bottle . just horrible .

smells creamy/milky with rich , almost sweet coffee , chocolate , kaluha , cocoa , and a touch of green hops . absolutely divine . the flavor is roasty with burnt/charred malts , coffee , chocolate , and a medium bitterness .  this beer was skunky ... skunky like a becks . and i couldnt find any other component of this beer redeeming enough to get over that skunkyness . my encounter with this beer started out ok ... it has a pale yellow appearance with a medium amount of head . taste exhibited becks ( or maybe even becks light ) levels of skunkitude , again with a bit of clove chasing after it to apologize . definitely not recommended .
this looked wonderful ! ! !  but i felt the feel was a bit thin .

the body of hop head poured an absolutly beautiful copper-orange color , with a sizable custard head . retention and lacing were both excellent , thanks to a constant supply of carbonation from below .  not sure what they used for malt , but very sugary at first . the hops comes in and stays with you . almost like an ipa with the first snoot full of hops . i suppose they have to keep winning people over cause of the whole inbev deal . king of beers , so i am not surprised .
with a black body to more than live up to the style , kostritzer pours two and one-half fingers of slightly tan head that is quite durable .  m-medium carbonation . medium body , slick .
very creamy look with beautiful lacing .  smooth mouthfeel with a moderate amount of carbonation and just a little watery in the finish .

the nose here is at first reminiscent of a barleywine ( raisiny , sweet ) , then an imperial stout ( chocolatey , roasty ) , and ultimately an outstanding cabernet ( earthy and leathery notes on top of dark fruits and floral perfumes ) . i find this to be an ideal complexity - notable not for its blunt force but for the way it continues to surprise . cigar box certainly comes to mind . barleywine-type sweetness is much more prevalent in this dimension , although it interacts in interesting ways with a darker , roasted quality . the finish is warm in a pleasing way . outstanding beer for slow sipping and contemplation .  body is not as full as i would like , but this is one heck of a tasty beer .

comes out of the tap a rich opaque warm sable with a thick , fine-bubbled , almost guinness-like light tan head that leaves some good lacing .  had this on tap when i was being introduced to the lager style of beer . it 's smell is very specific to the beer and is appealing if you are craving a medium-bodied lager . its has a malty intake and a bit of a spicy , hoppy after taste . it goes down smoothly but the taste tends to stick around and interfere with ordered food . it is very drinkable but as stated , but be careful when drinking this with food .

very nice 3 finger head that was creamy with a great deal of structure . deep orange/amber in color and quite translucent . great lacing and a touch of visible carbonation . this short description is not an indication that it was n't great .  tastes like , yeah , tart blueberries ( probably artificial blueberries ) . just sweet & weird & sweet ... really tough to finish one . much like a cheap , too-tart wine cooler .

surprisingly hoppy aroma for the style with a prominent earthy pine presence as well as hints of citrus and tropical . it smells great just not like a wheat beer . clean , crisp and easy drinking with a slightly dry finish .  less fizzy than anticipated in the mouth .

the appearance is still wonderful , rich , creamy and delightful , although you get less of the wonderful spectacle of the bubbles gently settling on the surface .  mouthfeel/overall : the body is very light , and it has pretty high carbonation .

smell of dark rich chocolate , coffee and molassas , having some dark fruity earthiness to it . taste is again rich as in the above aromas with some roastiness and having alchohol present , but not overwhelming .  m- very light beer , at 3 % alcohol , nice carbonation throughout and thin almost watery .

crystal clear red-orange body , covered by a huge frothy irish linen colored head , rocky top which rose above the rim . very good lacing . a very vague , almost non-existent aroma , some bread baked much earlier in the day .  little lacing . it has an oktoberfest feeling , but not full fledge on the taste . very drinkable . i think i will serve it at my halloween party because of the label and easy drinking style .
a - huge head , really fluffy . beautiful amber color with appealing haziness .  m/d : the mouthfeel was a tad low , as i assume to the three years in a swingtop , but by no means distracting .

s : sour cherries are noticeable before the glass reaches my nose . t : the aroma carries well into the taste as the sour dark cherry hits the palate first and then gives way to the sweetness which tastes more like a jolly rancher than sweet tart .  light-medium bodied with crisp high carb .

) , 2011 scorched crimson brown color ; fairly dark . the head does recede but retention is solid and there is a good bit of lace .  tastes like an aged beer , its very dry and cuvee-like . significant hops.its wierd but it does smell like a barleywine . a bit undewhelming mouthfeel.there was some problem with foam in the taps , and maybe if i had this in the wee hours . still good .

poured into an a-b flute on 1/3/12 deep , slightly cloudy honey-amber color with a two and a half finger head that is intent on having the appearance steal the show . the head is very slow to thin and leaves thick lace along the way . retention is thin by the end , but it does last the whole way and lace remains excellent .  perfect carbonation and ridiculously easy to drink .

the aroma was simply amazing ! i was champing at the bit to drink this . very sweet smelling . reminiscent of belgian candy sugars and granny smith apples . it was n't unpleasant but i did n't expect this from the aroma . overall , an impressive beer .  the beer itself is pretty thick , and mixed with the lingering foamy head , it feels great in the mouth for savoring what taste there actually is .
