upon opening the bottle you receive a pleasant aroma and on pouring the smell is obviously even more intense . the mouthfeel is actually kind of weak and bitter , surprisingly , given the pleasant look and smell of this beer .  the mouthfeel at the start was mildly crisp and finished dry and smooth . the unbalanced flavors knock down the drinkability for me .

this is where this beer truly shines . sweet brown sugar and candied fruits - i thought of cherries and apricot - are met head-on by the alcohol . the result is a rich , warm , somewhat medicinal elixir that was just wonderful to inhale . do n't get me wrong - it 's very nice . it just did n't quite live up to the advance billing . very nice .  no complaints as the the mouthfeel , medium bodied with a pretty sharp carbonation .

s : the best component of this beer , gratifying spices on top of a light roasted malt . d : good smell and its light make for easy drinking , but i would prefer more commanding flavors and spices .  medium mouthfeel .

pours a dark brown as you 'd expect in a chocolate , and the aroma is pure chocolate . unbelieveable aroma . really hoped that the taste would match , but no .  the mouthfeel was decent , medium with adequate carbonation .

the aroma is very nice , a heady mixture of malt , honey and alcohol . unfortunately the flavor does n't come close to fulfilling the promise in the aroma . the body is carbonated with a rather lager-ish character .  i like the feel with some prickly carbonation and moderately light feel and some creaminess from the head .
s - great hoppy but aromatic aroma with a warming malty finish . lovely hops they are using .  the mouthfeel is crisp overall .
a smooth golden color with a nice fluffy white 2 finger head .  mouthfeel is thick and smooth , no watery sensation at all .
very nice sherry character to it with a hint of a woody edge .  m : medium-bodied and creamy ; high carbonation ; mouthfeel is this beer 's strongest attribute , in my opinion .
awesomely complex . taste : chocolate , chocolate malt , coffee , chocolate syrup .  mouthfeel : smooth and medium thick , low carbonation .
aroma is excellent . it 's full of fresh hops , citrus and pine .  nice creamy mouthfeel .
a : beautiful deep dark red , with a foamy , rich head s : unbelievably fragrant of cherries t : this is a sweet cherry beer . yummy .  medium carbonation .

some lacing & no head retention smell ; huge oaky & sherry notes taste : super sweet up front , followed by raisin , vanilla , treacle/honey and tangerine notes . very complex , but a little too sweet for my tastes mf : syruppy , oily , undercarbonated , & slightly out of balance .  light to medium bodied , with a very smooth mouthfeel .
looks great ! great color , small head .  m : creamy and spot-on carbonation .
like the looks of this . full thick head .  m - good mouthfeel , coats a bit like oil but smooth .
smell- nice pungent scent of pine hops amidst lots of powdered sugar .  mouthfeel : medium body , medium carbonation overall : this beer has almost no taste , pity

black color with a solid brown head . head does n't retain for very long , but wonderful lacing follows this brew from start to finish .  but , also an odd smell kind of like salami . this must be some nasty phenol created by the yeast . a bad yeast flavor here and a lot of it . i usually love unibroue brews for that complex yeasty quality but for some reason this one tastes a little off . that lunchmeat aroma and now this bad oily yeasty taste make this beer almost undrinkable . i doubt it considering it 's called edition 2004 , we 're in 2005 , and it 's 10.5 abv .
nose : a pleasant light piny hop aroma . a very inoffensive ipa .  mouthfeel is fine for the style .
amazing nose of peach with a high , frothy , long lasting head with an almost soapy mouthfeel .  the mouthfeel was quite good , though . well carbonated and it felt good going down .
huge sweet and bready malts rise to the nose upon an initial whiff .  this beer feels almost delicate .

s- very large coffee smell . great complexity . t- taste starts with sweet fruits and a little bit of chocolate then is balance excellently by fresh bitter coffee .  the mouthfeel is smooth and oily and the carbonation is alright .
looks great on a goblet . amazing retention and lacing .  it is medium bodied and smooth in the mouth .

s : a very sweet and complex nose here . lots of caramel , toffee , dates , figs , raisins , and wood . t : not quite as impressive as the nose , but still damn good . lots of caramel , bourbon , oak , and apple .  pretty refreshing , not overwhelmed with carbonation .

pours a very lovely rich golden color with a creamy white head that clings to the sides of the glass as you drink .  the palates leads with a thick , malty mouthfeel up front and a sticky , resiny bitterness in the back .
a freind brought this brew over ... a : perfect look for a belgian ale . deep dark ruby color like an iced tea .  m : mouthfeel is crisp , light-medium bodied and pretty dry .

body was cloudy and amber aroma was outstanding . moderate hoppiness and perfume .  still for such a big beer it had a great body , just not sure if i would want more , until it got about 5 years on it .

smell was very enjoyable with lots of wheat , lemon , banana , and hints of honey . thumbs up . t : followed the nose nicely with touches of wheat , lemon and banana that are felt in the tongue as soon as you sip the beer . the good smell and taste made up for the weak appearance .  mouthfeel : soft creaminess , light to medium carbonation , with a medium to full body .

smell : really great smelling chocolate aromas .  pours a cloudy , almost 'chunky ' looking way -- looks a bit similar to an apple cider ( non alcoholic kind ) . caramelly sweet too . vanilla . taste is what kind of throws me - again , both the oak ( taste of whisky barrel ) and smokiness are there . i like both of those favors in my beers , but combined , my jury is still out : like they are competing for my affection . alcohol is quite present too , which seems to go well with the aforementioned whisky oak . a lot going on in this brew .
appearance : a wonderful amber color .  mouthfeel is good and thick , finish is dry with a moderate dose of alcohol present .

the smell is filled with some nice hops with a good bit of sweetness .  aroma : hops . the crystal hops dominate the aroma . the malt is there , but overpowered by hops . but i do n't taste the balance that an esb should have . the hops weigh far more than the malt in this beer . notes : this tasted like a very good ipa , but did not have the balance i was expecting , for an esb . a great beer , but did n't fit the style as well as i would have liked .
beautiful tan head with steady retention .  oily mouthfeel with next to no carbonation . quite thick and heavy , coating every area of the mouth .

2011 bottle poured into a tulip glass . a - an inch of dense cream-colored foam sits atop a beautiful ruby colored ale .  everything about this beer was pretty light - light , crisp malt scent ; light fruity taste ; light body . feel - 4.0/5.0 - refreshing , which was really nice .

appearance was the best characteristic of this one . super fluffy head that lasted a short while , but then died to a thick laceing .  smells sour , big nodes of orange and very tart lemon juice . there 's a bit of a funky hop in there , as well . no real spice of which to speak , nor any hint of wheat . very sour , almost cidery . starts more tart , like lemon juice , moves into a dryer , white wine middle , and ending on a more of a light , semi-sweet orange sour . a unique beer , to say the least . could benefit from a bit of something at the end , but is drinkable enough as it is .

smell is intense . lemon sour acidity , pepper , lots of sweat & musk . sweet florals . earthy funk . it just seems more then a tad empty when compared to what i smelled up front .  mouthfeel is nice & creamy .
this is one of the nicest smelling beers i 've had .  m : fuller side of medium-bodied with moderate carbonation that tickles the tongue and throat . this aspect of the beer is really nice .

great smell good apperance .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied , with a soft prickly creaminess , along with some easy slickness in the body that helps that raw feeling finish go down . just a smidge of alcohol is felt but it is n't overly noticeable .

the pungency of the wheat prevents it from becoming cloying . delish . nice flavours , but some darker fruit character would n't go astray . nice . good stuff . a smorgasbord of confectionery aromas and flavours made to order for a sweet tooth .  m - nice and creamy in the mouth , goes down smooth .
sweet and tart raspberries , this is fun to smell ! very nice .  the mouthfeel of this beer ( outside of taste ) was great . great carbonation , bitter hop aftertaste , medium bodied .

the aroma is a nice blend of peaches , caramelized pecans , wheat , toasted bread , and a hint of bourbon . an interesting and unique dunkel , with an amazing aroma but it 's too sweet to have more than one .  mouthfeel - good smoothness , a medium body on par with the style , crisply carbonated .
a - pours a thick 2 fingers of tan head that sticks around for quite some time .  mouthfeel is quite nice and full .
robust cherry smell that is fantastic . taste is almost all cherry , wheaty malt underneath .  m- felt just about right on not too thick .

it had a great smoky aroma of smoked wood , smoked malts , olives , dark chocolate , roasted coffee beans , and just the slightest touch of caramel at the finish .  m - good carbonation and it finishes clean . good light to medium mouthfeel .
overall , very nice smell . taste is fruity , quite a bit of the banana in the smell comes through in the flavor .  m : easy drinking with medium-body and low-moderate carbonation .

excellent retention . something you could stick your finger in and feel the foams welcoming grasp .  as i drink more my palate adjusts but it does n't ever really get over the off flavors m - pretty thick , not too carbonated , nice mouth coating qualities d - burnt coffee does not go down very well , plust the thickness of the beer limits my ability to quaff this completely i like coffee , i like stouts , and i like a lot of coffee stouts ( new glarus and founders breakfast stout for instance ) .
malt and hop scents are virtually non-existent . very aromatic . t : starts off with a quick dose of pumpkin flesh .  m : moderate carbonation with a decently viscous mouthfeel .

sweet and very appealing like a hopslam . t - taste is a bit different than the smell and reminds me of pliny the younger . very good . o - i think this is a very fine dipa .  finish is very grainy and `` off '' lol mouthfeel : full-medium , creamy body with moderate carbonation .

s - very lovely . a nice mix of sweet citrus fruits and hops . nice .  mouth feel is more medium bodied than the wheats i 'm used to , a nice change and the full blast carbonation leaves one a happy advocate overall it is lacking smell , good in flavor , great in feel .

one of the best aromas to come around in a while for me . very decadent chocolate here ... sweet , silky ... you can really smell the cocoa nibs here . a slight hint of hop bitterness as well but this is a very chocolatey aroma . the body is a bit light , and the taste is certainly full of chocolate , but is more of a mix between a sweeter chocolate and a bitter , roasted chocolate . this marriage keeps it from becoming cloying or just being too bitter . what was a pretty sweet and rich beer on the nose was n't quite so on the tongue .  m : lots of carbonation , but a pretty smooth medium body nonetheless .
smell : smells like a nice rich coffee from sbux with tons of caramel added .  mouthfeel : medium body with smooth carbonation and a dry finish .

the beer has the unique feature for this style by including a spiced-raisin aroma although it is mild . no hops contribution to the scent .  m : creamy to a crisp finish with a good carbonation throughout .

this beer has the most incredible smell in the world . '' the big wafts of vanilla , caramel , and butterscotch fill the nose and is absolutely delectable . i could enjoy the aroma of this beer for hours . one bomber was enough for me , and i was pleasantly surprised .  i did n't want to buy this because i do n't trust twisted pine to sell me a good beer . since i am a sucker and i love hoppy beers i bought it anyway . the smell was very hoppy citrus , pine and something off i could n't place until i tasted it , butter . this beer was quite disappointing and i poured out the remaining 13 or so ounces after i finished my first glass .
served in a tulip corsendonk glass . a - beautiful golden with a nice airy white head .  fine mouthfeel , nothing objectionable , but it 's not a stand-out lager either .

i was much more impressed by the pour and visual of this beer than by taste or drinkability . nice puffy styrofoam cloud of a head .  mouthfeel -- nice , an initial carbonate bite followed by a foamy smoothness . , molasses , pepper/spice .

sweet and sugary , but delicious and unique . alcohol is absolutely brutal on this bitch as the heat slaps you in the face with the force of 10,000 fighting japanese midget minnow farmers .  mouthfeel - some creamy smoothnes , well-carbonated .

aroma is sweet delicious malt bomb extravaganza . dark fruits , plenty of sweet caramel laced with burnt sugars , no heat at all , and a small amount of oaty malted milk ball aroma . a+ aroma for sure . this is one amazing beer , it woo'ed the hell out of me .  lighter body and a nice lively carbonation .

nose is quite complex with some really nice notes of oak , vanilla , chocolate , roasted malt , and some light coffee . the taste does n't mix these together quite as well , but is still tasty . great feel coming from all different directions and quite drinkable for the big beer that it is .  mouthfeel is nice and light , with adequate carbonation for the style .
this is a great looking beer , more black than brown and , when held up to the light , a beautiful red highlight appears .  m : smooth and round .

4.5 s : bourbon and maple come through most prominently . oak and vanilla next . as i sort of expected , most of the wheat gets lost in the previously mentioned powers . i say the bourbon level is just right . 3.0 t : again , maple and bourbon dominate only this time it may be too forceful .  creamy mouthfeel with the addition of oatmeal in the mix .

this brew pours with a deep amber body topped by a medium thick head with lots of lacing .  mouthfeel is medium bodied and crisp . good carbonation , but the overall trainwreck of flavor in the brew makes this one hard to take down .
a - pours an inky black with chocolate brown head , very nice looking beer .  mouthfeel is medium , well carbed , nice on all fronts but where it needs to be . big failure , in my opinion .

poured into a chalice a- huge huge huge frothy merangue like , sand colored head rises way above the rim of the glass . it has incredible stay with incredible lacing . the beer is a murky and clouded dark brown/umber .  the body is nice and thick , with a flavorful malt profile : sweet medium caramel malts with a bit of roast character . hops , by the way , are almost nonexistent , which would n't be bad if not for the oxidation , which makes the faint floral flavor seem dull . overall not bad , but has the same type of oxidized or maybe just oversparged flavor common to other corporate breweries like gordon-biersch .

poured into my aventinus glass . a very light orange color with a massive head , great retention with about a half inch of foam maintaining throughout the coarse of the beer , and some lacing .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and watery with almost no carbonation .

one and a half fingers of super creamy off-white head . excellent retention and lots of lacing . awesome !  medium body , almost non existent carbonation , sweet sticky syrupy mouthfeel . i think the lack of carbonation ruins the mouthfeel and makes this taste and smell overly sweet .
huge tan head after a normal pour , looks very nice .  overall , feels unbalanced , too much carbonation and a little too dull .

appearance : very , very deep clear gold , head on this one is one for the ages , really spectacular . huge , dense , pure white and a bit slick ; looks a bit like whipped egg whites .  flavor is rather plain , roasty , sweet , a bit of coffee and coco , the hops seem to be hiding somewhere , i detect little to none , little carbonation , short finish , with a bit of dark bread , and rasins , very thin body.drinkable but not very memoriable .

a - pours a dark , cloudy copper with an amazing two finger light brown head . the head on this beer was huge and crated with never ending retention and thick , gooey lacing .  m : this was the most dissapointing . aside from the lingering dry finish this was a very thin porter .

poured from a 11.6oz brown bottle with a white cap marked `` bottl 2006* 12 % '' into a tulip glass . easily one of the longest lasting , largest frothy heads of foam i have ever seen on any beer . appearance is a rusty yellowish orange color , cloudy and semi-translucent .  mouthfeel was poor .

pours an opaque black with a creamy tan head that retains well and laces the glass .  body is depressingly light . very nonexistent in the finish . taking bigger an bigger sips just to capture some flavor . smooth , but light . bitterness in the aftertaste follows a big gulp .

pours a coal black beer with a good reddish brown head .  the mouthfeel is disappointing with absolutely no carbonation and mild flavors lingering around . overall , i could have possibly gotten a flat beer but this beer had potential ( when carbonated ) but it didnt come through in my bottle .
the nose is impressive . easily the most enjoyable part of drinking this beer .  mouth is thin and watery . too simple and too one dimensional and thin .
on draft , served in a tulip glass . a : pours very dark , almost pitch black with a nice tan head .  mouthfeel is thin for the style .
pours a pitch black , with a solid 3/4 inch head that has serious staying power .  2.5 m very light , i am not impressed . it is very close to water in feel .

amazing lacing & head retention , really pretty to look at s : hints of choclate & some roasted malt as it warms t : rich choclate up front , then a little grainyness & some bitter choclate .  the mouthfeel is syrupy and shows none of the carbonation that the pour hinted at .
a- gorgeous . deep gold with hints of orange .  aside from that , the taste , like the smell , is unremarkable mouthfeel is borderline watery .
s - beautiful dark malt and deep cherry aroma .  the mouhfeel is weak , watery , thin .

pours a huge head with crazy retention that wo n't leave the glass .  taste is weak , almost watery , has to be drank ice cold or has a taste like vomit . bottom line is compared to other cheap beers pbr excels in taste , quality , and conveniently the price , 7 bucks a 12 pack .

pours a beautiful red-brown with ruby glints , off-white head is large and thick .  smells basically like apple juice . watery . also , the carbonation that was so present during the pour now seems dulled . for all its faults , in the end rogue makes a malt liquor that achieves what you usually want out of the style .
the color is pitch black . head is large , creamy , and dark tan .  m - thin , watery , overly carbonated .

a- pale translucent body with thick white head . great head retention . leaves behind plenty of lacing .  mf : it 's medium-bodied at best despite the label 's claims of `` full bodied . '' speaking of which , it has a soda watery type carbonation , not at all the `` luxuriously smooth '' of the label . i have to say that they could get the mouthfeel under control ( i 'd imagine this is less of an issue on tap ) , it would be hands-down my favorite irish stout .
a : the pour is a deep dark brown , essentially black , with a fluffy tan head .  mouthfeel is equally watery .

poured into a stemmed tulip : finger of foamy , smooth , beige head over a russet body with some nice , maroon highlights . visibly nucleation , lots of tiny bubbles . leaves some nice bars of lacing .  very thin , and barely any head .
usual alesmith great appearance .  it 's highly carbonated , and extremely astringent .

s : fragrant molasses , baked dark bread , brown sugar , sweet , loving the nose . t : baked brown bread again , baker 's chocolate with a fair amount of roast . d : great nose , solid taste , in the end a nice effort , it needs more sweetness to be really good , it definitely has potential .  mouthfeel : terrible . after drinking half of this bomber , my mouth is completely numb and i am starting to feel comatose .

aroma is a terrific perfumey blend of spruce and crushed flowers and an underlying malt sweetness . very inviting . soft malt up front is washed away too quickly by the surprisingly watery mouthfeel .  mouthfeel is thin and weak .
big fluffy cap of beige foam makes a nice stand and keeps itself steady for a good while before dismantling itself to a heavy skim and lots of thick lacing .  mouthfeel : absolutely no carbonation .
really lovely to look at .  the mouthfeel was thin and not terribly hoppy on the palate .

appearance - crystal clear gold body with a huge white head ( took three goblets to pour this ) . gorgeous .  mouthfeel : the carbonation is very high , way too high , for a milk stout . the body is thin . drinkability : just an ok beer , the mouthfeel also hurts the drinkability .

a- clear auburn and orange , massive three finger fluffy/foamy white head , excellent retent s- hops , oily and leafy , citrus and caramel t- just as hoppy as it smells , hop flavored alcoholic heat at finish , grape skin , grapefruit , caramel , butterscotch , fruit like characters , hop oils m- medium body , lots of alcoholic heat , dry after , smooth , hops abuse palate much d- lots of interesting things happening here , but i think the alcohol presence was out of control , not to mention this might as just be hop juice .  m - thin , a little harsh and a bit drying .
the nitro definately makes this beer look great . otherwise , it 's a pretty average ale .  mouthfeel is excedingly thin and watery .
bottle : poured a bright golden yellow with a super huge pure white foamy head with great retention and super good lacing .  really thin for an imperial stout .

perfect head retention and plenty of lacing left behind in the glass .  tastes first of caramel , then of grain , and finally thin , fizzy bitterness . for all its color , finishes bone dry with a tragically meager mouthfeel .

looks fantastic and i am very impressed with the head retention .  mouthfeel is watery . this style needs more body - the maltiness is there , but there is very little roasted character & not enough creaminess .
great retention and lacing !  maybe a little dusty , but i probably dislike the low carbonation & tackiness more . my tongue feels like i just drank a pot of black tea .

s : coffee ice cream cones ? like a joy ice cream cone , and a mild coffee . only beer yet to give me that . m : creamy , creamy and creamy . imperial anyone ? t : i 'll start with a heavy dark chocolate to start .  the mouthfeel was then utterly unimpressive . overall , the drink looks good but the taste and feel are way too thin and watery .

poured from a 12oz bottle into a perfect pint glass . the bubbles slowly dissipated down to a 1/4 '' layer that left behind tons and tons of lace . this one fine looking offering ... the nose is solid ... piney hops with an earthy aroma mix with a sweet , bready backbone ... seems like this one will have some balance .  very pale straw yellow color , hazy but filtered look no aroma noted water like very light bodied taste and looks like water ... . however better than most would give credit to seeing how its bud .

pours a dark brown black with a large creamy brown head that retains well and laces the glass .  with a near-white head , very little in the way of roasted quality in the nose or taste , and a very thin body , this reminds me of a weak porter with a slight coffee aroma .

pours a massive , incredibly thick , dense and chunky white head that is long lasting .  palate scraping astringency . the lack of carbonation particularly makes me wonder if i should have given this more time in the cellar to condition .
pours a dark black color with a thin brown head .  the carbonation and the bitterness overpower the toasty flavors .

during the pour , this raspberry lambic style has a fantastic bouquet of raspberries and frothy pink head .  the lack of body really disappointed me . while surprisingly drinkable , this beer needs to be heavier to match the taste , so more body and more alcohol are needed .

a nearly perfect pour . smells and tastes of the usual hefe spicy , peppery yeast , clove and banana , with a touch of citrus ( maybe lemon ) sourness .  very light bodied , an ok mouthfeel.. just way too watery and thin , not much for taste , just some lemon zest on the after taste .

pours a cloudy , very dark golden orange/chestnut mahogany brown color with dark golden orange hues when held to a light source and a two finger frothy , pillowy yellowish beige head . excellent retention , only slowly fading into a lasting cap . sporadic chunks of soapy lacing left behind .  on top of that , the beer tasted a bit flat and felt thin .
great aroma , hope there is more of this in the palate . pretty decent .  the feel is fizzy and watery thin .
one finger large off white that shows great retention .  as many others have said , i 'm not liking the extra carbonation .
brilliantly clear light goldenrod , forming a large meringue-like rocky white head with excellent retention and gorgeous lacing .  it is entirely too thin for a stout .

now that that is out of the way , this is the first time i am reviewing one of there beers a : rich amber color , nice and clear , with a thick foamy white head about half an inch thick that retains well . plenty of carbonation rises from the bottom of the glass as well .  mouthfeel was pretty watery and went down quickly .

this beer sure looks good , but it sure aint of me . stone ris pours an oily thick pitch black witha huge brown head . as the head disapates , it leave so great lacing .  thin to medium mouthfeel with zero carbonation -- lifeless .

this beer is a handsome black with a pillowy light tan head that has great retention and lacing .  the mouthfeel is quite disappointing due to carbonation that is much too high for a stout and a body which is not thick or creamy .

pours nicely to an amber color with good head .  smell is not overwealming , but seems sweet with hints of yeast and hop . watery , yeasty , sweet ... more corn than i thought there would be ... taste relatively one-dimensional , unfortunately . fairly drinkable though ... inoffensive and cheap ...

batch 9359 packaged 9/17/09 a : pours an opaque black with a tight dark brown head which leaves much lacing on the walls of the glass as it fades to a thin layer .  in body and taste , this is so akin to water that i find it very drinkable .
a-bronze and brilliantly clear . huge eggshell head .  feel : active , assaulting carbonation and a light , watery body .

pores black with a thick tan foamy head about 2in .  it actually smells more like a belgian dubbel . it does n't have much complexity and it drinks very watery . this is by far the thinnest quad i 've ever come across .
great retention and lacing . looks fantastic .  although the mouthfeel is thin for a stout , the flavor is pretty good .
a- pours a very hazy yellow-orange with a thick white head that lasts a long time and leaves lots of lacing . exactly what this style should look like .  carbonation is too high .

this beer pours really dark , with a nice tight off white head . there is good lacing throughout .  very little mouthfeel , this beer is meant to be drank ice cold as implied with the cold indicator on the can unlike most beers that i drink .
nice retention and awesome patches of lacing .  very thin , and watery . lower carbonation .

this is a seriously complex nose , just tons going on ... fruits , mainly peach , some pineapple ? certainly lemon , white grape , sure , some white pepper , dry lemon rind , citrus , gosh ... it goes on and on and on ... certainly some funk and wildness , dry white wine ... yeah , this is hard to pin down and extremely academic , enjoyable , and all around good . t. follows , lots of dry white wine , peachy , semi-sweet , spicy , earthy , some tire , champagne , peach again , no real hop , dry , wild , funky , lemon-citric , seriously interesting , challenging , to be sure , but i am digging it . fun to try and get your palate around . d. not really , this is something to share and comment on , and take your time with .  color very pale green or lemon odor , which suggests more concentrated lemon juice only freshly cut lemon slices , but preserving a small mouth , perhaps a bit too much . the lager that is the basis must be extremely low in taste because the body is still very watery , just a few hints of lemon , no sugar but not bitter unfortunately .
pours a deep chestnut with a thick white head which dissipates pretty quickly but leaves some nice lacing .  mouthfeel was stingy and watery .

smell is wonderfully floral and hoppy . not floral or hoppy , but more like perfumy .  the mouthfeel on this one fluctuates but it has one of the worst finishes i can recall in a beer . the thin body and soda-like carbonation ( and some wheaty texture ) save this some , but the finish is just harsh . artificial flavor , sticks to the teeth , chewing on cardboard , something is wrong here finish to the mouthfeel .

the fluid is dark caramelly clear with a huge three finger head of off white , which eventually receded to a half finger width with lacing still attached to the glass .  m : water thin , light side of champagne-like carbonation .

a - this is a beautiful looking beer .  its rather thin in the mouth , and doesnt ready leave me wanting more drinkabilty - with its high alcohol , and bitter mocha overload , this beer doesnt do it for me .
this beer has a very nice apearance , cloudy straw yellow in color with wispy white swirls on the surface .  feel is thin , dribbly and loose .

that little widget in the can sure does the trick : a majestic light tan head formed in my pint glass atop a layer of mesmerizing , cascading bubbles and a dark brown body .  mouthfeel is painfully carbonated . light bodied , way way to much carbonation .
appearance : good frothing and great head retention , the pale amber hue shows an active carbonation and a brilliant clarity .  it was very thin bodied as well .

the smell was fantastic ! a hop bomb . nice hop finish lingered on my tongue . i 'm anxious to try the imperial version of this brew .  the palate is not unpleasant , with plenty of that molasses , clove , and dried fruit and some decent maltiness , but this beer is very light in body ( hence my unusually low `` mouthfeel '' score - i rarely dock or add points here unless there is significant deviation from stylistic expectations ) .

this beer had a beautiful pour into a tulip glass . very dark and rich , with a dark roasted tan head that was very thick and continually rebuilt itself every time i swirled the glass .  very thin feel , little oily .
) this brew pours a wonderful brown color .  m : thin , watery , light-bodied , not something you 'd expect with the smell .

insane head retention & lacing s : resiny pine & tangerine , doughyness t : leafy hops , apricot , piney hops & orchard fruit up front .  the mouthfeel needs work . it is n't creamy at all , it is just really watery and lacking carbonation .

outstanding retention and lace , strong carbonation . looks beautiful in the glass and the lace is breathtaking , but the flavor just falls short of expectations .  it 's low in carbonation and a little thin and watery , which is a real shame .

poured a solid black , even when i held my led flashlight up behind it , with about an inch of thick , sturdy light brown head that had great retention and moderate lacing .  for some reason i do n't taste the citrus like everyone else does ... m - thin and flat . propagates through the mouth pretty easily though .
pours a clear yellow with tons of head and lots of lacing . not typically a fan of the pale yellow look , but this one had an amazing head and great retention .  carbonation is much too high .

poured into a founders tumbler the beer looks beautiful . hazy brownish orange body with a beautiful bubbly head that recedes to a sticky big bubble film that does not go away . i just love this .  for a russian imperial this is even for 9.7 incredibly weak and watery it 's the first thing i notice . the mouthfeel on this is not good , it 's even weaker than most american stouts i 've had .
impressive retention , plenty of lacing .  very light in body with a slick mouthfeel at first that becomes almost slimy .
pours a slightly hazy reddish golden with a big pillowy white head that retains well and laces the glass .  m : watery , very light-bodied , body of a light lager .
wow , what a good looking beer . dark dark , dark body and small light brown head ontop .  mouthfeel was light in body and watery in texture with a fizzy carbonation .

it looks good , always being ( in my experience ) in a nitro can or on nitro tap . it has an almost black body with an even , medium , creamy light tan head that lasts a long time .  the mouth feel is very thin for a stout this big and has almost no sweetness .
the beer i poured into my goblet has a creamy merengue head , and itself is a rich , effervescent amber . almost like a river-worn globe of amber .  fizzy carbonation and no body .
beautiful in it 's appearance , and a welcoming texture on the tongue .  very watery . the mouthfeel was thin and watery as well .

nbd ... popped then poured into a small tulip glass . lots of foam at first , about 1/3-2/3 foam vs. liquid . the liquid itself was completely black , with no other discernible hues evident . the aforementioned topping was a mousse-like meringue of creamy , richly-colored tan bubbles which sits at about 1 '' and holding . first whiffs of this offering bring lots and lots of bourbon !  the body is very thin and watery and the carbonation level is medium low which does not compliment this beer at all .
thick dense white head with great retention .  fizzy ... gross . m- watery , thin , minimal carbonation , and nothing lingering .
a - black as night with a thick frothy brown head . fades slowly leaving a thin solid layer of foam on the beer with excellent lacing .  the body is a bit thin and feels too bubbly .

the appearance is beautiful . a bit darker than i 'd expect a golden ale to be , but it looked great .  s. nonexistent . m. also nonexistent . just plain and unoffensive . light beer on amber side ? nothing to brag about but goes down like water . above average in it 's class .

pours a nice deep brown murky color , with some red note showing thru , nice rich belgian look to it . head is rich nice fluffy tan that last and lasts finally falls to ringed scum that laces all the way down .  it seemed to have very high carbonation .

classic pride look - inviting transparent brown body with a reasonably large head , albeit casked up suds . leaves superb lace on the glass . awesome .  i do n't taste any pecan ... m : thin . not to impressive in this dept o : do i love it ?

pours an effervescent honey color with3+ fingers of cream colored head . insane lacing & head retention s : grapefruit & lemon , fades a bit as this warms t : follows the nose , plus pineyness , slight breadyness & a touch of leafy hops & dryness hiding behind a ton of grapefruit up front .  the sweetness died out in the taste , however , which was flat and slightly watered-down . a weird bitterness gave an unpleasant mouthfeel but still not difficult to drink .

oured into my tulip ... rich active head rises fast and descends slowly ( very opposite of cycling ... ! ) ... sticky , frothy umber head laces thick and intricately , like some kind of rorschachian frieze ... color is a lovely rye whiskey burnt orange . i think the mouthfeel ( too much carbonation ) is what keeps this from being stellar .  mouthfeel is too thin for me .
poured into a chimay goblet and it looks beautiful . nice size head with a nice golden clear look to it .  mouthfeel is awfully watery , though not completely distasteful .

s : best nose on a dipa i 've ever experienced . the alcohol is actually a complement to the hop aroma , however . this is one of those `` i wish this was an air freshener '' aromas . t & m : flavor is interesting -- some herbal and grassy hops , some notes of citrus , and a good smattering of pine . it does n't seem to be as balanced as stone ipa , but it 's still pretty tasty . the mouthfeel is very nice -- a sticky , full , and lasting feel with a long finish .  medium bodied , but watery .

s - grassy yeast , bread with some honey notes , earthy grains , green apples , with some spiciness as well . t - malty followed by a spicy citrus .  still has some things that i 'd consider defects that define budweiser 's trademarks ; it 's got plenty of personality but not enough charm . overall seltzer water vibe , which shoots beer right up your nose like soda pop . do n't pass it up if you 're at the brewery , simply because it 's not too shabby when it 's this fresh .

reviewed 12/30/2009 ( bottle ) : pours a very dark almost black color body , ca n't see through at all . big light tan color head , somewhat lasting .  the mouthfeel is thin , with excessive carbonation that gives it a slight harsh feeling on the tongue .

expiration date april 2008 , sampled january 2004 pours a beautiful ruby color . it is vry highly carbonated , which creates a thick creamy light brown-tan head .  ( m ) thin mouthfeel with some bitterness loosely gripping at the tongue , barely holding on .
pours dark amber-brown with moderate clarity and a nice and thick light tan head .  the mouthfeel was a bit thin and watery .

my first 5 for appearance , and it 's well deserved .  m : despite its creamy appearance , the head feels thin on the palate . the brew itself is thin and watery , especially as it warms . the carbonation barely registers .

poured lighter than i was expecting for whatever reason - i somehow put strong and dark together . a shimmering gold , with a great and sticky foam head . looks wonderful .  taste : decidedly like its nose , only more so ; large notes of bittersweet chocolate and espresso rule the roost , here ; not nearly as sweet as you might imagine ; total lack of carbonation left the impression of a somewhat light , thin mouthfeel .

the beer pours a bright , clear , pale straw yellow with a full inch of dense head . good lacing - by the time i finished i had delicate remnants of head all the way down the glass . carbonation is very energetic . this is exactly how a pilsner should look .  mouthfeel was very watery and not smooth in the slightest .

2008 vintage a- almost stout-like in appearance , no head , fizzy swirl of carb in the middle of a color-devoid structure ... s-vanilla , cherry , oak , intense , strong , amazing smells ... .omg ... .there is n't a single hint of sour beer behind this nose . simply smooth vanilla and cherry ... awesome ... .ca n't remember a better nose on a sour ... . t- starts off smooth , nothing much going on *served at 39 degrees f.* then spice , phenols , tartness , tanginess , oh man ... this is great ... . m- solid brick of a mouthfeel , with a few glimmers of carbonation ... nothing exceptionally nasty about the 'brick ' that i speak of , but it is different ... .all together a different beer but for mouthfeel , i 'd expect something flat to taste like this , but in all it provides the right amount of carbonation ! duchesse on crack ...  m : very overly carbonated to the point where it was difficult to drink early on , mild acidity , medium-bodied .
great looking pour for a white ale .  3.0 m thin .

22 oz bomber served in a tradional english pint glass this beer poured a cloudy medium to light brown , with decent 1 inch dense head that left moderate to heavy lacing .  way too carbonated here , which hurts the mouthfeel quite a bit .

a - this beer pours black in color . this is a beautiful looking beer .  pretty nice . the body is as thin as water . that leads to a very drinkable beer , actually , since it goes down ... well , like water .
it pours with a clear amber body topped by a medium thick off white head with a good amount of lacing left on the glass .  feel of almost flat carbonated water .

when you smell this beer , you know this is a big one . lots of power and lots of liquor , much like rum with some fruity notes to me . it felt like port or a fortified wine in my mouth and the taste was rather like a really , really nice rum .  m- thin highly carbonated .

i havent seen a head that tall in awhile.pcb 's cabot street wheat poured a thick frothy solid white head that lingered and left a lace around my whole glass.it smelled of bananas with a citrus twist.the color was a cloudy light yellow.it yielded a banana wheaty taste with a touch of sour lemon at the finish.it leaves a dry feeling in the mouth with virtually no aftertaste.a very good light beer for a hot summer day !  the mouthfeel is very thin .
rich reddish brown colour with a creamy beige cap .  the body is light and really deters the taste .

12 oz bottle poured into a dfh tulip . a- literally my favorite color of beer- deep reddish-copper . solid 1+ inch head that laces well .  the herbal hops will become medicinal with traces of alluminum and will become a bit less appealing as it goes from a zippy feel to rather stagnent . a flat and bitter hop flavor is the finish .

this is , not too surprisingly amber , poured with a nice fluffy head and some lacing , would be perfect , except that the head did n't retain too long .  the presence of tannin explains how , while quite watery , satan red is also quite drying .

a=a nice , beautiful dark amber-brown , with decent-sized creamy head , that leaves noticeable but faint lacing . nice , very nice .  the finish is lightly sweet rather than crisp , and the mouthfeel , which started out thin , ends on a watery , undercarbonated note . zywiec is an average epl , making it a below average beer in general .
pours to a beautiful deep dark brown body with a hint of ruby red when held to light . hosts a decent 1 and a half inch rich tan head , leaving some lace as it fades .  thin and watery .

unusual , overwhelming and lovely aroma of port wine , raisins and dried figs , hints of barnyard . i understand that some people find it cloying , but with a beer this rich in aroma and flavour , i accept the sweetness .  alcohol is very well masked for a 6.5 % way too much carbonation for my liking .
pours with a vast amount of co2 . produces a beautiful light tan head that sticks around forever . the body is dark amner in color .  the mouthfeel is pretty thin and watery .

as it recedes , it forms beautiful beige rocky formations . the liquid is very dark , nearly stout-like where light will not pass .  mouthfeel was light in body and watery in texture with a flat carbonation .
this one pours a hazy yellowish orange with a white head that just will not go away . looks great overall .  i thought that the mouthfeel was kind of watered down ... it needed more `` oommff '' .

a - a nice looking beer with a dark brown color reminiscent of a good black coffee or coke . head was a good two fingered tan froth , that retained quite well .  mouthfeel sucks . the viscosity is where it should be , which is the only reason this gets anything above a 1 for mouthfeel . low carbonation is acceptable in a beer like this , but no carbonation is inexcusable . drinkability is ok , but the alcohol heat definitely shows up , and the poor mouthfeel does not help either . alot of promise in this one though , would be quite tasty if it was carbonated , and not quite so hot .

it has a massive creamy bone colored head , very large and good retention for a cask ale . decent lace trails stick to the glass .  flavor : then , i drank some & everything went downhill . it was watery & disappointing .

the beer looks great . there 's a great cascade look while the bubbles settle , and once they do the head is a solid milky white about 2 fingers deep .  tastes like someone put artificial flavoring in carbonated water .

appearance : a big , rocky , dirty white head of both large and small bubbles . loads of lacing .  the flavor was spicy and malty and the mouthfeel was tingly along with a burning sensation as it is swallowed .

this is a phenomenal aroma i ca n't get enough of ! t - sharp rye comes out in the flavor much more so than the aroma lets on . it actually overwhelms most everything else . d - very good take on the saison style that 's completely unique .  mouthfeel was very light bodied and again , watery .

pours into a pint glass a translucent straw yellow with a billowing white head and and amazing lacing that last throughout the drink .  m- this is precisely the opposite mouthfeel that i want . it feels like it wants to be sweet and sticky , but it really just falls watery on the tongue .

appearance- beautiful honey-tan-golden creamy pour with a nice 3/4 inch fat solid head . lacing is a solid sheet of white down the entire glass .  overall feel was very thin , not impressive and not terribly satisfying .
overwhelmingly the finest ipa i 've ever sniffed . perfect . m - very good . nice carbonation and appropriate chewiness without being syrupy .  body is pretty watery .
black with a glorious creamy beige head with great retention and lacing .  m - crisp start but the finish ends up being very watery .
fantastic looking beer .  taste is that of a standard belgian wit , but the body was off-puttingly thin . it was watered down , far too light for my tastes of wit beers .

poured a translucent mustard/straw yellow with a huge , rocky , white head that faded into clumps of white froth . beautiful lacing .  no attempt whatsoever to hide the alcohol and the addition of the heavy acidic espresso taste and a watery mouthfeel make this hard to down .
pours black as night with a brown head . definitely looks the part of a big ris .  empty , chalky mouthfeel , not much going on here .
huge bubbly head .  good lacing down the glass s : coffee , sweet bready malts t : coffee , slight harsh maltiness also slight hint of chocolate m : light very thin bodied beer .

pours a cloudy medium orange amber with a nice 2 finger white head that very slowly melts to a craggy , very sticky white lacing .  better than expected , but as someone who despises ab products + light beer i was n't expecting much trouble is , within the same can it tasted like lemonade in some sips , water in others . giving it a 4 on drinkability because it 's light , so one could drink a lot of these if they chose to .

at first is it a bit sour and funky , but then takes on some earthy hop characteristics . the nose is really complex and interesting , but that does n't translate flavorwise as this tastes much more straightforward .  the palate is way too thin for a stout .

a : deep brown with a nice fluffy tan head . 2-fingers to start , slowly receding . perfect .  2.5 m thin , with only the grain tastes and the slightest stickiness keeping it from being water itself .

pours a hazy translucent straw color into a standard snifter . a thick fluffy white head tops this one off . tiny amounts of frothy lacing are left behind .  this is a drinkable brew that definatly packs a punch , but it 's kind of one dimensional and thin .

pours a deep , rich plummy color topped by a lively head of sloppy , sticky looking foam . this has a very healthy head that sticks around and laces majestically .  the mouthfeel is confusing as it feels too thin for the amount of sweetness on the taste buds .
like most nitro beers , this one looks great . cascading bubbles leads to 1 inch white thick white head that lasts and lasts .  the mouthfeel is astringent .

caged and corked 75cl bottle ; poured with an immense head of tight foam and a beautiful tornadic swirl of yeast-inspired carbonation .  skimpy in body , vapidly dextrinous and approaching watery in mouthfeel .

pours to a bright copper color with thick white head that lingers throughout , and slowly diminishes to a white foam cap with excellent lacing .  appearance : golden with extremely high head with low head retention smell : sublte hop aroma , taste : light and refreshing , herbal with some decent hop flavor mouthfeel : light bodied , way too much carbonation , jeez ... drinkability : great flavor belgian pale but its overcarbonated .

pours a hazy amber color with a large head that has excellant retention . heavy lacing is left on the glass .  m - too thinned out , would guess this is medium bodied but seems like they cut this one with a little bit of water or something .
pours a beautiful pale orange with a large and persistant head .  seemed flat and had a flat taste .

aroma smacks you . good and hard . hops and oak would be an obvious statement . my notes indicate an amazing floral and woody perfume aroma . initial flavor is upfront pine and sweetness .  m - way too much carbonation for my taste .
body was black as night with a tan head .  m - light bodied , very thin feeling , and very little carbonation o - not too impressed with this beer .

pours a deep brown color with a thick , brown head into my glass . great presentation here .  mouthfeel is indeed excessively thin , leaving a slight tingle of carbonation , but otherwise going down like iced water .
pours a beautiful deep red ( more red than amber ) with two fingers of soft light brown head . leaves a ton of lacing behind .  the mouthfeel was flat and very dissapointing .

color was a hazy golden color with a tightly tiny bubbled heading that left great lacing and a nice white covering until the very end . as it leaves incredible lacing and a lovely looking heading all the way down to the last sip .  taste is rich and sweet , slightly nutty , but this beer really sufferes from it 's thin and watery mouthfeel .

appearance/pour : nice dark amber with a surprising stream of carbonation rising from the glass bottom etch . head which dissapates to a nice ring with small foamy clusters . thick lacing and a dense sound while pouring- sounds thick .  chocolately , dark . dry chalky taste , sweet . some warming . watery porter-like .

it produced a nice , soapy , white head at about 2-fingers . decent retention that left some seriously clumpy lacing behind . this is a vibrant and inviting looking beer .  mf- watery and too light bodied for a red ale . mouthfeel lacking .
bottle : poured a clear light amber color bock with a large frothy off-white head with great retention and some very good lacing .  m - flat , uninteresting , a little oily .
a - murky apple juice with and incredible pillow head ... slow to leave , chunky lace left .  m - extremely carbonated .
appearance : nice maple syrup/caramel bronze , it matched really well with the polished bronze colored bar where i was sitting .  the mouthfeel was flat leaving a watery feel in the mouth .
poured nice gold color with a generous stiff white head .  far too thin and light for a bock . carbonation was assertive , but the body just felt thin and watery .

a : black with a huge tan head , great retention & lace .  starts with fruit taste , looses interest with a thin mouthfeel and water middle although helped by a supporting co2 texture and some tartness ( carbondated water ) ending with lactic acid and dry pucker on the back of the tongue and esophagus .

this alt looked fantastic ! has a rich , deep , clear chestnut color , with a very fine light tan head topping off at about 1 '' . the head dissipates at a very slow rate , and leaves top-shelf lacing .  flavor is of arange , and body is highly carbonated . prickly mouthfeel , and a bit boring overall

pours hazy copper amber color with a very nice dense 2 finger off white head with fantastic retention , that reduces to a thick lacing cap that lasts till the end of the glass . some fairly nice glass lacing is present around the entire glass .  too thin .
dugana pours beautifully for a 2.5 finger thick off white head , with great retention .  md - thin and not much of a body to it .

when i went to smell the aromas , i was very impressed with the assumed banana and clove . they were very prominent and defined ... i couldnt wait to taste ( damn it has a strong aroma that belies its appearance .  biggest disappointment was the mouthfeel which lacked any crispness/carbonation at all ; practically flat and way too light .

pours a pretty deep black with dark tan head that clings to the glass . looking quite appealing .  smell- sweet malt and grains ( sunflower seeds and barley ) taste- watery with a touch of malt acidic hops . mouthfeel- acidic and bitter .

bottle : poured a clear deep back color stout with large light brown foamy head with good retention and some lacing .  high carbonation and a continental hop aroma mixed with corn . light , watery body with a vegtable-grainy taste . dry , crisp finish . strictly unsatisfying .

12oz bottle to pint glass a : very creamy brown with a puffy tan head that has decent retention and some lacing . i think the look of guinness is my favorite ... does n't get much better .  fairly watery on the tongue . i was exited for this one after smelling , but the lack complexity on the palate coupled with the watery mouthfeel made this one a disappointment .

serving type : 16oz bottle appearance : pours a darker cloudy orange colour w/ a 1 finger head . plenty of lacing the whole time while drinking .  high gravity beer , this one is king . drink alot of water when drinking or a major headache occurs . so drink with caution .

opaque pitch black , moderate brown head . '' apart from the looks and the aroma : very disappointing .  a thin mouthfeel . extremely drinkable . but that 's all i can really say good about it , the taste is n't great , and the mouthfeel is too thin .
this beer poured pitch black with a thick light brown head out of a 12 oz . this is how a stout beer is supposed to look !  m - weak and thin . lifeless .
it looks like a very refreshing and tasty beer . crystal clear straw colored beer , again looks very refreshing .  mouthfeel : pretty thin , with sharp carbonation and a watery finish .

poured from a 750ml bottle into a spiegelau tulip . appearance : pours a clear medium amber color with orange highlights and a fluffy 3 finger off-white head . excellent head retention and nice lacing .  crisp to the point of being overdone , loads and loads of soda like carbonation . notes : ho hum , average , run of the mill , mediocre ... etc .

2011 batch 1 - 750ml bottle poured into a cbs snifter a : black as night . gorgeous finger-and-a-half dark brown head that leaves a nice full cap throughout consumption .  it tastes ok. kind of watered down . cant taste any malt or hops . it was too bubbly , seemed over-carbonated .
pours a deep murky brown with a nice frothy light-tan head that lasts and leaves great lacing .  m- thin and watery this could be improved greatly , but then it would probably be too sweet .

the beer itself is not opaque and almost black . very nice looking in the glass .  mouthcoating is chewy , tacky and fairly unpleasant . the mouthfeel was distracting but it does become a bit more tolerable and almost smooth once the mouthcoating becomes entrenched .

smell : malty with some pie like characteristics and caramel . very bready on the nose making it quite appetizing .  m : medium bodied beer but it is a bit light on carbonation . feels dull and flat .

this brew poured a medium head of fine bubbles and left behind a nice lacing as it receded . it has a dark cloudy red brown body and a malty aroma .  mouthfeel feels thin and weak ; this is my only real complaint with this beer .
clear golden amber body with a steady level of carbonation and head that leaves a quarter inch of film like white head ; crystal clear .  mouthfeel is very thin , again very soda like .
looked great on the pour . hazy apricot with a thin wispy head .  one thing about this beer is it feels extremely watery .
this is a delicious looking beer ! dark with a creamy , full head .  the body is kind of thin , and there 's too much carbonation , which brings the drinkability down a fair bit .
a : pours a dark brown/near black with a tall light brown head that sticks around and leaves some very nice lacing .  the mouthfeel leans toward the thin and watery side .

pours dark , great head , and it retains it thru the glass .  i 'm no fan of bud , and probably have n't had a bmc beer in 2 years , but this is not one of the worst 50 beers in the world . it 's far better than many of the cheap , crappy pale lagers in many parts of the world . although it had little taste to speak of , it was exceedingly easy to drink , which , for bmc swill , ai n't that terrible .

a 1/2 '' medium brown head takes a very long time to fade to a thick film . lacing is impressive , lots of thick , clingy curtains stick around for a while and eventually fade to thin strings that were still there when i went to wash the glass off .  mouthfeel - one of the most water beers i 've had .

hazy and dark copper-amber in color with a thick cream colored head of super tightly laced foam that left great lacing at it receded at a slow but steady rate ; the head reminds me of an improperly baked cake very slowly losing its leavening .  definative lack of carbonation , maybe this one blew it 's top at one time or another . body wise to thin to stand on its own without more carbonation , lacking in complexity .

copious carbonation visible throughout . head is a dense , small-celled foam that swarms out of the pour vigorously , and stays for ages , fading to a mottled cap .  slightly watery body and bland carbonation .
the appearance was great ( and yes i know to pour 2/3 of the bottle , let it setle , then pour the rest ) but the flavor was just not up to par .  mouthfeel is very thin and overly carbonated .
very dark brown with garnet highlights and a giant , fluffy , dark tan cap .  mouthfeel very flat for a belgian dubbel .
dark brown color with a smooth , silky , creamy , long lasting head of white foam .  taste : carbonated water , with hops and light malt thrown in . mouthfeel : light and quickly fading .

although very skunky it smells alot like pot which to me is an awesome characteristic . i am curious if the fermentation process of beck 's involves any hemp but it seem 's unprobable .  the mouthfeel is unbalanced as if the carbonation and the liquid will not merge . for as much noise the carbonation made on opening the bottle , it seems quite on the palate .

batch number 09135 poured a hazy darker orange bordering on ruby . a 2 finger bone head recedes to a small layer of tiny bubbles on the surface . it is much more ruby than other ipa 's and i think its looks great in the glass it smells of a non discriminant hop .  m - light bodied and bordering on watery . a little too carbonated imo .

well there is no way i can fault the look of this ale..its perfect for style darkest of black with a huge frothy light brown head..beeee-u-tiful .  a : it 's still carbonated , that 's something at least . too fizzy .

pours out a rich and dark amber/auburn colour with a big eggshell white head that is big and frothy and has staying power .  heard great things about this , found it in buffalo bought a 96 vintage.started promising i liked the color and the nice head , after that all downhill.had little to no smell , the taste was peppery ( overpoweringly so ) and way to sour ! the beer was way to thin and watery to go along with that taste.didnt finish the bottle just to peppery and thin for me , waiste of six bucks .
appearance : crystal clear orange-brown body with randomly-placed shades of red . very nice head retention on the whole and lots of web-like lacing .  tingly , thin watery feel .

a - golden yellow with a huge , chunky white head . excellent retention ang big chunky lace up and down the glass . beautiful beer .  m : very thin and watery -- it has a consistency not far from kool-aid .

pours a motor oil black with some brown edges and two fingers of mocha tan head . threads of lacing line the tulip . however , for some reason the beer is extremely green - perhaps it 's the victim of oxidization ?  the mouthfeel lacks more . and flat .
a foamy one-finger head with a solid , unyielding sheet of lacing . casked effect makes it look phenomenal .  sweet crackery finish , m - thin with very low carbonation .

appearance : hazy golden orange . effervescent body with a thick pillowy , white head that just wo n't quite .  not so much the taste as it had a good belgian style wheatiness to it but the body was extremely thin and almost watery . i was looking for more in the way of the mouthfeel .

huge off white head eventually settling to a half inch and tons of thick lacing . strong steady carbonation , perfection for this strong style considering lasting head on a barleywine is a rare happening .  body is a nip thin . a bit too still , but more carbonation would have blasted through the empty body of the beer , making it even less desirable .
guinness pours ruby black with a beautiful creamy white head that lingers for quite a while .  mouthfeel : way too big-bodied , way too carbonated , and way too uneven .

on-cask at the brewpub : hazyish copper tinted hay color with a puffy topping of oatmeal cream . keeps its cap for a great length and laces well across the glass in small curtains and spots .  feels thin and watery on the tongue with a low level of carbonation . bitterness is harsh and detracts from drinkability , mouthfeel is unsatisfying , and the flavors are n't interesting and complex enough to yield repeated enjoyment .

presentation : it poured beautifully into an oversized wine glass . coming out of the bottle it was an amber color , but in the glass it turned to a deep , dark maroon .  a little thin overall . mouthfeel : light-bodied and lacking . way too light and delicate of a beer to have an abv of 7.5 % .
poured dark brown with a light tan head .  i must say this beer is best on tap as everywhere i 've tried it otherwise all of its carbonation seems to be non-existant .
has a really nice fluffy one finger tan head that sticks around . lacing covers a huge portion of the glass .  the mouthfeel is way thin , but drinkability is ok .

appearance - nice copper color , cream colored head holds at a solid cap and laces quite well .  the body was disappointingly thin for such a big beer , allowing the unwelcome alcohol notes to really come through .

s- huge cherry notes with wheat right behind it . this has that waxy taste to it that is just very unappealing . great smells and mouthfeel to it , but i can not get over that medicinal taste .  thin mouthfeel with average macro carbonation . touch of caustic mouthfeel in the middle with the bitterness and petrol notes .

a - only a sliver of red around the edge . tall very tight light brown head leaving considerable lacing .  m - kind of flat on the palate with very little carbonation . hop profile caught me off guard and the mouthfeel is pretty weak .

poured into an imperial pint glass . color was a dark amber with a slight reddish tint to it . head was initially 3 fingers , but dropped down to 1 , and consisted of off white foam , almost like a meringue that clung very well to the sides .  it 's drinkable , but the body and carbonation are really lacking .

pours an impossibly crystal-clear straw color . the bubbles are as fine as you will find in a beer , crazy lacing on the sides of the glass .  m- not a lot of carbonation , kind of syrupy actually . i feel if it would have been carbonated more it would have helped a lot .

this beer poured a deep mahogany brown color . very clear and was topped with a creamy lacy head .  i recently bought a bottle and had it at home and was supprised to find that it really was not much better than the average super brewery light beer . the taste is almost nonexistant and unlike some mega beers has almost no aftertaste at all which for this beer is actually a benefit . i would compare is most to a pbr .

this stout pours a deep tawny red that appears black unless held to light , decent head .  m : mild , almost weak or watery . does not have stout presence at all ; feels like flat cola , if anything .

12 oz bottle poured into pint glass a : dark brown almost black , big head 3 fingers or more of off tan head ... . head settles to a nice layer of foam , wonder lacing . great looking beer .  the mouthfeel was watery , the body medium/light and the carbonation average .

appearance- clear , dark , copper-colored ale with persistent , cream head . full carbonation . lots of lacing .  mouthfeel was thin and tingly , and the initial flavor was sour fruit , which was fine , but then it too was quickly overtaken by the taste of grains .
looks great , but that does n't translate to mind blowing .  mouthfeel : seltzer drinkability : would be good but the mouthfeel sucks .

just when you think you have seen it all when it comes to beer appearances , this one comes along . strangely fascinating looking beer .  the mouthfeel is flat , but predictable as there are virtually no bubbles in the glass after the first minute or so . as far as drinkability goes , i 'd save it for the hot summer days , the ballpark and the cheap 30 pack for the party .

it pours an orange yellow glow through the haze . the head is massive , billowy and ice cream like in its consistency .  mostly smells and tastes like a lager pretending to be an ale . that hint of lager ( as in yuengling lager ) sits there in the background , but then there 's a nice hit of hops in there too . it 's odd , but not necessarily bad ( although certainly not a good american pale in any sense of the word ... it 's a cheap beer masquerading as an american pale ) . not great , but one to try if you 're tired of lager as your cheap beer for the minute .
big , frothy , sponge-like head towers over the brew and new fully disappears .  thin on the mouthfeel and the carbonation is way too high on this one making the thinnes hard to handle .
river horse special ale esb pours a deep cloudy gold with a massive pillowy head that took up half the glass .  mouthfeel is rather thin for a scotch ale .

30 cl brown bottle poured into a pint glass ( it 's the only glassware i own ) . a : super-thick , rich , creamy , mostly white foamy head . in fact , the head was so thick that this small 300 ml bottle would n't fit into my imperial pint glass without waiting for some of the head to thin out .  m : dammit , i hate porters like this . light , watery body , slightly oily , and slick on the palate . this would have been so much better with more body to it .
a - classic dark bronze doppelbock color .  the body was very thin and the beer lacked substance .

appearance : very much a rich dark brown color that lets no light through . great measure of head .  strong roasted malt character with a twang of hop bitterness , but really light and pale in the mouth with a watery body . no creamy mouthfeel , which was somewhat disappointing , but it was overall enjoyable . clean , pure and watery finish was n't quite what i had hoped for , as i was expecting something a little more milky/creamy/smooth .

a - poured a slightly hazy amber-straw color , with a big , fluffy , two-finger head . took several minutes to dry down to a thick cap , which left nice rings of lacing down the glass . very pretty .  pours a clear golden copper hue which leaves a creamy fast vanishing two finger head and creamy lacing , the smell is herbal grassy hops and some honey malts thats it , the mouthfeel is light and watery and has tastes of honey malts , herbal grassy hops , fresh cut grass , pale malts and finished with a mix of herbal grassiness and toffee and overall i definately would not buy again and the bitterness is only very light avoid cheers .

t : after the aroma onslaught , the hoppiness on the palette is rather subdued . still nicely bitter , with a good pine , grapefruit , bitter orange flavor . d : the aroma is a bit of a tease , but the taste does n't entirely disappoint - certainly a beer i could have again .  for the level of alcohol , there is hardly any hotness at all and a bizarrely watery and light body for a barleywine . could also stand some more hops , as i could hardly detect any at all .

nitro-tap , nice pour into a pint glass at henry 's 12th street tavern in portland . color is brownish-black , thick tan head has excellent retention all the way to the end .  m - thin , watery body , moderate carbonation , slight bitterness in the finish .
big bulky beige head 1 1/2 inches . a thin head remains throughout no matter how long it sits ( very nice ) .  m - watery , light carbonation .
pillowy head lasts well , and lacing is surprising nice , with heavy foam coverage .  the mouthfeel is surprisingly flat .

nice warm smells , clear and well-executed .  that being said i want to keep track of beers i have tried and will start to try reviewing beers i drink ) from a sampler pack found at specs liquor . tastes flat to me . no alcohol taste that i can tell of and not a whole lot of flavor . goes down easy and not much of an aftertaste .
odell 's red ale came out of the bottle an awesome red color with a fluffy off white head .  mouthfeel is thin .

a : a stunning deep brown near black with cranberry highlights . a inch of toasted head comes after a medium pour . the head slowly fades to an impressive 1/3 inch . lacing on a dark beer ?  thin , harsh , and astringent- the mouthfeel is where the beer suffers the most .

this one certainly fits the bill . appearance is nice at a dark brown near black with deep crimson hues and a thin tan head .  it has a below average mouthfeel - boring , too watery and macro-brewish .

bottle purchased at liquor world , somerville , ma poured a slightly hazy , very light and pale straw yellow with a tight , bubbly , three-finger , bone white head . tons of cascading , spider webbing lacing formed large ridges that last well after the beer was finished .  thin , watery , overcarbonated .
wow , the pour results in an inch thick head and a nice burned orange body . the lacing left behind is like an intricate work of art .  mouthfeel is like most others ... flat .

a : pours a dark , um , brown in the glass with some light penetration indicating it 's not opaque . the head is pretty fizzy , with two fingers of creamy beige bubbles generated at first , before receding into a half-finger cap on top of the brew . some streaks of lacing as i drink .  m - watery and sticky . its almost a thin beer .

i rarely describe a beer 's color as `` black '' , since most are actually a deep brown , but this poured like motor oil ! i got just over a finger of deep-tan head with decent retention off of my pour .  a bit bland for the style . body is a bit like soda water , and fades really fast .
beer is a dark , dark color , with just the slightest hints of ruby at the edges and a coffee colored head . beautiful to look at , and almost as nice to drink .  thin and tingly mouthfeel .
appearance : nice easy lacing with a light head , lively , golden color .  horrible macro version of the style .

fantastic lacing & head retention is als really good , a peresitent film hugs the orval goblet all the way down s : slight hints of choclate , cherry & oak barrels t : choclate & oakyness up front .  the mouthfeel is light bodied and watery .

poures a deep tranparent amber in color . leaving a half finger of retention.thick gloppy rings of lace . : ( i was pretty excited to taste this after its wonderful appearance and terrific aroma .  the mouthfeel is light and watery , not much substance . a very watered down dunkel , i would skip this in the future .

a : pours a hazy golden with a thick bubbly white head that slowly faded into a thick film that lasted the whole beer through and left an incredible fuzzy sheet of solid lacing down the glass . beautiful .  finish really kills me as bad oaks comes off ... mouthfeel is the true downfall of this beer , watery light with no depth ... easy to drink but not good enough that i would .
a : pitch black , slightly viscous . excellent head formation and nice lacing . this is how an ais should look in the glass .  a thin mouthfeel and not a lot of carbonation .

mayan-inspired schwarzbier ? attractive pour , tons of lace and strong retention . fluffy foam that rises above the rim of the glass with irregular crags and peaks .  mouthfeel is very flat and is not impressing at all .

the appearence is exceptional . pours a stout lovers favorite color , motor oil black . less than a finger of head , but it is a very dark brown .  the problem is that the beverage is thin and flat on the palate and leaves a really unpleasant metallic aftertaste .

beautiful , clear dark copper color . excellent clarity here . a moderate cap of light whipped cream , tiny bubbles mostly , sits at the top . this is as pretty as an ipa can be .  m : flat . way too sweet for the ( non-existant ) level of carbonation .
the hop aroma is like sticking your nose in a bag of cascade hops and taking a deep breath .  mouthfeel is way watery and i feel like it is slightly udnercarbonated .

pours a very nice looking dark ruby with a thick tan head which remains forever and leaves sticky lacing in my delirium glass . a beautiful beer , i wish they all looked like this .  it does bring vanilla to mind . the sweetness almost removes it from the style of beer . far to thin for a brown ale .

s -- amazing smell of dark chocolate and roasted coffee , no sweetness to it , but very pleasant . t -- the coffee in the smell comes through the strongest , with a hint of the chocolate .  t : cheap carbonated corn . m : if it werent for the bottle this beer would have sunk years ago .

a : pours a dark brown , almost black , with a tan 1 finger head and decent lacing s : lots of coffee , chocolate and roasted malt , cant wait to drink this one t : not as much coffee as i thought would be there , a lot of chocolate and roasted malt coming through with a nice coffee bitterness .  not sourdough , but sour-smelling dough . taste is very flat and bland . malty and earthy , but with a dry finish .
appearance : almost completely black with a large , creamy , tan head that had very good retention . nice rings of lacing .  mouthfeel is overly carbonated .

a : pours a pale lemon/lemonade color with a hazy body full of carbonation and bubbles . head has good retention , about 2 fingers thick , with beautiful lacing .  mouthfeel is disappointing ; thin and watery , with too much carbonation for my taste .

pours a perfect cloudy gold with a big fluffy head .  a - light , clear , yellow color with a thick head that dissipated quickly s - beer , cheap beer t - beer from a can , cheap beer from a can m - thin , flat , not much d - went down smooth , probably because i 'd wisely iced it down with some ice and rock salt so it would get really cold .
pours a beautiful light honey color , having little to no head kept it from getting a better score .  the body was water and medium light .
the cascade that forms when this brew is poured is excellent . it posesses a thick , heavy , cream-filled head and awesome amber-hue .  m : bubbly and very thin .
poured into an ommegang chalice a reddish/purplish brown color with a solid half-inch of head.. perfect for the style .  very thin mouthfeel , almost tasted flat , nothing special .

the pour is beauty in the glass ( a snifter this time ) . a mysterious murky deep orange that still reveals the active carbonation rising up to the dense 3 fingers of sturdy , creamy off-white crown . once it was swirling in my snifter i got strong fresh hop tanginess , herbal esthers , big florals , and a kind of peanut brittle sweetness .  tasting it my first impression was how thin the body was for an english porter , compared to , for instance , the excellent fuller 's london porter or young 's double chocolate .
real dark brown . nice big dark tan head that retained throughout the beer and laced the glass nicely .  mouthfeel : very carbonated with a thin , almost watery feeling .

bottle poured into a dogfish head signature glass it pours clear copper color . a fluffy eggshell white head is very long lasting and intricate lacing across the glass .  m - this bottle was flat . this gave the beer a thick and somewhat unenjoyable mouthfeel .

this beer black and entirely opaque with a thick and persistant off-white head with flecks of tan in it - very nice looking beer .  slightly watery body with adequate carbonation . mouthfeel is slick and thin with a metallic and astringent finish as it dries .

s - smells very inviting ! full of citrusy hop aromas ( pineapple , grapefruit , and orange ) and some pine scents as well . t - taste is different than expected . d - moderately drinkable - it would be nice if the malt flavors competed a little more with the hops to help balance it a little .  it 's watery on the palate , surprisingly so - i 've had beers of 3 to 4 % alcohol that had more body . the finish is lightly astringent and bitter .
it smells delicious , but it needs more sweetness and less bitterness to balance the tartness of the brett , no fusels , less carbonation and more body .  zero carbonation .
visually it 's perfect . nice copper color with a fully creamy head .  the first thing i notice with this beer is the watery mouthfeel . the mouthfeel is terrible .
a beautiful , reminiscent of the normal guinness cream top decks this dark copper colored beer . blanket lacing .  the mouthfeel was very thin for a stout .

a : beautiful , clear , dark ruby body under a majestic two-finger head of creamy , sticky tan foam . tons of lace . truly spectacular . s : a little underpowered - light acetic sting , some sweet fruit , and a bit of husky malt .  it has a difficult time making a favorable impression though since the body/mouthfeel is way too light for the style . what makes it to the taste buds is washed away in seconds as the anemic body collapses into nothingness . as a result , it 's hard to appreciate any depth or complexity in the beer at all .
appearance : pours dark brown with a hint of red . the head is a nice frothy tan with good lacing .  mouthfeel : thin and watery body , medium carbonation overall : highly overrated .

a - caramel-butterscotch gold with a thick off-white head , very nice looking .  mouthfeel is very thin with low carbonation , almost watery , drinkability is poor , huge bitterness and watery mouthfeel is a disappointment .
pours a deep black color with a half inch frothy head .  the mouthfeel is pretty sad on this one . very watery and thin .

great look to this beer .  feels really dry and grainy , very prickly in my mouth and sand papery , not impressed . there 's some interesting flavor components playing which eachother , but ultimately the mouthfeel and the harsh finish really let it down , shame that wo n't be reflected so well in the overall score with the way the weighting system works .
